review_title: The PMD Program is a great job - for about 2 years
pros:
Excellent training program
Vast product platform and deep, global information resources
You can learn a lot if you want to
Looks good on your resume
Great name recognition with prospects
Good life/work balance and flexible hours
cons:
The PMD program is engineered for failure.  If the failure rate is consistently 95%+, perhaps the problem is with the program and not the trainees.  This is not an accident.  The program is specifically designed to generate new accounts for senior FAs who will inherit your clients when you (inevitably) fail.  This is not a design flaw, it's the point of the program.  Senior management couldn't care less if you fail, because they are counting on you failing so that they can transfer your assets to the senior FAs.  As a PMD, you are completely expendable - the financial services equivalent of the red shirt guys on Star Trek.

The firm wants you to annuitize the business that you bring in but this will generate, on average, ten to fifteen basis points a month in revenue, based on total assets.  Do the math and don't kid yourself.

By month 12, you are more or less forced to begin selling variable annuities or closed-end funds (the highest commission products) in order to survive.  Nothing else will generate sufficient revenue to even get close to making your hurdles.

The PMDs all start out very optimistic and by the 9 month hurdle, start looking scared.  By the 12 month hurdle, panic is beginning to set in.  By the 18 month hurdle, everyone is blatantly looking for another job.

Obviously, if you have family money or an existing book of at least 15MM, you'll probably be ok.  But if you don't, look out.

Sadly, there is absolutely no opportunity for any kind of advancement or lateral move within the organization. If you can't make your hurdles (and almost no one can), you are out.

Finally, unless you are very lucky with your particular branch and branch manager, be prepared for working in the most unfriendly environment possible.  Senior (non-PMD) FAs will barely acknowledge your existence and in many cases, will actually refuse to speak to you.  Hmmm... perhaps they know something you don't know?

review_title: Graduate Level at Bank of America
pros:
Great first step and a career notch on your CV. You won't be changing the world here or even remotely close but it gives you a good sense of confidence and a good sense of work place practices if you are fresh out of college.

Great work life balance though, very family oriented however and there is a clear preference in terms of flexibility for people with families which is a little unfair but at least it is there. A nice place to retire in. You can get lucky with teams also as some teams are great, some teams are hell. Expect late nights and weekends now and then due to incredibly inefficient release processes in some cases.

Plenty of encouragement for career advancement but then when you tick all the boxes, it's not enough so be prepared to walk if you want to move up. It's a giant corporation and has all of the attributes of one so a little push pull is needed to get to where you want to be.

Great community spirit. The Bank does a lot for the local community and really is heavily involved with philanthropic efforts. Even if it is just for PR it does benefit the country.
cons:
Hard work and exceptional talent doesn't really count as much as it should.

Spend time and money rejuvenating old redundant processes and let developers focus on development not bureaucracy.

As a company, the bank tries desperately to think and move like a tech company but ultimately stiffened regulations and fear of change from senior managements brings good development and projects to a halt. Additionally there is just an awful amount of mediocre developers just doing enough to survive and this leads to a lot of frustration and costly meetings where good developers are driven to agree to the majority rule.

No realization for the power of open source technology.

Time is seen as the only real measure of experience not performance.

pros: large organization = might provide opportunity in normal economic times, allowed autonomy in many situations, pretty standard benefits, lots of various businesses happening all around provide an opportunity to learn.
cons: Large organization = no one knows who you are or what you do unless you work in a prime city like Charlotte, NY, or Boston.  Too much time is spent on anonymous phone meetings.  Not really a people company, I felt more like just a number everyday.

pros: Great brand recognition.  Senior leadership is highly skilled.   The orgainization works extremely hard to educate the team about the corporate vision and direction of the company.  Ethics and quality standards are engrained into the culture.
cons: The Home Loans and Insurance division is struggling to close loans on time due to multiple system issues.  As a result, work/life balance is not in place for operational employees.  People are great and want to do a great job, but redundant procedures and operational systems hinder production.

review_title: Not good! If you love micro-management then go for it! Very disatisfied.
pros: good benefits and holiday's off but they work you like a donkey for it!
cons: change the way they do things every 3 months it seems. no direction from the very top. seems like a chicken with his head cut off is running the company. Training is absolutely horrible. They care about sells and revenue and that's it. don't believe the hype they spit out. The goals they set for sales is ridiculous. Don't expect to hit they very often. It was the worst job I every had. I left on my on choice without a job on hand if that tells you anything.

pros: Everyone is keen to do their best, but not as stuck up as some other investment banks. Has a good team atmosphere
cons: Very bureaucratic. There is a constant stream of compliance tests that have nothing to do with your work function. I.T is a nightmare.

review_title: Only men and "token women" get promoted.  Brains and creativity = management gets scared
pros: Some of the best benefits out there, and once you are hired, it's almost impossible to get fired.
cons: Don't expect to have your ideas heard or to be acknowledged for your contributions unless you happen to be somebody's golden boy.  The money is good and they treat you well, but the way to promotion has more to do with who you know than the quality of your work.

pros:
Hourly it Pays a bit better than some commercial banks.
Health insurance is private Aetna
cons:
They don't drug test!!!!
No bonus when you make a sale or "bundle". Many bank give bonus
High cost health insurance. Comes out of your check every 2 weeks from 50 to 100 dollars
Pay rise is up to managers discretion. If they don't like you forget about your raise at the end of the year by the way no more than 50 cents. 
They dont like to promote within only it you brown nose a lot 
They do not sponsor you for licenses.  
They don't like to hire many students.

pros: Benefits are nice. 401k matching, 12 weeks paternity leave, vaca time, and casual dress. Can get overtime pay. Dont have to put in long hours.
cons: Once you're in a department, hard to move up. Have to move around. There are a few exceptions of course. But, most managers / team leads stay in their positions for years and years so there is no where for you to go.

review_title: Bank of America has good core benefits but going in the wrong direction
pros: Medical, dental, vacation, nice staff
cons: Selling to meet a daily goal has become the norm . We no longer sold to their needs only what the computer prompts us to sell. Enormous pressure, stressed out employees and unhappy clients

job_title: Customer Relationship Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: There is plenty of opportunities to advance your career. While the insurance is not the greatest, there are also a lot of other corporate perks such as discounts to several services including auto insurance, child care and phone.
cons: As a whole the company is very hard to work with. While there are opportunities to advance, a lot of them require relocation. Also the company has a hard time keeping their policies strait and end up contradicting their own instructions. Additionally, their training is all system training and nothing relating to soft skills such as talking to customers.

review_title: Big opportunity and quick movement upwards.
pros: Awesome team, lots of support, with new incentive plan sales are measured and correlated directly with the company message for enhancing the quality of financial lives. One team cooperation has improved year over year!
cons: If you show up bad on any report, expect a lot of busy-work. This can be helpful for some, but it can become excessive... Especially if your banking center is poorly staffed (as many have had cuts.)

job_title: Loan Processor/Junior Underwriter in Saint Charles, MO
pros: The pay is pretty good.
cons: This company Sucks. When I work there from the moment i walked in I knew it was going to be a short stay! Their trainning methods are a joke and their Hr assistance is terrible. I receive a warning for my performace  review because i closed a loan two day past the dead line. I then received a written warning a week later for being one closing behind the goal. The week after that i receive a reward for being the first person to to meet there goal from my trainning class. Then The week after that i got my final warning for performance. I kid you not I could not make this up. I couldn't help but her cooler talk of people forming to gether to file lawsuits against this company. I quit that very same day!

review_title: Good company to work for just need more autonomy to make decisions.
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Portland, OR
pros: People that work there really enjoy their jobs.  The customers are respectful and most are a pleasure to serve.  The benefits are BofA are good.
cons: People need to be able to say things in their own words and not have scripts to follow.  Pushing sales is not a way to get business either.  Building relationships is the key to success in banking, or any business for that matter.

review_title: I just started a few months ago. The company seems to be going through some changes. Some positions are being eliminated
pros: Benefits seem to offer a lot for a decent premium. Child care is reimbursed up to $240/month per child
cons: The teller training leaves something to be desired. It's computer based in the banking center. No direction at all and I was constantly having to redirect customers whom I could not help being as how I took the training while sitting at a teller window.

review_title: Quality company and good job.  Lots of opportunity to move up very fast.  Could be very fun but job just wasn't for me.
pros:
This part of the company is expanding quickly with room for growth and movement to other parts of the company.
Opportunities for bonuses
Tons of overtime availability
Easy if you aren't in market hours
cons:
Not much flexibility within job hours
Work is extremely draining for introverts (as you can imagine being on the phone alllllllll day)
Micro-managed (bonuses sometimes tied to using phrases like "my pleasure" rather than "no problem")
Can be chaotic
Always rolling out something new and there is no way you can know everything you need to know (this part can be fun but yet a drag)

pros: With a good manager and the right location, you have the ability to develop and grow. The bank is a large company with that comes the opportunity to pursue a number of career paths beyond traditional banking.
cons: The bank is such a large company, it's easy to get lost. Like most companies, the benefits continue to shrink and as an employee in a staff or operations area, incentive and stock options were challenging. Since I wasn't on the revenue generating side, it was a blackhole as to why people received bonuses and stock. Basically you needed to be a "favorite".

review_title: Great place to be if in the right team
job_title: Operations Research Analyst in London, England
pros:
Great scale, lots of opportunity
Access to expertise from various areas readily available
Very good benefits
cons:
Tends to consistently underpay compared to other BB
Lots of politics and lack of flexibility when it comes to crossing LOBs internally
Very keen on the process and lack of flexibility when things go wrong
If you get stuck in the wrong team, only chance of getting out is jumping to another team in your LOB. Moves to different LOBS nearly impossible even after careful personal networking - pigeonholing at its best.

pros:
Great corporate benefits, including emergency childcare, small reimbursement scheme for purchasing a low carbon vehicle, pension, private health care etc.
Location is very close to St Paul's station and many amenities so very convenient to get to.
Possibility of flexible working is there, dependent on your manager entirely.
cons:
Management needs to be more understanding of employee's engagements outside of work (be it community service, childcare, elder care, etc).
Training also not particularly highlighted nor emphasized. Compliance training is stressed but training for the individual's development and enhancement are not highlighted in the slightest bit.

pros: Overall (in my area anyway) good life-work balance; equitable pay; balanced work load.
cons:
Lots of turnover (management especially); forced rankings during performance appraisal led to inequitable treatment; constant survey of employees but little effort to correct issues; promotion seemed due to more who you know rather than on objective criteria; HR systems horrible (performance, internal and job application process); lack of focus on customer experience.
  To  bad prior CEO had bigger dreams and also buckled to Bush's guy and bought Merrill Lynch and Countrywide and MBNA. Fine company before that and the stock has paid and continued to pay for it (down!). I started when stock had rose to near ~$55/share and now look at it...

pros:
Compensation is Competitive, Bonuses, Vacation time.
401K Matching Program is excellent
Hours of Operation are perfect for families
Customer Interaction, Building Relationships with Regulars
cons:
Impossible Sales Goals
Non Stop Share Point Reporting every hour on the hour
Condescending Conference calls twice a week
Lack of Training

pros: Bank of America is a progressive company that is stable in it's business and offers a variety of job positions one can choose from. Health insurance offered for even part-time employees.
cons: Some managers prevent the successful and talented employees from job growth and career development by blocking other opportunities and not providing training, leadership and IDP's as they should. "They" like to keep the good employees locked down in a department and let go of the lazy ones.

review_title: Contact Center - Sr. Customer Service Specialist
job_title: Senior Customer Service Specialist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: I work for the call center for BoA & although call centers can be stressful work environments, BoA makes sure that employees are comfortable and have available resources. Pay is reasonable & competitive for "just answering phones"
cons: The managers in call center environment can tend to be micro managing when it comes to your schedule. When you go to break/lunch is all determined by a dept called Workforce that assigns you your break time based on "business need."

pros: Good experience in the financial industry and exposure to how banks operate.  Great chance to better understand what the focus is and goals of a major financial institution look and feel like.
cons: Commission structure isn't going to drastically impact your annual income unless something has changed with how they structure their compensation plan for personal bankers.  Great entry level opportunity to be a personal banker.

job_title: Business Support Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great benefits.  Ability to move around company.  In the right group, you are always busy and always learning and are acknowledged and sometimes rewarded when you give extra effort.  You can never know it all at Bank of America.  There is always something to learn and contribute.
cons: Poor staff management in some departments (not all).  I have worked with wonderful managers.  However, one bad apple can spoil the entire moral of a team and when this occurs, there is no resolution as human resources protects leadership.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Simi Valley, CA
pros:
Probably some of the best benefits a company can provide to its employees as far as insurance and a 401K plan, as well as benefits of discounts for being an employee.
Free banking.
Community Volunteering is championing.
cons:
Layoffs became so common the last few years that we called them layoff Wednesday/Thursday.
Recognition is low among the common folk. 
And constant restructuring of departments - department and title name changed 4x before I left (was still doing the same the work). 
Structuring  of Mortgage Financial side was and remains unstable. Company likes to outsource and takes shortcuts on processes, regardless of financial loss and/or error .

pros: Established Company with multiple opportunities globally.
cons: Not a meritocracy.  Most leaders are promoted based on longevity not merit.  The organization also has multiple cultures that are a reflection of the unit leadership.  Some cultures are great but most are not.  Many senior leaders are not leaders but managers who have been promoted to leadership roles without leadership/people training.  This leads to excessive turnover.

job_title: Client Service Representative in New York, NY
pros: Very strong in promoting from within as long as you show initiative and desire to advance. Support is there depending on your FC location.
cons: Technology is really old,. Too many systems for simple transactions. No bonuses and incentives for CSR's. Full-time workers only get 30 min break for some reason. Some locations do not use cash machines behind the teller window, which makes it more difficult for tellers to provide service at busy times. Goals are set too high considering the traffic experienced in the FC location. Low pay when compared to banks like Chase, TD Bank, Wells Fargo, Citi, etc.

review_title: For a bank that big you'd think almost everything should be structured and streamlined, right? NOPE
pros: There were 4 months of training
cons:
4 months of crappy training. You sit in front a monitor viewing what looked like an 1980s assembled graphics content and click thorough the whole thing, for 8 hours a day. 

There's this thing known as a "click" culture a. t BofA. Basically, just click through all your mandatory banking regulations and training. Employees there learned about the regulations gradually over time as they had either violated some or had learned through others' mistakes, but definitely not thoroughly through training. And for someone like myself, this lack of proper training and then put on the job to deal with other's money, stresses  me out. Quit 2 months right after. Didn't want to think of potentially ruining someone's books.

review_title: Does management know who does what? Who is a leader?
pros: Benefits are very good. The way the company structures employee networks and offers employees to volunteer in their communities is awesome.
cons:
Too many managers and managers of managers.  It enough leaders anywhere. Reduce executive and managers. Have more workers. To be a leader of an area should mean you’ve worked at least a year in the role you are leading. No one above me knows our role functions. 
Pay has gotten reduced for those with years in. After 5 years I make barely above minimum wage for the company (and two levels of difference).

review_title: Bank of America is just another bank
pros: A job that provides a great learning experience in banking and also good experience for future jobs related in business.
cons: Working at Bank of America is that there is not much opportunities within the company. Most of the time from what I have seen is that Bank of America will hire people outside of Bank of America. Also, working in retail banking, there isn't really any job security even if you've been working there for over 10 years. You can easily lose your job over something small if a co-worker wants you fired.

review_title: Bank Of America-A place where you dream to work
pros:
1) One of the most admired organization in the word
2) Treat employees as an asset and respect them
3) Excellent domain to work with
4) Since we dont have any client, work pressure is minimum
5) Free transportation, food etc
6) One of the Paymaster in the industry
7) Excellent senior leadership
8) A pool of brilliant people where exists a healthy competition
9) Opportunity to learn and apply advanced technologies 

These are the main reason why i prefer bank of america. However these are all my personal feelings and i hope it would help you. Thank You All
cons:
1) infrasturcture
2) Restricted enviornment with alot of secuirty norms
3) Less onsite opportunities

review_title: Solid place to start a retail banking career, but much depends on who your manager and market executives are.
pros: Great brand name. Co-workers are generally nice and easy to get along with.  Good benefits, and the company seems to genuinely want to help the community. Most of the managers I worked with were good bosses and good people.
cons: The branch I worked at had 3 different managers in one year, so that was difficult to deal with. Our market executive kept trying to change things to boost our numbers, which resulted in a lot of confusion and lack of focus and stability.

pros: Benefits Benefits Benefits.  The time off, medical, dental, maternity/paternity, and many more are amazing.  Plus, by being a bank of America associate you get lots of discounts at major retailers.
cons: There is not very good communication between upper management and people in the branches.  The training could also use a little updating and go more into depth.  Support is also very important.  Sometimes the branches are so busy that when you have a question or need help there is no one around to lead you.

review_title: The Bank that will Weather the Current Crisis
pros: Bank of America is a strong, secure company.  It is an industry leader that I am proud to work for.  There are opportunities, especially if you can relocate.  The company does care about work-life balance and the benefits a good.  There is also a wide variety of work within a company of this size.
cons: There is little that comes to mind in this category.  I enjoy working, it beats having to watch daytime TV.  Bank of America allows you to do what you enjoy.  There does seem to be a little bit of a communication gap somewhere between senior management and middle management though.

pros: There are a lot of different functions in the bank so there is opportunity to try out different roles in different function areas. If you have a six sigma certificate, it might help a lot in finding a job in the bank.
cons: Lower pay, Consumer banking culture and mindset. Charlotte seems to be the center of the world in this company. It is hard to imagine how its culture is going to be merging with that of Merrill Lynch as they have very different styles. In addition, BoA has a very poor severance package in case you get laid off. It is abysmal compared with any other banks.

review_title: Will Bank of America evolve quick enough?
pros: Bank of America is a world class organization.  The culture is very competitive compare to other banks.  Because its dominant market share, you are expected to produce in the fast paced environment.  The market share, its superior training, the drive to be number one offer great brand name and recognition.  There are numerous opportunities for career growth because the bank is so big.
cons:
Although the management promotes open communication, employees are not comfortable to speak up.
The pay range tends to be lower than competitors even though you may be producing more with higher goals.

review_title: A great place to work if you don't need hand holding
pros: flexibility, decent pay (regardless of current events) and an extremely complicated business and legal structure means you will never be bored.  I've been at the bank for 3 years and still feel lost at times.  There is opportunities for continuous learning and I've never felt bored at the bank.  There is always new challenges presenting themselves.  The company continuously is in acquisition mode which makes it extremely challenging at times but this adds to the lack of bordom
cons: no structured review process at end of year, no insight into ranking system, bonus % ratio, etc.

review_title: A healthy career or a lack there of ...
job_title: Senior Project Analyst in Concord, CA
pros: If you are fortunate enough to work in a group of settled associates and are able to built that family relationship, that is the best reason to work here. I have created a family away from home, we work together and help to create some sanity in this ever changing environment.
cons: We are consistently laying associates off. Teams are very lean and the stress of the same workflow is evident.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer Loan Servicing Specialist in Saint Austell, England
pros: Overall some of the best reasons to work at BOA would be the job opportunities, ability to grow, and compensation.
cons: Bank of America once you start working there is a place by all employees known for its incompetence and how badly things are run / handled. Although the pay is fair and there are plenty of opportunities for growth and your owrk is always acknowledged it is a very stressful enviornment.

review_title: Stay away from Bank of America
pros: The benefits were great, including extra health costs and pay outs for child care.
cons: Each and every week there was a new form or policy.  Its great to keep up with the times but just because a teller 5 states away was conned does not mean your branch will be.  The change of policies and forms make it nearly impossible to be in compliance for audit unless that is all you do.  Staff quickly learns how to work toward reports and not for the customers.  They will also cut staff dramatically and will replace full timers with part timers.  This forces management to secretly work off the clock, which you can be fired for but feel the pressure to do everyday.

pros: Allows work life balance, and allows working from home.  When working with people in other time zones, they are very respectful of when you are requested to attend meetings, ensuring the meeting time is not too early or too late.
cons: Organizationally they have too many departments doing the same thing, and no one communicates, creating duplicate effort and fighting for the same resources.  They have too many goals.  Actually they cover just about everything you need to improve the business, so they are not focusing resources appropriately.

review_title: Vast Amount of Opportunities - However, each group is different.
pros: Bank of America is such a large company so there are many different opportunities to take advantage of. They also have a cometitive benefits package and are one of the last companies to offer a pension.
cons: Each group can have a different culture. Really try to figure out what they job and culture is like before you make a move. Some are more flexible than others.

pros: Great growth opportunity. A lot of locations, so if traveling or having to move, it allows for the worker to keep there position. Also there is a lot of training potential. You can pretty much sign up for any training that you want.
cons: Agressive sales focus isn't for everyone. They keep a strong focus on numbers, instead of the customer. It forces the worker to become somewhat cold hearted. Which can lead to a pretty big chip on your shoulder.

review_title: Used to be great, now it is a horrible place to work
pros:
Work from Home - great perk, easy to join the program, simple enough for anyone that is not client facing.

The pay is fair, even a bit above average.

We have some great managers (few and far between).
cons:
Overall Management is Poor - we have a large number of managers who walk on egg shells and will not make a decision until they have hosted a half dozen meetings on the topic.  Getting things done is very tough, takes weeks to months to complete the most mundane efforts. 

We reorg management every 6 months, no kidding!

review_title: Strong tactical company, very weak on strategy...continual organizational restructuring highlights this.
pros: Typically strong team to work with and good work ethic.  Values how things get done in concert with what gets done.
cons: Short sided and "siloed" investment strategies.  Very poor conversion on acquisition synergies.  Global expansion starts with relationships not products...most US based companies fail to recognize this key element in growing outside of the US.

review_title: Bank of America is a world leading financial institution
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: There is a wealth of information that could be overwhelming to new comers. However, it's use of technology is first-rate in the world. The structured work duties is beautiful. Access to knowledge is humungous. There is a great room for growth and moving up in the company.
cons: Need some work on the training for new employees and be more generous with expenses.

review_title: overall a good place to work
pros: good benefits and flexibility, they helped pay some of tuition
cons: their benefits got a little worst each year, health benefits got a little more expensive and with less, like the tuition reimbursement. It used to be where it didn't matter your degree, than they changed it and had to be job related.

review_title: Good place to work, but has many issues to sort out still
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Washington, DC
pros: Smart people, and interesting work - the current environment is difficult but navigating through these challenges can be exciting. Salary was pretty good, and the work-life balance was good as well. The company finally seems to be finding its identity.
cons: Still a disjointed and "siloed" organization from all the multiple mergers - much work needed to complete integration, but progress has been made. Effects of cost-cutting still being felt, including the loss of talent. Culture still in a state of flux.

review_title: Good job if you are not managment
pros: The pay is good, reasonable life/work balance most of the time. The cooperation culture is getting better. Right now we get to work from home a lot.
cons:
A lot of management churn. If you don't like your manager wait 18 months and that person will change as will the manager above that. 
some long hours or extra hours. Used to be infrequent for a release. but now it happens all the time so that off shore can get meetings in with on shore. with no adjustment for regular hours for taking the extra meetings at 7 am and 10 pm.

pros: Benefits were great, they reimburse for school, paid maternity leave, bonuses every three months, etc.
cons: Depending on the branch you might have to work six days a week, if you do not reach your goals you will get a warning and possibly demoted, if you're not with a client you're expected to make outbound calls or stand in lobby, training every few months can be ridiculous with a trainer breathing down your neck as you're helping a client. They train you to do whats best for the client, but honestly they just want you to sell banking products. You have to ask permission to use the bathroom and ensure someone is covering your area if you do.

pros:
Advancing opportunity  available 
Culture built to balance work and life 
Learning and development opportunities to strengthen your skills and help you move forward with your career
cons:
Limited flexibility with schedules 
Yearly merit increases rarely more than 2-3%
Pay not competitive with external companies 
Education and training needs major improvement for content around daily job

review_title: Very sales focused, stressful environment, great job for students or those not looking for long term career
job_title: Teller Operation Supervisor in Naperville, IL
pros: Great Benefits, employee discounts are pretty good, perk not to pay for bank account services and having paid federal holidays off is nice bonus. Coworkers have always had great personalities, a lot of fun to work with.
cons: Sales pressure is on at all times, not enough staff on hand to provide excellent service to customers, and tellers are down to one at majority of locations. Stressful environment. Customers treat you like emotional doormats if you let them.

review_title: Good People working for a Not So Good Management
pros: Most people care about doing a good job and making the company better and treat each other with respect and a desire to achieve a common goal.
cons: Most of upper management appears to have little interest in the people working for the company.  as shown be a complete lack of focus on determining a plan / path to follow.  Major swings in direction come in waves as each new exec attempts to make their impression on the organization without any regard for what was or is being done.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Amazing benefits, great work environment , teams are very dynamic. Bank of America ensures that they invest in amazing training opportunities and in their employees who are their main assets. Recognition programs are in place to help morale and change is constant. Although customers can get high rate, there is always a great work life balance .
cons: During my time at Bank of America there were eliminating positions. It was really hard to transition into corporate positions from banking center settings.

pros: They sucker you in with a competitive pay and good benefits.
cons:
However they do no tell you that your position is based not only on being a teller but you also have monthly percentages in how much credit cards, accounts, etc you sell. They will let you go if these percentages are not met. I thankfully found better opportunities else where!

The whole hiring process was extremely unprofessional when I was getting hired they fired my recruiter and left me stranded with no one to call  it took a month for me to get hired. 

If thats not a red flag from the get go I don't know what is. 

If you are looking for a company that values your time look elsewhere TRUST ME.

job_title: IT Operations Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great corporate facilities and environment.
cons: WAY TO MANY FOREIGNERS (mainly from INDIA and ARABIA) occupying those floors and cubicles through and about in BOA's Information Technology departments in their uptown Charlotte, NC location.  At least half, if not more, are foreigners with student visas, or the like.  Unless you don't mind working in a work environment located in Sir Lanka, Bangladesh, and other cities of INDIA, then you might be heavily discouraged and deeply disappointed in their talent searches outside the good 'ol USA.  Something very wrong about that picture....particularly, from one of America's largest financial institutions here in the USA.

pros: Good solid company. Excellent exit opportunities. Great management and coworkers. Despite the overwhelming feeling of "Corporate America" life, coworkers still willing to be personal and get to know you. I personally enjoyed my time working for them, however there always is fluctuations in consistency with any large company.
cons: As I mentioned, it has a very corporate feel. You get used to this with time however, and can really start appreciating what truly matters in a workforce. There is a great deal of bureaucracy, so if you are an individual that moves quickly, you have to learn how to navigate it. <not really a negative, just stating an additional skillet you must develop in order to succeed.

review_title: Not too good place for work if you are a male employee
pros: The entire company's focus is on women employees...their safety, their work life balance etc.
cons:
Being a male employee if you work there, u feel like a candidate of general category in govt institutions where all the advantages are limited to reserved category only. Here too much women orientation. Women are given preferred shift timings and instead male employees are asked to work in late shift timings or sometimes beyond that as extended hours.
It is a very good company for people who don't know how to work and don't want to work.
as no night allowance, no performance based incentives. No difference between a performer and a non performer.

pros: Great benefits. Company works to provide associates in general with things they request. Can be a good place for long-term employment many associates have been there for decades.
cons: Sometimes work is slow. You may be laid off. Many associates have been there for decades. Too much compliance training over and over again. Some classes require too much thinking just to understand what is said in one sentence that may mention a group or department that is mad up of 4 or 5 words and that department may had been called something else a year or two ago.

pros:
-Work Life Balance
-Good starting salaries
-Opportunities for growth if you are willing to move
cons:
-Not enough staff; laid off most of teller staff
-Way to many leaders telling you different things
-Always sales focused; not very customer focused
-Not enough budget to run operations
-Not much room for growth unless you wish to focus on sales
-Disciplined for overtime that is forced on you
-Too many tasks, not enough people

pros:
okay health plans and benefits like 4% match on 401k
bonuses are available to you of your successful and motivated
cons: bonuses are quarterly not monthly. payouts can be cut as high as 70% for things not in your control such as others failing compliance or one poor customer experience and does bad scoring for reviews. your career stops here unless you commit 5 years and then take a assit manager position for another 2 with no bonuses... they do not look to promote you or help you get into other feilds your investment is in your self

review_title: Organisation providing good atmosphere for a satisfactory career
pros: Good exposure at work, salary levels are far superior to those of industry, decent support from top management
cons: Expectation of unhealthy working hours, certain biases to people who don't gel with the seniors for their parties and break the outside work, rigidity to rotation of job roles

review_title: Great Company on the wrong path
job_title: Small Business Consultant in Washington, DC
pros:
Benefits 
Name
Reputation
Great networking and career building
Training is excellent! 
Paid vacation and holidays 
Able to advance in the company quickly if you play great corporate politics
cons: Sales pressure exceeds that of the Wells Fargo crisis. You are asked not only to produce numbers for your own role, but refer to other partners within the bank. You have a credit goal with no leads and less than a 20% approval rate. You are what your number is. Changed performance management rules so that if you don’t produce month over month you can be fired quickly.. but you are paid quarterly. Impossible to use vacation due to suffocating sales goals

review_title: Some good, some bad.  Like any other large institution.
job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very large company, many opportunities for promotion or career changes.  There are some incredibly talented and smart people working for BofA.
cons: So large that often one group did not know what the other group was doing or how to leverage each other.  Change happens soooo often that many employees feel it is hard to keep up and a constant game of what have you done for me lately?

review_title: Bank of America does not promote
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: It was a great place to learn a lot of information and start a career in the banking industry. They teach the basics of professionalism, customer service, and thorough training and updates.It was nice to feel like the company would always be stable due to its size.
cons: Respect. Lack of advancement opportunity. They always talk about how they want you to get promoted, and tell you how to get there...but when you are doing everything they want you to, they still don't promote you. I waited 2 years for a "promised" promotion that never happened. The only thing they had to day was they needed more consistency. wtf?!

review_title: Bank of America is a large, stable institution.
pros: It's a large, stable institution, meaning that wondering if the company was going to be around in a year wasn't really on my mind while I was there.
cons: It's a large, stable institution, meaning there was little room for creativity or very quick advancement.  I wanted to be working somewhere where I had a chance to advance quickly if I overperformed.  This was not the case at BofA.

pros: One of the best reasons to work at Bank of America is because it is a globally recognized financial institution offering its associates a vast array of opportunities to excel in.
cons: Presently, some of the downsides of working at Bank of America have to do with its newly acquired entities during the last several years. The politics of the acquired company are still in existence within some of the divisions such as Home Loans and Insurance.

review_title: worth it in the long run, not for the weak
job_title: Home Loan Specialist II in North Plainfield, NJ
pros: Money is good, people are nice and promotions will come. Just do what your boss says and do not tell tales.
cons: B of A speaks of respecting work-life balance but does not practice it. This company has absolutely no respect for the humans in it's workforce - we are called "associates" and are really just numbers on spreadsheets. 80 hour workweeks are very common at this horrible institution.

pros: Benefits are excellent, great hours. Banking is a great profession if you are a sales & service motivated person. Bank of America offers the opportunity to stay on the cutting edge in the banking industry.  The technology and systems they use are unsurpassed in the banking world.  Online and classroom trainings are available and allow you to learn at your own pace.
cons: Work/life balance is difficult.  AM's are non-exempt associates expected to work as exempts. Hours are long and can be uncompensated. Constant change in Regional management makes it difficult for banking center associates to develop a working relationship.

pros:
-great manager, really fair
-flexibility with the schedule
-great benefits, tuition reimbursement, medical insurance, car reimbursement
-branch closed on sundays
cons:
- many decisions were not competent when it came from the headquarters
- lack of communication amongst all the coworkers
- unhappy atmosphere to work in
-no promotion within, would hire an outsider before their own

review_title: Bank of America tries hard to strive for Work/Life Balance and provide growth opportunities but has fallen short.
pros: Coworkers.  Fast Paced.  No 2 days are alike.
cons: Lack of training, work/life balance issue, poor upper management, too much red tape and hurdles to jump over for approvals and funding.  Not on the cutting edge of technology.

pros:
The new incentive plan is really 
good for top performers who have fair and honest managers.
cons: Tellers do not have incentive opportunity, nepotism and senior leaders placing their friends and associates in branches causes challenges for managers when the job fit is off. Many CMMs are not qualified for their roles so they either are jealous of top performing managers or cannot handle specific situations that only they have access authority to resolve. These are some reasons why top performing managers are moving on to competitors or leaving the industry for more intelligent and sophisticated corporations.

review_title: I was treated very fairly and highly respected by Bank of America,but due to company downsizing, Iwas released.
job_title: Senior Foreclosure Specialist Lead in Richardson, TX
pros: Company benefits were outstanding, their indepth training of  associates  for various line of business needes and pay was wonderful.
cons: advancement opporunities became a little difficult but our pay increases  due to performance never ceased.

pros: The company believes in broadly training their associates and inclusive meritocracy, at least that is what they say and promote inside the company.
cons: When the company I worked for was purchased in 2007, the old company's retirement plan took precedence.  Bank of America has a better retirement program than Countrywide Home Loans did so in effect, Bank of America wouldn't allow previous Countrywide employees the same retirement as their legacy Bank of America employees.  I have known previous Countrywide employees who gained employment after the purchase at Bank of America.  They said they were disappointed because the bank reinstated their old Countrywide retirement instead of the Bank of America plan.

job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: A lot of benefits to take advantage, most people like the health insurance. Very big company, they allow remote work for some positions but some departments are not open to it.
cons: No bonuses for "individual contributors" that are at a certain level. Its a 'pay for performance' company and raises per year are very low even though the highest ratings are achieved. Development and promotions are hard to get depending on where you are and whether the money is there. Some departments give out promotions like candy.

review_title: Overall great company  to work for!
pros: Great Benefits...many departments to work and opportunity to move or relocate to another area is available.
cons: Everyday is different and you always have to expect change in priorities from one day to the next. Putting out fires seems to be a daily routine, no one ever seems to figure out how the fires get started to avoid the panic each day. Departments overlap quite often and the left hand never seems to be talking to the right hand to get everyone working together and on the same timelines. Communication between departments could be much better!

pros: If you are amazing at sales they will promote you fast. training was really good, they do not allow you to do certain things until they fell comfortable with you doing them. They will help you understand the nuts and bolts of the business.
cons: demanding sales, constant miscommunication. a lot of "do this" and when you get in trouble "why did you do this." another bank that says they care about the customer but in reality they care about how many sales figures you got that day. Very numbers based culture.

pros:
Good benefits
Tuition Reimbursement
3 week vacation per year
cons:
If you work at a busy branch you will never get to interact with co workers
You have to meet your revenue goals every month and every quarter. 
Incentive plan is IMPOSSIBLE to track or understand. 
Incentive plan always CHANGES! Every quarter it gets harder and harder! 
You will hate your job if you don't meet your goals! 
if you dont meet your sales goals of the day you have to write a paragraph explaining what you could have done better (yes, like in elementary school)

review_title: Don't do it unless you want to get licensed and leave
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative/Investment Specialist I in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great benefits with HSA Plan to cover out of pocket expenses for co pays and prescriptions
cons: Poor training on the systems. Horrible license training..managers come in all excited in thrthe beginning, but shame people on test scores of practice exams. Pull regular reps off the floor to attempt to train on Series 7 licensing, most of whom felt uncomfortable and couldn't help. Need to have an actual proctor to teach to exams required.

pros: Great Benefits, great technology, great products. Opportunity to grow with company, but mainly if you want to relocate. For the most part, good people.
cons: Unrealistic goals, shifting priorities.  All about the process, not the people. Everyone is replaceable. Hard to climb the ladder unless you are blowing it out of the water, did i mention unrealistic goals?

review_title: Ok but lots of room for improvement
pros: decent company, benefits, and pay.
cons: Complete lack of job security, constant reminders how the business "strategy" is changing which essential means they are trimming overhead and most of their employees in the banking centers.  Training was horrendous and almost non existent.  Considering how many regulations are in effect you would expect it to be much more thorough instead of the sink or swim mentality.   Promotions are strictly based on brown nosing and politics.

review_title: Good place to get vast experience
pros: Bank of America is virtually everywhere and 1 of every 2 households in the US as some sort of client . You can easily make 6 figures and it all depends on your partnerships , being self motivated and your ability to present yourself as a, leader in your Financial Center . If you see other reviews as being "a glorified banker" That's probably the reason why some FSA didn't last, didn't do well. You are not a glorified banker and you don't fight over business with bankers . There is Plenty of business to go around , coming from other firms where you need to make cold calls or canvassing , this is a piece of cake
cons: Systems do suck, change happens all the time, sometimes you don't know who your manager is. You must be comfortable working with "what you have " and make a lot of friends to ask questions because this job isn't "explained" in training.  There is so much you will need to learn that I even feel bad for the new guys . The turnover is high.  You need to be used to working in retail banking.  If you came from a firm with an assistant or with fancy elevators and you are used to that ... run , this job is a retail banking job , you will encounter children crying in the lobby. Homeless people pooping on banker chairs, and some sort of things that not even in your wildest dreams you've imaged

job_title: Product Sales Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: The bank supports employees who wish to explore new opportunities and define their own career path.  I was supported by senior management to interview for and eventually be hired as a sales specialist after spending several years in a product management role.
cons: Internal bureaucratic processes can be very slow - it took 8 months to be hired into the bank and another 5 months to finalize an internal transfer.  Employee benefit choices for higher compensated employees are costly and offer limited options.

pros:
Best training by far!!
Best career growth path and opportunities!
Did I say best training!! Before you ever touch a customer, you are ready to help customers reach any financial goals. Every customer who walks in, has access to a team of experts. Been in financial services industry for years and this is the first place where they apply financial planning holistic approach down to every servicing need!!
cons: If you are not committed to be the best for you clients, not the place for you... Got to chase or wells!!!

pros: Training was very in depth. I had no prior banking experience and after 3 weeks of training I felt very prepared to succeed at my job. Management was very supportive.
cons: Very high turnover at both the personal banking side and the teller positions. This can be very difficult because you are then understaffed or working alongside someone with little experience. It  always seemed like we were understaffed while I worked there which causes clients to have to wait in longer lines, which then sours their mood by the time they get to the teller window.

pros: A lot of policies are up to manager's discretion, so a good manager can be very accommodating to the needs of individuals on a team. Great benefits in a family friendly company. Child care reimbursement, 16 weeks paid maternity/paternity leave (adoption eligible). Reimbursement programs for college course work, hybrid/electric car purchase. Discount programs for electronics, cell phone providers, museum attendance. The company actively encourages participation in the community through volunteer programs and donation drives. LGBT friendly policies.
cons: The default side has been shrinking for years. Lots of lay offs and the dreaded "Walk Out Wednesday." It understandable that they have to let people go as the work need has gotten lighter, but it's still a hit to morale.

pros: Diverse work environment; excellent benefits, but NO true opportunity for advancement, the bar is always being raised (like a carrot to a horse). Unrealistic goals that changes once you feel you have mastered a task.
cons: Somewhat hectic environment at times; no choice in any deployment or changes to your position; transfer from one department to another with maybe a week's notice.

review_title: Big org with a lot of risk management
job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: It stated out awesome and became less so once the company became so completely focused on risk management after the financial crisis.  Pretty obvious that it was being lead by a lawyer at the time and still is.  Just like all businesses, the people you work with determine how enjoyable it is.  You get a bit of everything but in general, the environment was incredibly professional.
cons: Size, bureaucracy.  Difficult to move the needle.  Not to different than working for the government.  ten people standing around a hole while one person has a shovel and actually does the work.  Pretty standard for a company of this size.

review_title: Great opportunity if you can relocate
job_title: Financial Solutions Consultant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Fast paced environment, with a training staff that is willing to take from a complete novice in investments to a beginning professional. If you are a great salesperson, and are willing to relocate to one of the new facilities that they are opening across the country there is a great opportunity to advance into a comfy lower management spot.
cons: Once you hit the phones you really are on your own to fill in the gaps in your knowledge during the limited time that you are given in-between calls. You are also trying to do this with an out of date software system that has been patched work to handle an online platform.

review_title: Excellent experience.  High expectations but great rewards
job_title: Small Business Banker in Austin, TX
pros: Great benefits, good work environment, chance for advancement based on performance.  Good paid time off.  Performance reviews are done in a timely manner.
cons: High pressure to meet goals.  Micromanagement through daily reporting requirements.  Lots of email messaging regarding daily performance. Very distracting and not motivating.

pros: Decent benefits, not great, but decent. The past days with Merrill Lynch of extra perks are gone.
cons: Have really streamlined the training to the point a new rep is completely lost. Understandably, there are a myriad of scenarios that cannot be covered in training, but strong basics should be covered. An eight week class pared down to 2 weeks is too severe a cut.  There are no annual bonuses anymore or commissions for traders. The reworked pay did not nearly compensate.

review_title: Good company, good benefits but lacking career opportunities
pros: Good benefits, Stable company. Depends on which group or manager you have, but work schedule can be flexible
cons:
-Difficult to find opportunities for advancement despite the size and breath of products/services provided by BofA
-Management not vested in employee development and growth
-Frequent lay-offs (always in fear that you will be next even if you are a top performer)
-Unrealistic expectations for Technology Teams to deliver which is causing burn out

pros: The opportunity to get licensed
cons: Merrill Edge is a young organization.  Training is severely lacking, which is one of the consequences of it being so young.  New employees are unapologetically thrown out to sink or swim.  Without adequately teaching employees the systems, policies or procedures you're expected to service clients who have incredibly varied questions that you don't really know the answers to.  Getting the answer can be difficult too, especially when you're co-workers are often new like you and learning how to research internal systems takes a lot of time that you're not afforded.  An alternative to asking coworkers and trying to find the answer in the systems is asking a Team Lead for help.  However, the Team Leads can be inundated and sometimes frustrated by answering a lot of questions by the new hires, which can cause them to be short, which contributes to the poor culture and unwelcoming atmosphere.  You're also going to be pushed to "deepen," which means gaining more wallet share of the clients.  A core responsibility of the Investment Specialist role is sales, not service.  Be prepared and be comfortable with asking clients for more of their wallet share everyday, multiple times and potentially with most calls.  I'm grateful that I worked here because this was such a bad place to work that I have greater appreciation for my current employer.  Several Merrill Edge coworkers quit because it really is a bad place to work. Get licensed somewhere else, make a career somewhere else.  Merrill Edge gave me a bad job, not a career, but did launch a financial services career somewhere else..

pros:
1) Incredible management at the market and regional levels.  Manager understands the sales cycle and knows what it takes to be on the 'frontline' - leads by example.  Support is always there.  

2) BofA has a sales tool for everything the company has to offer clients.  Has made me a better and more well rounded salesman overall.  Company listens to end of year employee satisfaction surveys.
cons: Micro-management.  A lot of small, tedious, day-to-day 'must-do's' from an operations standpoint.  Takes away from client facing time and opportunities.

review_title: A lot of political games. Fake it, and you might make it. Also, pretend you don't see the unfair practices.
pros: Good benefit package, 401k company match 100% up to 5% of pay. Paid tuition, company contributes toward HSA account. Short and Long term disability.
cons: Executives are saying they are all about 360' coaching, dont even think about providing honest- constructive feedback .. you will regret it and your carrier wIll stall.

pros: The benefits and pay are pretty awesome
cons: Management is cliquey and asks like they are back in high school.  My manager was with me for my first three months and then left to take on another team while their existing team was left with no management.  When they came back to manage both teams, we were put down for performing awfully and were treated like we were idiots.  The company found many ways not to pay out on bonuses when their systems went down for a month and prevented us from being able to sell.  We were told many things in training that turned out to be completely false.

review_title: Great company to work for but FCLO position is not great
job_title: Financial Center Lending Officer in Columbia, SC
pros:
Great benefits
Team environment
Volunteer Events to promote team building
Bonus for good performance of company
CEO communicates with every employee
cons:
Poor communication in regards to compensation (commission based structures)
No HR rep to speak to about concerns
Multiple conference calls per day that keep you from keeping appointments with clients
Cold Calling clients that are not interested in mortgages and just have a banking relationship (this was not advertised to me and added 6 months in with punishments for not doing it)
No reimbursement for job expenses

review_title: Bank of America - Great place to work!!
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Security, they are one of the best financially positioned US banks in the country!!!  The compensation plan, with respect to our commission bonuses is really fair and thought through.  In addition to that, the company does a great job of listening to the associates of the company and being flexible enough to make changes when needed.  They also encourage switching from one line of business to another in order to be more well rounded.
cons: Sometimes the industry itself can be boring and routine.  However, the financial sector is the best to be in!!

review_title: Many options under one roof, but not fit for the career minded individual.
job_title: Premier Client Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: MAny options in different lines of business. When you feel you need a change, you can change and still stay with the same company.
cons: The bank is too big. It's very easy to become the one cog in the very big wheel. The impact you attempt to make is miniscule in the big picture.

pros: I hope that it will be a great place to work.  I will begin as a summer analyst in the summer of 2009.  My interviewers seemed very friendly and gave me the impression that it is a great place to work.  My compensation is very generous and is considered "street." Their new office at bryant park is great and is also very green.  I think that with the merger of merrill lynch, bank of america will emerge from the financial crisis as a leader in the financial services industry.  Going forward, bank of america will be a great place to work.
cons: The bank is not as prestigious as other banks.

job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros: If you are the type of person that wants to "blend in", it is easy to do.  The company is HUGE, no one will notice you.  Due to number of acquisitions, you can make a living doing transition if that is what you are interested in.  Free access to museums.
cons: Too large, no career or compensation growth, you can do the same job for the next 30 years if you wanted to.  Impossible to get promoted.  No respect for work life balance.  Good ole boy Southern network at the top.  No global focus until Merrill Lynch.

review_title: Its what you make of it
pros: They pretty much described in detail the background of whatever they had me doing ( mutual fund analysis, creating client presentations, etc). They are usually busy so you have to pick their brain, but if you do they gladly educate you on any questions you have regarding the financial and wealth management world.
cons: Majority of work was basic office duties, but nothing unexpected as an intern. They didn't have me grabbing coffee or anything

pros: I loved working at BofA because you get the opportunity to build great relationships with the customers and the rest of your team. I love giving people money, although I wish it was mine.
cons: Sometimes referring to the personal bankers can get annoying when you see the same customers week after week. I actually had an excellent referral rate, but I just hated offering people products they had no need for.

review_title: Unrealistic goals set by top management
pros:
-Some of the people are really nice.
-Lots of paid holidays.
-Free checking account.
-Out of all of the banks, I still believe BoA is the best one even though I no longer work there.
cons:
-Upper management sets unrealistic goals.
-Some of the products they try to force you to sell don't apply to the ethnic makeup of the city your branch is located. For example, a product for safely sending money to people in Mexico will not sell in a city that is mainly Asian.
-Low wages.

review_title: Everytime I think working for Bank of America could not get any worse, it does.
pros: The pay is ok and I like my co-workers.
cons: The management is the worst.  They treat their employees as slave labor.  Bank of America is turning into Countrywide fast.  That tells you how competent their management is.  They buy a bank that was dishonest and failing and then proceed to adopt their broken computer systems, management styles and processes.  Real genius.  They will soon fall like Countrywide did.

review_title: If you really need the money or a job, than I guess its worth it.
pros: Two weeks paid vacation, Banker Holidays, Benefits for part time, Flexible with school schedule.
cons: Standing up all day... even when we have chairs that we aren't "allowed" to use. Lack of professionalism between management, Constant pushing to sell products that most customers aren't interested in, lazy and unprofessional banking center managers that are barely there and are extremely incompetent, false promises on promotions and transfers, and most importantly TOO much work for TOO little pay.

review_title: Nice people but am underwhelmed by experience or thought process
job_title: Senior Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: loads of potential to be a real mover in the market.
cons: relies too heavliy on it's name and doesn't try to push the envelop on it's innovation.  the financially viable divisions often get mired down by the bank's rigid and often times illogical mandates.  results seems really sloppy and accidental.

review_title: Great as a bank, not as much for an employer.
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits, including tuition reimbursement; Vacation time increases with job level or years of continuous service. Most in my current position would only get 2 weeks paid vacation, but I get 3 weeks. When you exceed your goals you receive rewards in the form of points that can ve redeemed for gift cards, home supplies, jewlery, and other merchandise. There is also a company discount website for employees that provides discounted deals on apparel, electronics, travel, food, etc.
cons: Micromanagement; There is no consistency across different branches. Each banking center has managers that have a different vision; Employment opportunities are scarce and most center managers opt for favortism when promotion opportunities arise.

review_title: Had a lot of fun working here, but strict new rules eliminated many...
pros: Pay was decent, lot of fun coworkers, ok benefits, and can move up if management likes you. They do seem like they care about you and are very involved in the community.
cons: CRAZY strict rules!!! New zero tolerance policy that made so many GOOD employees lose careers. This all started in 2013. I'm not sure if its just our market or all of BofA. I was fired over a customers mistake, but customer blamed me so it was her word over mine.

review_title: Not for the Faint of Heart
job_title: Customer Relationship Manager in Simi Valley, CA
pros: salary, benefits, short commute, nice people to work with.
cons: Can't tell you in 20 words. Please see comment below.

review_title: Ended mortgage operations at this locations and turned us into a call center for the deposit and credit card products.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: We still have a job, salary was kept the same, vacation was kept the same although it's much more difficult to use.
cons:
Call center environment.
No upward mobility.
Management is never available, always in "meetings" leaving no floor support.
Feels like they are pushing out tenured/higher paid associates from mortgage to make room for lower paid new associates making appropriate call center wages with the constant rule changes and new procedures that seem to be added weekly.

pros:
Awesome coworkers/teams below the executive level
Diverse work environment
Tuition Reimbursement
401k with match
cons:
Constant layoffs
Poor compensation/bonus structure
Subjective performance ratings
Constant groupthink
Moving up within the organization gives you a minor % pay increase rather than market value for the position.  Not a good organization to start at entry level and work your way up.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Brea, CA
pros: Great benefits and mostly good salary.  Advancement is pretty good if you can stand the politics.  There are many departments to transfer to for expanded knowledge and experience.
cons: High stress in most departments due to the need for high productivity goals.  Some departments required to work extended hours without compensation,  High level of repetitive stress injury from long hours on the computer in high production units.  When there are job postings, the most qualified person is seldom selected.  Lots of politics and favoritism.

pros:
Always busy with work. Worked with you on shift times and having
To leave for appts etc.
cons: Would constantly give more work and still have high expectations. Never gave any help for anything but would like more work on you and expect same results with someone with half the work. Nothing was the same across the sites, one site could get away with something that another site couldn't.

pros: Loved a few of my the co workers and the benifits were wonderful I enjoyed the hours with this company but was tough to manage work and life with the hrs
cons: Where do I start managers are horrible they would write you up for every and any little thing they are extremely sales driven and that's all they want and care about they are extremely selfish company and I hate how they treat employees and other customers I will never got back and I'm glad I have left since worst company morals and your just another notch on their belt DISCUSTING and better yet of you don't make them happy they are out to get rid of you since day 1 I'm a teller not a used car sales person so I prefer to not badder and bargin and harass customers and they do as well

review_title: Underwriting challenges, very restricted product portfolio
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Flexibility
Autonomy
Competitive commission payout for a large national bank
Very high volume of leads and referrals
Almost no time for proactive prospecting because of lead volume
cons:
Guidelines more stringent in most cases than investor guidelines
Underwriters decision loans more conservatively than they should
No FHA refis unless currently serviced by BAC (30 bps)
No VA refis unless currently services by BAC (30 bps)
No USDA
No HARP refis unless currently serviced by BAC (30 bps)
Appraisal is always completed before initial approval - pusses customers off because they lose their appraisal money if their loan is declined and will be for any minute reason the underwriter can find.

pros: Great hours for a college student, great pay while getting my degree. They company really works with me so I can do well in school though, as they can schedule me different hours when I have a big test.
cons: Standing on feet all day is tough, and having to work opening early in the morning is sometimes a bother. Also, hard to balance a job and full time college

pros: The company is very flexible in terms of location for roles that don't heavily depend on the financial centers. Most associates are spread out across the US with management in other cities/states.
cons: The "feel" of being around other coworkers is off when you don't work in the same city/state as your leader/coworkers. When changes occur with staffing other business news the information is not cascaded to associates. You could probably learn more from the world news about what is happening vs. working there.

review_title: Good for Freshers & Leadership position but not for Tenured people
pros: This company provides a good platform,a good brand name for freshers. This company is also very good for those who come from different companies at a higher level.
cons: For those guys who stick around for a long time, it's not at all good for them. Salary hike is average but the promotion cycle is huge. There are too many designations which slows down the growth path. A guy who comes from another company will be earning more than you even if you have more experience & at a higher level.

review_title: Surprisingly ineffective, unstructured and lacks direction
pros: Reasonable base salary and perks.
cons:
I worked under a new team called Global Loan Products, and it was the worst experience I have ever had in my life. Both MD's who I reported into had no commercial knowledge and had very little direction. Throughout my 3 years there, they could not provide an answer to all the questions I had.

I was also mis-sold the job and the educational support they will provide.

job_title: Client Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Benefits are pretty good. Offers family/ parental leave for up to 4 months. Offers a match to your 401(k) contributions. Also offers tuition reimbursement for certain classes and some adoption fee reimbursement.
cons: You work almost everyday of the week. They want you to do more with less help sometimes. Company doesn't allow for more help towards affording adoption.

review_title: Taking online classes for medical assistant
job_title: Investment Banking Associate and Medical Billing and Coding in Newark, DE
pros: Christiana Care I love the feeling of warmth and comfort when I was in there care. I've always wanted to work at a hospital so I can give back to the staff that took care of me there in my hours of need. I love helping and caring for people and my co-workers.
cons: It does become over whelming at times but I couldn't think of anything any rewarding then to help others

pros: Many good and capable people to work with
cons: No clear business unit management (can receive 'orders' from anywhere and are expected to fulfill them), no real management support (management only cares about themselves - not about any employee), documented processes & procedures are hard to come by making it nearly impossible to get anything done in an expeditious manner, benefit offerings are the same year over year (but with the added bonus of price increases), no training offered, incentive & base pay freezes even though the corporation is making money hand over fist, pay discrepancies for same role, telecommuting is now frowned upon when just a short while back telecommuting was encouraged, career opportunities are non-existent for long time telecommuters and people in non-hub locations, lots of management talk but very little management action, and on and on...

job_title: Team Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great employee friendly place with lots of information to assist employees with career and personal development. Flexible fun atmosphere with lots of benefits (Insurance, bereavement, maternity leave 4mo, paternity leave, 401K, Toastmasters, diversity.
cons: If you come up within the company, depending on the position, the pay is not as competitive as someone on the outside coming in. Advancement is possible but limited, layoffs.

job_title: Licensed Lending Officer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Health insurance is cheap, other than that nothing is really remarkable. The sales assistants don't do much, they could care less about loans closing and the amount of your own processing you are forced to do means that they aren't really doing their job.
cons: Most of your loans go straight in to the trash. Closing 15 loans barely gets you paid. The stress to close that many is unreal. The underwriters work against you and your client in an unimaginable way. Its unreal their business has sustained this long with such utter waste in resources to cancel good loans.

pros: Great company, customer focused, innovative, technically driven.
cons: Sometimes politics and protocols for appropriate layered communication  got in the way of work.

pros: In 2 years I went from making $12.50 an hour to $16.60. There's a lot of room for growth. Management wants to see you succeed. Benefits are good. No occurrences while you still have sick time.
cons: I've been in 2 departments so far both seem a little unorganized. People do multiple roles and the requirement to get the extra compensation is almost impossible.  I know someone trying to join the team and he can't get an email back. No matter if you are looking for a job internal or external the recruiters are HORRIBLE

pros: Benefits and Wages are good. If you enjoy working for a large company BAC is a decent one to work for. Unfortunately I worked for the bank at a time of down sizing and intense oversight, regulation and policy/procedure changes.
cons: BAC Leadership heavily relies on reporting. In the mortgage industry reports can be very misleading as processes are heavily laden with systems related stops and metrics measures. There were many leaders who had no real understanding or knowledge of the processes and didn't care to know.  Expectations often were unrealistic due to this.

pros:
- pay is generally around average for positions
- a good brand to have on a resume
- good maternity leave
cons:
- horrible employee satisfaction scores are normal in my group
- horrible corporate culture
- minimal perks
- leadership brags about “flat to down” monetary incentives while executives seem to be getting their payments and bonus increases
- your overall career path is DIRECTLY CORRELATED to who you know and very little on merit
- leadership shows favoritism
- don’t expect any increase in your base pay and don’t count on annual bonus

review_title: Bank of America has its advantages and drawbacks.
pros: The best part of BOA is the benefits and the pay. The company is so big that you have the potential to move up, especially if you don't mind relocating. The benefits include your health, dental, vision, 401K, childcare reimbursement and tuition reimbursement. The cost of everything has gone up, but the beneftts are still some of the best.
cons: Management is unprofessional and sales is the focus of everything. It is so big, and sometimes you feel like just a number. They don't give adequate time for training to be completed, but yet still expect you to perform without complete knowlege of the job.

review_title: Card Services CA to Consumer Banking
pros: The benefits offered by the company in the way of Health insurance, vacation, community involvement, EAP, and the child care reimbursement are the reasons i stay.  If the economy weren't in the shape it was, I would definitely be sending my resume elsewhere.
cons: The company has definitely changed over the last 36 months and it isn't a "great place to work" like it use to be.  :(.   It seems now, Sr. management feels that incentive is something they have an obligation to save the bank, instead of something given to the associates to make them feel rewarded for a job well done.

pros: Senior managers demonstrate a strong interest in guiding incoming professionals toward professional success, both within BAC and your own career development.  The MBA LDP gives interns the opportunity to move on to a full-time rotational program where you can "try on" different roles and find the right group for you.  I made several invaluable friendships and professional connections during my three month internship alone.
cons: My direct manager didn't seem comfortable working with MBAs - which made me wonder why he wanted to be assigned one in the first place.

pros: I would have to say, it is a secure reputable company to work for. And you could transfer and relocate just about any area, because we are all over.
