cons: For me personally...their isnt any room or opportunites to move up to next level or in management in my dept. so i would have to look to other depts or outside of the bank for growth opportunites.

review_title: Don't expect to make a lot of money for putting in a lot of work
pros: Training given is amazing. They give every kind of scenario that could happen and show you how to handle it.
cons: Pay is horrible for the amount of stress you go through. It's ALL about sales, sales, sales. If you don't get the set number of "referrals" for the week you get "talked to". There is no way around it therefor don't expect to get a raise or promotion unless you are a good salesman

review_title: No management support for wholesale is why bofa exited wholesale -twice!
job_title: Account Executive in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Brand awareness 
Broker loyalty
Great associate programs available
cons:
Very corporate culture - office politics are very present
The acquisition of countrywide created many problems in service and IT which resulted in 6 months of awful turn times and low pay for the 100% commissioned ae's.  It was clear that the former bofa management style and customer service went to crap once cw was acquired.

review_title: It was very rewarding and I looked forward to the challenges of each day.
pros: Great atmosphere.  Benefits were awesome.  Plenty of opportunity to make overtime money.  Management made it a upbeat place to work.
cons: Dress code we did not ever see the public so I did not understand the strict dress guidelines.  Expected to work holidays it was unspoken but you knew that you had better come in at least half a day on major holiday's.

pros: Some of the smartest and most effective people I have ever worked with, and some of the most supportive, honest, straightforward, focused and skilled executives I've ever worked for/with.  If you can get into the right group, the work can be enjoying and rewarding.
cons:
Avoid mortgage servicing - currently re-org about every 3 months.  New management will populate their with prior co-workers from past orgs and ditch or demote current team.  
Otherwise, lots of bureaucracy for overly matrixed and siloed organisation. Sometimes it takes a lot of extra effort just to get the right result.  Also some of the worst executives I have ever worked with.

review_title: Great place to learn and make contacts
pros: I was able to learn the financial system and how it applies to small businesses.  I was also able to interact with clients, and since most business owners come on a routine basis, it is very easy to start developing relationships with them.  From my interactions with the customers, I landed my first internship and built my career from there.
cons: When I was there, the bank focused a lot on meeting sales goals.  From what I hear now, this may no longer be the case.

review_title: I have leaned a lot through out the years.
pros: Believes in promoting and helping you advance in your career. Excellent coworkers and very diverse. Salary is good
cons: Really horrible turn-over. Becomes short staff almost every month or so. Sometimes you are forced to work more hours then expected at the last minute.

review_title: Belt tightening and often short sighted decisions, but solid benefits and work life balance overall
pros: Solid benefits package (though less so than 10 years ago).  Diverse opportunities within the company.  Acknowledgement of need for work life balance and typically strive to make that possible.
cons: New management pushes once a year it seems, based on current popular management trends.  Levels of bureaucracy involved in all aspects of work (in Technology, at least).

job_title: Senior Collector I in Westlake Village, CA
pros: Helping those who are truthfully in need stay in their homes.  It's nice to be able to have saved a number of people from losing their homes in the time I was there.  It was a nice understanding of the mortgage market and is very educational.  I now have a very firm understanding of the servicing process, now that I have been in this position.
cons: Collections isn't a pretty job.  If you can't handle a volley of insults, if you can't tell people the honest truth that they're going to lose their house because they overspend and don't take in enough income...then this isn't the position for you.

review_title: Old dog with few new tricks
pros: ability to work from home in some positions.  If you don't like your manager, just wait a few months and you'll have a new one.
cons: continues to play the "efficiency" card  and continues to cut FTE to reduce expense when the well is already dry.  Over dependance on vendors and outsourcing.  Constant change leads to inefficiency and confusion.  too many "watchdog" teams, to few "producers"

pros: Benefits, availability to advance, salaries,  and lots of great programs to help you be successful in making a career for yourself.
cons: Vacation and schedule.  Schedule can change pretty much day to day, and hard to plan any type of appointments for yourself and family.  Would be better if you could have a consistent schedule.  Seniority comes before the time you request.  If you got a day off already approved, someone with more seniority can come later and they will change it for them.  Regardless

review_title: Overall a good place to work with a lot of benefits, but it is so large things don't always make logical sense.
pros: Good people, good pay, well known brand, many different opportunities to grow, good culture and teamwork
cons: So large it is doesn't allow for the common person to be heard or logical sense. Decisions are made from the top down with little understand of how the implementation affects the end user. Due to its size, it is very difficult to make a difference or affect change.

pros: Work force is diverse and it give the employees an opportunity to see things (and learn from) different perspectives. There is no one set way to accomplish your goals - you are given autonomy in your approach to solving the business objectives and goals.  Also, there were some opportunities to work from home.  BofA treats its employees well and the team concept is highly valued.
cons:
There are layoffs, at least once a year.  If you are not an individual who embraces change, then this is not the place for you.
There are numerous opportunities for career growth; however, you may need to be willing to move to another department or location.

pros: I gained a lot of knowledge and new skills.  There is a lot of room for opportunity; however, you are so busy there is no time to take advantage of it.
cons: I worked hard and was seldom absent; however, a co-worker never came in the same time everyday, was out a lot, took care of personal business more than work and was always behind.  I was caught up and did my job; however, I was laid off and she got to keep her job because she rubbed elbows with the right people.

pros: The micromanagement culture of the office environment can be over bearing and create a rift of competency vacuums in overall productivity and performance due to the group thinking and resultant conspiratorial behavior spill effects.
cons: Company values are secondary to these brain and skill drains with staggering markets and organizational consequences. The tendencies for lackadaisical, compromised and complacent manager and supervisor attitudes and behaviors persisted.

pros: great benefits!!! You somewhat have options of schedules you can choose from.
cons: Its a call center, enough said right? You said at a desk all day taking call after call. You have to watch the number of calls you take, sale on every call you take, make sure your doing everything right because compliance is listening to your phone calls, your rated from customers who will pick 1-5 if you are not given a 5 its pretty much a fail for you which is VERY BAD! This is every month. So you dont meet the requirements 3 months in a row your out. No joke Your fired.

review_title: IT Operations Is a Great Place to Work
pros: Middle and upper management is fair and supportive.  The Bank is dedicated to creating Best In Class production operations and has made great strides since 2012.   The culture is focused on resolving issues and not on placing blame, very refreshing.
cons:
Direction to outsource to or source talent from India and Pakistan is creating communication issues which can get very frustrating at times especially during outages.
OpEx goals/challenges impact perception of job security

review_title: constantly changing, so if like change, this is the place to work.
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: Easy to move up, do your job, and consistently talk to your manager about your goals, and they will help you. We also have 360 degree coaching, meaning that if you see someone, including your manager doing something incorrectly, you can coach them with no consequences.
cons: Seniority rules. The people that worked longer with the bank get first dibs on the vacation schedule, meaning that the time you get your chance to pick, all the holidays are taken. There used to be some great bonuses, but they got rid of them.

pros: The company offer great benefits.
cons: They pay very little and as you move up the pay increase is absolutely ridiculous. The next step up from a teller would be to become an SSS which stands for Sales and Service Specialist and after that to be a banker. They have eliminated the Teller Supervisor position accross the US. After 6 years with bank of america I started at 10/hr and I am still making below 13/hr. Management changes a lot and if sales arent great there is a lot of SALES PRESSURE on the tellers. They want you to SELL SELL and SELL with every customer interection. I can not wait to leave this company!

review_title: objective of collaborating in a working environment where I can put into practice my knowledge in favor

Bring solutions to the problems of day-to- day. Seek solutions for a project or alternatives to problems.

job_title: Client Services Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: This is generally a good place to work if you like complacency. It provides a comfortable, secure, safe, work environment with a moderately competitive compensation package and lots and lots of work. Great place for upwardly mobile sheep, looking to climb a corporate latter.
cons: As a legacy Merrill Lynch employee I stayed on with Bofa after the 2009 recession and their corporate take-over. The changes were stark, but they came slowly over several years. In that time the general atmosphere, culture, and overall compensation package changed dramatically from great to worse, providing less of everything, while squeezing out more and more, and as much as possible, from everyone. Same old corporate grind.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great culture and work life balance. Smart people who are not "working to work". The maternity/paternity benefits are great. As a father I took 6 weeks to
cons: Salaries are lagging behind the industry. There are a number of benefits that the bank has removed over the years in effort to cut costs. These costs are dwarfed though by huge legal and regulatory settlements we make each quarter.

pros: benefits are good. Nice people to work with.
cons: terriible work - life balance. The organization expect more and more daily from every employee,expecially in the retail centers.  With no additinal pay, just told to wrok harder.  Most folks are not happy and seekign employment elsewhere because they are not paid, not happy and not appreciated.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Buffalo, NY
pros: Good Benefits Package Overall. Hours are conducive to work/family life.
cons: Micro Management from executives that have not worked in a Branch for YEARS. Market Management seems to be out of touch with the stress levels they are giving EVERYONE. Sales goals are, for the most part, very high. Almost unattainable unless in a large Branch. Sr. Leadership changes almost quarterly. Slowly reducing footprint in this area in order to avoid news seeing it.

review_title: Comfortable but frustrating for those wanting to advance
pros: Good work/life balance here. 4 weeks of vacation and 2 weeks of sick time, 4 months of parental leave (maternity AND paternity), health insurance is a bit high per pay period, but accepted almost anywhere it seems.
cons:
Hard to get promoted from VP to Sr. VP.
Difficult to attend conferences or trainings.
If you're good at what you do and an asset to management, they're reluctant to allow you to move because you're a key part to THEIR success, doesn't matter about your career. Management told me that when they get promoted, then I will too because they will bring me up with them. What?!? 
Bonus amounts are at the discretion of management.

pros: The leaders are great for the most part.  Most truly care about their employees.  Its definitely a work-hard environment but if you don't mind the work, the team work is great.
cons: A few managers step over work/life boundaries. If you call an employee at home right in the middle of them cooking dinner for their family just to review a document that is not even due for 2 more days and you get upset, then the issue is the manager and they need to respect that boundary.

pros: Extremely competitive commissions and benefits.  Unusually flexible scheduling.  Generous time off policies with forgiving sick leave options.  Incredible location.  Customers could be very interesting.  Some supervisory-level management were vibrant, inspirational leaders.  Awesome coworkers.  Also, the parking situation was pretty darn good (which is a much bigger perk than most people realize).
cons: "It's not what you know, it's who you know" culture of advancement held a lot of great people back and promoted some who were questionable.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Some of the smartest teammates I have ever worked with. Team oriented group where everyone pitched in and had a strong  work ethics. Supportive  direct Managers and good Senior Managers in area as well.
cons: Experience will vary depending on area. My last two managers were amazing .Mixed bag of managers in prior areas including a tolerance for unprofessional behavior with no consequences. Being it is a large company this is the only downside, if you find a group that is a good fit for you, the experience is more positive.

review_title: Great Company, Great Benefits, Great People
job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Often fantastic leadership who are eager to help their teams succeed.  Lots of opportunity to advance and branch out into different lines of business.  Great benefits.  Opportunities to gain exposure to senior leadership.  Diverse workforce amd a ton of employee networks catering to all kinds of interests.
cons: Very few cons, really.  Customer service can be difficult when client expectations do not align with our product or service features.  Occasionally you end up working with someone who behabes selfishly or does not seem willing to work for the team's success.  That's not the norm, though.

pros: Good benefits, large company, room for growth. Average pay.  Some very intelligent and dedicated managers.
cons: They Value outside individuals more than promoting within. Very much like a clique when it comes to management if you are in their circle they help you, otherwise your just an extra body to them. Some arrogant pushy hammer style managers.

pros: Friendly and stable, competitive pay that is less volatile than peers. Huge balance sheet with enormous consumer bank is a competitive advantage.
cons: Employees less driven than more agressive shops. Years of underinvestment in technology which evolves at a snails pace and with little consistent direction or vision. There is seldom any progress without months of incessant chasing.

job_title: Private Client Manager in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Treat employees professionally and with respect. They have a fairly responsive culture. The on-boarding process is going well. Everyone seems pretty friendly and genuine. The acquisition of US Trust seems to have boosted morale for those who stayed. They have nicer offices which help as well. Take a lot of pride in empowering employees. Like how there is a focus on career development and how it is not treated as a bad word (like in other organizations).
cons: huge bureaucracy, can streamline some people (like in HR). In frequent meaningful HR communication. Not sure how the hierarchy works and no one can really explain it well.

job_title: Senior Interaction Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work - life balance is excellent. Four weeks paid vacation for the first year, excellent. Add to that the many bank holidays, plus two weeks personal/sick time, and you're pushing eight weeks off per year.
cons: The glacial pace, the annual re-orgs, and level upon level of executive/managerial strata. This is no place for innovation, no place for agile work methods, and it can be hard to be recognized as a top performer.

review_title: So remind me again why i took this job here......
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Croydon, England
pros: Good name on the CV.
cons: Worklife balance...you must be joking, they sprout all this rubbish about promoting worklife balance and then ask you to work late and at weekends! Also the attitudes of associates is bad, noone has time to help anyone else and this cause a 'ME' culture which is not good for business, although this is not completely management's fault, but is their fault for choosing employee who life up there own asses.

pros: It's a fun work environment because you have the opportunity to meet some great people.  It's an easy job to network in if you use that to your advantage. They are understanding and flexible with your work schedule because they understand the importance of your education.
cons: The branch I work in has terrible management skills and some people work harder than others.  I admit some people do not get recognized for their hard work. There are less customers coming in therefore making it harder to work on your sales goals (which is a key drive to your bonus).

review_title: Some pros and cons of working at  Bank of America
pros: What makes Bank of America a great place to work is that management has an open door policy and you can literally walk up to any upper manager and ask a question or simply have a conversation and you're not made to feel as if you are beneath them.  It is also a very diverse company where everyone has an opportunity to grow and excel.
cons: Middle managers could be a bit more forthcoming with information and recognizing genuine performance; not just for those that they "like".

pros:
If you are 4+ experienced candidate you can get good salary.
You can get good front office application to work which will improve your competency level.
Short term onsite opportunity.
Transportation from a pick up location to office.
cons:
Bonus is very less. This has got worse after they have acquired Merrill Lynch.
Very much New York or London driven.
High politics. People at higher management are very incompetent.
Too many AVPs and VPs even at places where they are not required.
Employee at lower level does not get recognisation. Lead try to take recognisation of all your work.
Policies are not very employee friendly. This is getting worse after acquisition of ML.

pros: benefits are great like the paid weeks and sick time but i am sure most companies have that. Envrionment is not bad.
cons: pay is not competetive always asking for sales but you dont get pay what you deserve

pros: Was a solid company to work for.  Huge corporation, so need to know that going into this company.  Try as they may, in the end, you are still a number that will hopefully generate income for the company.
cons: Not so solid anymore.  No idea when they will lay-off people.  Mortgage industry is always going up and down, but in recent years it is worse.  Worst part is, there is no way to know when will get downsized.

review_title: Great people in the Chicago office.
pros: Managers are receptive and realistic. People working there generally enjoyed their work and the people around them. The reputation of the Chicago office is much more relaxed than Charlotte, people could wear jeans, etc.
cons: The only downside is the reputation of the company given the whole Occupy movement. It's a bit unfortunate because there are many people so far removed from the actual problem that get lumped in with it. I'm personally looking outside of finance, I just feel there are more beneficial uses of my time and hard work.

review_title: Gone from 'ready fire aim' to 'ready aim aim....'
pros: There are still some great people working for BoA, and it is a place where things get done. In many areas, things are genuinely improving and sensible risk controls are being put in place.
cons: There has always been a lack of overall vision,  things have not improved since the BoA take over. Even where strategy is clear, execution can be confused by management fifedoms and poor communication. There often appears to be a lack of communication between the management of even closely related areas, and certainly between management and other staff.

review_title: Bank of America taught me how to become an effective leader with a heart that truly cares.
pros: Bank of America offers a wide variety of trainings for development. It has five core values in which associates get its strong foundation to become a better employee performing his tasks and duties.
cons: The bank itself offers a lot of opportunities, though in a non core section of the bank where I am, processes are sunsetting since some of these assets are sold by the bank. That left us with some management challenges.

review_title: Company went downhill after acquiring Merrill Lynch
pros: I worked there for almost a decade. Their culture of hard working people and team environment was great. Good work-life balance. Benefits are better then most companies out there.
cons: Salary increases and bonuses were hard to come by. Work-life balance went out the window. After Merrill Lynch was acquired, the cultured changed dramatically, for the worse. Departments compete with each other instead of working together, you are not provided the resources that you need to deliver and morale is at its worst I've ever seen. Everyone is miserable.

pros: Bank of America provided excellent launch pad for professional work experience and interpersonal skills. It is structured to take potential from the bottom and give them the tools to move to the top.
cons: As the market changed so did the demands of the company. When the bank introduced a  Sometimes the requirements were unrealistic. I wouldn’t encourage anyone to apply unless they have adequate sales experience.

review_title: Great team! Loved being able to work remotely.
pros: Lots of opportunity.  The people are great to work with -- extremely hard working!  Loved being able to work from home.  The bank has very competitive benefits and salary with a very generous time off policy.
cons: In an effort to reduce expenses they are continually laying off employees without any regard to tenure, skill set, or performance.

review_title: Job is pretty good, can't say the same for a lot of the managers though.
job_title: Production Specialist II in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Pay is pretty good with little or no prior experience. Room to improve if you really want it. Paid time off, holidays, vacation and sick time are all definite bonuses. Employee discounts are also a huge help!
cons: All offices are different but it feels like I work in a dungeon. Some departments don't offer bonuses and some do. Managers aren't always the best at managing but that could just be my location.

review_title: Micro Managed constantly and upper management always being rotated
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Good benefits and they did good volunteer work.
cons: Glorified sales position. They preach "work, life, balance" but only care about your sales and constantly are harping on you to "keep your numbers up". I constantly wrote action plans and was on conference calls that were a waste of time and nothing more than "pep rallys".I also worked many Saturdays after being promised that i would only have to do "one or two a month".  Also, I went through 5 managers in the 16 months that I was there. Probably because no one wanted to manage the market I was in since the goals were far too unrealistic.

review_title: Overall, great company to work for.
pros: Great benefits! Most managers are motivated to help you to grow and develop.  Associates are passionate about what they do.  The company has many internal networking groups that they encourage you to be involved in.  If you perform and work hard, the sky is the limit.
cons: Terrible work life balance - lots of talk about it, but little action to see it through. Underpaid for what is expected of associates, even by industry standards.

review_title: Great place to work and learn, with average salary
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Simi Valley, CA
pros: The company is moving toward the right direction which is customer oriented. the leadership is very supportive if there is any interest for further improvement. It provides many resources to learn and excel via learning courses and trainings and constantly is trying to implement process improvement tools in place.
cons: The Salaries could be reviewed to match work loud. The changes in leadership team are constant which it cause different fundamental strategic changes. Movement of physical location is another inconvenience matter.

pros: the health benefits are great. the hours of the banking centers are employee friendly

review_title: It was the worst company I ever worked for!! No onet should have to experience working in n envenvironment like this!

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Merrill Lynch, once known as, "Mother Merrill," cared about their employees...one day again, I sincerely believe that they will..."reversion to the mean"...It can happen, I only hope that there is someone under Brian Moynihan, that will read all, if not most of the remarks made, & decide that it is truly time, "to make a difference" (the former motto of the fallen, "Merrill Lynch" pre-2008)
cons: Sadly, in the past 7 years, everything that you have read from both former & current employees remarks have been for the most part accurate...it is true about the work environment, but you are paid very well, for the work that you are expected to do, however, there is an obvious disparage, that has been mentioned in several reviews, once you are of a certain age, yes, it is true, this would not be the place for you...but the new regime encourages youth to rise above...in fact, you can be oblivious to investments & the impact that you have on clients, but if you really want to progress, you must, for lack of any other way to position it, caress your management, because if for some logical reason you think that hard work & proven performance will promote you, or even secure your job, you may be looking at the wrong company....since 2008, MEAC, is known for, "who you know or who you have gotten to know on a very personal level"...but, from years of wisdom, I can tell you for certain, this too shall pass...I am very hopeful that some of you young & up & coming bright Financial Advisors, will embrace what the name & the culture of Merrill Lynch represents, for the great company it once was!  & truly, "Make the Difference!!!!"

review_title: Great company overall but not great for working moms
pros: Great talent management processes, pretty good culture overall, ability to find new growth opportunities internally, wonderful facilities, vacation and benefits.
cons: They have removed flexible programs that support working mothers and restricted hiring in the wholesale bank outside of 3 cities.  They actually monitor the number of hours that employees are logged in remotely to identify who may be working from home rather than the office.  If you live in New York and either don't have or don't care about seeing your children, this is the perfect place for you!

pros: Great benefits as in vacation and sick time. Pay is decent for the position. High expectations for bonus. If goals are met high incentives as well.
cons: Leadership does not respond. The challenges to switch to different locations or other positions exists. You are stuck in a position for at least a year with no chances of moving up or switching job titles.

pros: The benefits are great. Very casual place to work.
cons: In two different positions with the bank, I have been hired to do one job. I exceeded at that position so my job duties were expanded to include training employees (new hires and on-going training) and providing ongoing support and and training for employees, team leads and team managers. Though my job functions were expanding in these positions, I never received a promotion or raise (basically, I was paid the amount new employees were hired at though I was training all the new hires and performing the job of a manager (aside from HR functions).

pros: The salary is good in comparison to other industries and sectors.
cons:
-Poor work/life balance. 
-The company values that are preached are just words. They are practiced by very few people in the organization. 
-The BoA waters are filled with people that finger point and will throw others under the bus.
-"Span of Control" creates situations in which a person can essentially have two managers while being in a role that isn't clearly defined due to tug-of-war between the two managers

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: Good exposure to deal flow, bulge bracket investment banking experience, credible platfrom from which to launch a career in sell-side or buy-side corporate finance.
cons: Long hours, but that is par for the course in IB.  However, hours were on the long side even for banking, also aggressive culture of people which made it that much harder.  My understanding is that since I left they've instituted some things to improve balance for junior bankers.  Compensation was also middle of the road.

pros: Base pay is decent (or good) for what you are supposed to do as concierge. Overtime opportunities.
cons: You do same account openings over and over again everyday (which may not technically be a cons). You are graded for calls on tough rubrics by people who have never taken concierge calls; often times those rubrics don't match with the guidelines that you are following. Can be frustrating.

review_title: Perpetual reorganization makes career advancement difficult
job_title: Senior Quantitative Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: The benefits are good. Mostly nice people to work with. The salaries and bonuses are competitive. Most managers allow flexibility to work from home occasionally.
cons: As soon as you have your job figured out so that you are good at it and can be successful, a reorg happens and all of a sudden you are either in a slightly different role or have a new manager to whom you need to prove your abilities. Or you just might get demoted and erase all your hard work from the past 5 years. It is very frustrating and demotivating. The company is so big they don't know or care how they are treating their employees.

review_title: A great place to get started but a tough place to move forward
pros: The benefits package is by far one of the best of all companies. This is a great place to get your feet wet in the banking industry.
cons: It can be difficult to get promoted or branch out into different parts of the line of business due to a recent downsizing of positions available in the area.

pros: One of the best company to work. You get everything -hike,  meal, transport, learning opportunity, rewards, flexibility, work from home ,events to support your society, to keep yourself happy and engaged. people usually never leaves after finding the benefits . Its a place you can call home.
cons: gender discrimination- the ratio is very poor ,there are people who still need proper awareness to regard woman in a certain way. There are people who will keep reminding you that you are hired to maintain diversity. apart from these I never found anything to complaint.

pros: It's a job and that's it.
cons: At least 1 person is being walked out the door or quitting a week. I'm not quite sure why, but maybe it is because of new management. At least that is what the people are complaining about in the hallways.

pros: Good benefits for full time employees including 4 months of Paternity Leave.
cons: Too much of  bureaucracy at Middle Management and there are several Manager's Managers who creates politics for the sake of their own survival. They neither have technical nor business knowledge, all they do is politics. There is huge discrimination and several Managers give preferential treatment to Asian origin employees.

review_title: felt like a disposable hard working little ant
pros: the people you work with can be great
cons: it's a weird position to be in, where your employer doesn't have your back. your job is always on the line with every customer who could potentially cause any problems or turn out to be fraudulent. corporate people imposed these awfully written robotic scripts that we must read to customers to sell them products. You have to do this with every customer. No commission, but you get written up if you miss one offer. Our branch was very busy. Imagine doing that a couple hundred times a day. It's been a few years, I hope things changed, but it was completely awful and every person I knew working for bank of america at that time hated their job as much as I did. Across multiple branches.

review_title: Good learning opportunities for a new software developer, limited growth in pay
pros: There is an emphasis on mentoring and growing new developers.  Four months paid maternity/paternity leave.
cons: Technology tends to be a bit dated.  While initial pay for new hires is competitive, money for raises is very limited.   After a few years, only way to get paid market level compensation is to bring in a competing offer, which Bank of America will usually match.  Very difficult to get sponsorship for a green card.

job_title: Vice President; Senior Business Control Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Focused on employee satisfaction
Diversity is key - creating a safe place for employees to be the most authentic version of themselves.
Strong leaders in place.
Good benefits.
cons:
Discontinuing of the mywork program was tough for some, but I understand the though behind it. Personally, I was more productive at home than surrounded by the office distractions.
Paid lower than my male counterparts with equal or lesser experience. Finding a way to market adjust within groups every couple of years would go a long way at employee retention.  Increasing minimum wage is a great start at remaining competitive in a strong market.

job_title: Relationship Banker in New York, NY
pros:
1. Built strong relationships within the workplace
2. Established strong work affinity with attention to detail 
3. Adherence to financial regulations
cons:
1. Many of your colleagues and employees are uneducated and inept at their jobs. 
2. Promotion within the company is all but impossible unless you're a high performer which I've found personally morally/ethically corrupts employees
3. Skeleton crews makes the job immensely hard when a colleague is missing in action

pros: Great benefits..however no pension.  Strong Bank. Great Values.  Job technology impressive.
cons: Serious sales pressure. Heavy Micro Management.  Branch employees are not appreciated as they should be. Pay for seasoned employees low compared to new hires. A lot of favoritism in job promotions ...need to fit the corporate mold. "Coaching" to the extreme.

job_title: Sales Vice President in Seattle, WA
pros: The benefits are decent, and there was a lot of schedule flexibility.  The pay is average, probably a bit lower than at other financial institutions.
cons: Communication from senior management to the staff is terrible.  The bank has created a culture of fear and discomfort.  There is no support from management when it comes to assistance or compassion.  I felt like just a number, and that they didn't care about me as a person or as someone who devoted my life to that company.

review_title: If you don't mind large companies and red tape, then this is a good company to work for.
pros: The pay and benefits are good especially the work/home perks such as large adoption/paternity/maternity leave.
cons: Hard to see outside of your little group to move around.  Everything is very process driven, and you can only do your task and then wait for the rest of the bank to catch up with you.  Large company means lots of red tape.  Outsourcing a lot to overseas.  All internal perks have been removed due to budget constraints.

pros: Ability to work from home enables me to work remotely.  I am encouraged  use my own judgement and the bank  benefits including 401K are adequate.
cons: Poor senior leadership- decisions are made that impact not only employees but customers.  Moving processes to rural areas impacts everyone and that impact can be negative customer experience. Management shows a  lack of respect for employees and poor customer service is the end result.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: Good benefits, Medical, Dental, Vision,  401k match, Pension, recognition for a job well done in some cases.... overall friendly place to work, easy to keep busy, and sometimes will feel like a smaller company than it actually is.  Upper Management seems to care about their employees
cons: Very big company, sometimes hard to accomplish things, sometimes because it is so big reorganizations happen all the time, sometimes the focus is not easy to determine, things can get started, and then disappear into thin air, without notice or reason to change direction.

job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Stable company to work for, with decent benefits.  Depending on your work history, education, or work performance, you DO have good opportunities to advance further in the company.  If you have a good team to work with, work can be a breeze, if you don't, it can be hell.  The Quarterly Bonuses are good IF you are able to get them.  Big company, so if you need to move or transfer, chances are, their will be a BofA near you.  The higher you climb on up the ladder, the perks get better.
cons: Depending on your job role, expectations are high for your level or performance.  And most of the time, the compensation for the work & time that is expected of you does not match up.  Be careful when you are hired, for if you don't do your research, you WILL be low-balled salarywise if you are not deemed an asset to the company, or if your are applying for an entry level position.  Many of the associates for this company are college students trying to finish their degrees.  B0fA's Tuition Reimbursement program is a joke, only covering you for up to 2k,  Which is nothing if you attend a university.  The quarterly bonuses are a good, but the company makes it really hard for you to receive all of it with many performance goals & criteria that can be difficult to meet.

review_title: Creative Destruction makes a company lean and mean, but it's no fun after a while.
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: BofA is a large and stable bank that will survive this credit crisis.
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement, mostly due to what is happening in the industry. BofA has succeeded via a growth-trough-acquisition strategy. The downside for associates is that every acquisition includes restructuring and layoffs. The Merrill merger alone will cost 30k-35k jobs.

job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: The opportunities are great and the chances to develop great skills is definitely there. The talent as a whole is good, but depending on what branch the overall ability to get things done collectively is really suspect. I enjoyed my time there and worked very hard, but had great co workers to balance it all out.
cons: The management can be a bit particular. The answer to that question is no so pushing services sometimes seemed fruitless.

review_title: Bank of America is still one of the strongest financial institutions which hold true to their customer commitment.

Pay rises in big companies are a challenge, the same here.
Need to negotiate salaries well otherwise one could lowballed.

review_title: Merge with Merrill right away and rehire the premier bankers.
job_title: Financial Advisor in Walnut Creek, CA

The premier bankers where fired and now the brokers have to manage checking accounts and lending for their clients without being paid to do so.  Referrals from the retail bank are non-existent.

review_title: One of the better jobs I've had
pros: Worked in a sales environment, but didn't have to worry about managers looking over your shoulder all the time.  All you had to do is complete your work, meet your goals and you would be fine.  Good benefits, I moved up fairly quickly and overall was a great working environment
cons: The only con that I can think of is when changes would come down from corporate we would sometimes get no warning whatsoever.  We would be told something was changing and then it would be effective Monday.

review_title: Terrible place to work if you want a career
pros:
-Stable (if not boring) work
-Paycheck and benefits are adequate
-Great company to work for if you're looking to come in, work, get your paycheck, and go home.
cons: Full disclosure: I'm a legacy Merrill Lynch employee and I loved everything about MER.  The culture was focused on client service and excellence.  Employees were rewarded with bonuses and promotions for going above and beyond.  It was a true meritocracy.  BAC is all about tenure to lead toward advancement, and as an elite performer, (among the youngest in my group) I find this immeasurably frustrating.  Further, the culture seems to strive for mediocraty.  I kid you not, one of our internal review teams is called the PAR Team.

job_title: Information Technology Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Very open to virtual work (work where you want, don't have to be in office), and it is possible to move around within the company.  Generally, a great place to work.
cons: It's huge (which has good and bad side), there is not a unifying corporate culture any longer - mergers have lead to a feel that you work in one of many companies.  Additionally, after a merger, you accept the good and the bad of the prior company - and it's tough to have the Bank of America name associated with what Countrywide did.

review_title: Bank of America has a plethora of policies and processes on project management and six sigma,
pros: Bank of America has a plethora of policies and processes on project management and six sigma.  They have good training and allow a person to improve there marketability through internal training.
cons: Bank of America has a plethora of policies and processes on project management and six sigma.  They don't always follow the procedures and sometimes follow the procedures when not needed.

review_title: Working here is like working for the government
pros: You get lots of vacation time and work/life balance.  Some groups encourage working from home (while some don't).  They claim transferring from one job to another is very easy.
cons: The pay is low, the morale can be low (depending on the group) and career growth is limited.  The company operates like the government...no frills and acts as slow as a dinosaur.

pros: The company has an incredible benefits package that I am very thankful for. They provide opportunity for advancement and has been an overall great company to work for.
cons: The company is always striving to be the best so with that mindset the culture is very demanding. If you are not willing to be challenged then this is not a company to work for.

review_title: Awesome place to start a career either in Retail, wholesale or Investment Banking.
pros: Due to its vast presence, it has provided thousands of people to start there career with one of the world's biggest bank. It provides lots of opportunity to learn new things and as well to enhance our existing skills. Exceptional performers are always appreciated. Rare situations of work pressure.
cons: It takes bit large time to grow due to the traditional hierarchical structure. As well the responsibilities are not properly distributed.

pros: BOA is really a nice place to work, team spirit is widely promotes. Benefits are very good. Retirment plans are incouraged. Salaries are on the high end. They have a set of core values that promote a nice culture. Managers are evaluated by their associates which "usually" weeds out poor management. In my case I received 100 percent associate surveys whsich means my teams were very happy with my management style. My Unit Managers style was very different than mine and I was actually terminated because of a minor oversight that occured duing a very difficult divorce. But that doesn't change my oppinion of the corporations. I enjoyed working there and I enjoyed the BOA culture. BOA strives to ensure employee, customer, and stock holder satisfaction. A very very dificult balance but the core values set the tone, my favorite retention of the the very best associates. I do not know of any other comapny that makes that statemen AND follows throuh on it but BOA does for the most part. My situation being the exception.
cons:
Customer service call centers are on the weak side. Resolving an issue almost always takes several deapartment transfers and/or multiple calls. In additon the customer usually receives misinformation because of the high turn over in the customer servce support area. My suggestion to all callers is ask the representative how long they have been with the bank and request a more seasoned rep if need be. Not always a supervisor because they are not on the phones and would not have the same knowledge as a seasoned representastive with years of problem research and resolve experience. 

Fees are a con for BOA their fee structure is designed to create revenue moreover discouraging poor financial management. In my oppinion a banks fee scale should generate revenue but should also penalize poor finacial management to promote the better financial well being for the customer. Managers are strongly urged not to wave penalties if the erro was not the banks fault; however, most are BOA's fault for not "educating" the customer on the banks policies. The customer is most often educated by trial and error. If an account has been opened less than six months the manager should have the option of waiving up to three fees but also required to "educate" the customer on their policies. If an account has been opened for more than five years then three fees should waived. If the customer has multiple relationships then then the managers should have the authority to waive up to three fees with out question. Branch Managers need to be impowered so the customers feel like the bank mananger is someone of power not just another suit with their hands tied up in policies they have no authority to munipulate to service the customer.

review_title: Bait and switch... all the way.
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Lady Lake, FL

As an SSS I am allegedly only supposed to work as a teller roughly 25% of the time but I have entire weeks where I am forced to work as a teller. I don't want to be a teller, that's not what I applied for. Immediate management within the banking center are great but regional management are complete bumbling fools, they send out mass emails with severe grammatical emails. review_title: Great coworkers, great benefits, positive work environment.
pros: Subsidized health/dental insurance with several different options, ranging from high deductible to full coverage. Two weeks each of paid vacation and sick time, along with leaves of absence. Maternity leave can be extended up to six months. There's also low turnover so you have a chance to get to know coworkers, and job security--no one gets fired out of the blue.
cons: It's a popular bank so there are long lines at nearly every branch, and the amount of hours provided for tellers per branch is low in comparison, so it seems like branches are short-staffed even when they're not.

review_title: Seems like a good place to work but......
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV

review_title: Really Great place to work at!

job_title: Mortgage Resolution Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA

review_title: Focus on the associates could make BAC an A+ place to work.

job_title: Market Information Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: Worked in eCommerce division. Was able to work from home for most of my 7 years. Good benefits.
cons: They started limiting the remote work, making it difficult for employees dispersed around the country. In eCommerce, there seemed to be a tendency to move older women with some managerial experience into lower positions and then lay them off. Issues with managers ignored if the manager was a favorite of higher ups.

job_title: Personal Banker in South Florida, FL
pros: Great benefits, there is room to advance, all things considered the work/life isn't all too bad in hind sight, salary is a bit better than competitors, work resources and technology are very good (makes your job much easier/efficient), paid vacation time is above average. AWESOME tuition reimbursement...basically paid for my degree. Awesome community involvement and volunteering available. Overall i would recommend bank of america in a heart beat...but attempt to advance as quickly as possible because the longer you remain in a banking center (esp a large one) the faster your spirit begins to drown.
cons: Learning Spanish is an unwritten requirement when looking for advancement, stress level is very high in larger branches, branches are very understaffed which makes for frustrating times. Vacation time is ample, attempting to take a vacation is another story (lots of hurdles to jump through to get the time you want, seniority means absolutely nothing, Very easy to get "blacklisted" within the company....all it takes is a manager or regional manager to dislike you and your chances to advance are up in smoke...everything is sales focused which can create bad sales interactions for the customers (product pushing) and your are told by a manager at the end of the day not to push products, yet at the end of the week when your sales aren't up to par you are reprimanded for that too.... at this time the company is focused on driving revenue as opposed to doing what is right for the customer (if you have moral standards this may eat away at you eventually). Because of the aggressive sales goals there is a lot of back stabbing and cut throat activities among bankers whose number 1 goal is to win. Beware of bankers who win at all cost, even if it is at the expense of the customer or team. If you can deal with a cut throat, understaffed, high pressure sales environment with a heavily micromanaged team with a half day off during the week to rest then you will make it within Bank of America....the question is for how long.

review_title: Too large, doesn't focus on developing employees
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY

job_title: Portfolio Management Officer in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Front End Developer in Plano, TX

job_title: Relationship Manager in Silver Spring, MD
pros: You can make alot of money in the right market. Some Relationship managers make $100k.
cons: The goals are very high with two or three other relationship managers in the same branch competing for sales. review_title: Great company if you're in a core city
job_title: Process Design Consultant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits and employee programs; company is focused on strong business goals and strategy, however sometimes things go astray between the CEO and the reality (for example, in flattening the company hierarchy, generally the only levels removed were at the bottom of the hierarchy, meaning the people who knew the most about the business were eliminated, and leading to many managers having to manage a wide range of things they didn't know anything about).
cons: If you are not located in a core city (Charlotte, Atlanta, Dallas, New York, or a couple of others), and you are not part of the sales force (branches, client managers, and their managers), then you are not truly part of the team. The company is slowly shrinking all operational jobs to core locations, putting people who work remotely or in small locations in a tough position. Regardless of whether this is the right business approach for the future, HOW they handle it with the PEOPLE impacted is not always done well. They only lay off the worst employees (giving them large severance packages), leaving the remaining people to do more work. They demote some really good managers solely due to where they they. They keep hiring people in core locations from a very small applicant pool, and they are getting some really mediocre people (and leaders) that way.  They have such trouble getting good onshore technology contractors that little forward progress is made; a lot of time is spent fixing what they did, or on-boarding new people due to constant churn.

pros: Regardless of the current market conditions and leaner organizational structure, BofA does provide a great opportunity to college grads who want formalized training while getting exposure to multiple areas through their rotational program. There are a lot of talented and intelligent associates who are best-in-breed which in itself helps further the competitive environment.  Many teammates are true friends and like family.  You work with people all over the country, and possibly across the globe.  Brand carries a lot of recognition and titles are great for grad school application purposes (you really have to earn them, invest time to the company & perform exceedingly well.)
cons: underpaid associates & inconsistent salaries for the same position across the country.  HR has no clue about the true cost of living in cities outside of the southeast.  lots of bureaucracy, forms, and unnecessary steps to get a job / task done.  inability to retain many experienced, professional associates.  recruiting efforts are suspect - has evolved from a search for those who offer most promise, sincere interest in the company, and intelligence (i.e. recruiting at top business schools) to cronyism (i.e. because an executive is an alma mater from some obscure liberal arts school... they recruit there...and those new associates have tremendous pull to hire their pals.  increasingly is becoming an old-boys network in some cities where it wasn't so before (or that was evolving away from it).  hard to get recognized for doing a great job.  sometimes, unrealistic goals -- which affects year-end compensation and the likelihood of getting anything.  again, starting salary is low and you really need the full potential bonus amount to be at a competitive salary for your position in your city.  bonuses are extremely subjective and often less than 50% of what is quoted at the time of offer.  some 'older' associates that they hire are often pompous, ineffective, and "lightweights" in their role.  they are flashy talkers, know how to manage-up, but are not team-players or professional in behavior.

review_title: Senior management largely responsible for unsatisfactory experience
job_title: Business Support Manager in Hong Kong
pros:
- By and large people are in good spirits and nice to work with. You don't feel like people are actively trying to stab you in the back to get a leg up in their career. 
- The offices and technology are all state of the art and in good working order. Overall it is a nice physical work space that most people would be happy with.
cons:
-Career Opportunities - Not many career opportunities. BAML outside the USA is a bit different from other US banks. Instead of looking to increase their share of foreign business, BAML is really just looking to facilitate business with their US clientele. This means that they really aren't interested in growing their Asian business. headcount in the region has largely been decreasing and much of the work done in the region is actually meant to find ways to automate roles. 
- Work-Life - It is a US Bank in Asia which means that depending on your role, you will probably be doing 1-4 late night conference calls a week. I regularly did 10-12 hour days. Many other people did much worse. 
- Senior Management - Though it seems like there is a lot of change in the financial industry of late, senior management doesn't seem to have changed at all. It just felt like an old boy's club (and I am a man myself) with massive amounts of politics and huge quantities of wasted efforts just to keep senior leaders happy. I acknowledge that part of a person's job is to help make their senior leader look good, but it just felt like we were spending too much of our time doing this so that he could keep his comfortable role. 
- Culture and values - Sure, BAML has them, but I just don't think senior leadership even bothers to pretend like they live them. Apart from mandatory training, which is largely lost on most people, the values seem largely uncommunicated. 

Compensation and Benefits - this is probably the one bright spot (and probably the only reason people actually work here). I felt the pay and benefits were quite good. 

Overall - If you need a job that pays a salary, work here. If you have any options, I recommend that you work somewhere else.

pros: The main advantage of working at BOA is the work-life balance. Even banking center managers typically work only 40 hours/wk, and that is during banking hours, of course. The benefits are awesome: great health insurance, 401k and pension, childcare reimbursement ($135/mo for informal care or $250/mo for formal daycare), company-funded health care account ($300/yr individual, $600/yr for a couple, or $1200/yr for a family--status based on your health coverage). A few progressive benefits: domestic partners covered, infertility covered, gender reassignment surgery covered. Promotions are very fair: pretty much everyone starts from the bottom as a teller now. Even the market leaders mostly started as tellers. Your performance and willingness to change banking centers when positions become available determine how fast you move up.
cons: Outside experience and education don't count for much. You still start at the bottom, but you may move up a little faster. You have to be very careful because 1 or 2 losses or write-ups can really hurt your ability to move up. Vacation is pretty skimpy--only 2 weeks for tellers w/ less than 5 yrs at the bank. They just cut out our bonuses, so tellers now get no cash bonuses.Management is always shifting priorities. They go overboard focusing on whatever new priority they have, and lose sight of everything else. For example, right now we have a long, elaborate greeting we have to do, and you'd better get it right if you're visited by a secret shopper. In a couple months they'll change their focus again & forget all about the silly greeting. Training is HORRIBLE. If you haven't worked as a teller before, you'd better be ready to fight to get sufficient training. My #1 piece of advice if you get hired: do not just let them throw you out there. It's your butt on the line if you make mistakes because you're not well trained.

review_title: Bank of America - The Land of Opportunity?

pros: Because the company is so big, there are many opportunities to network and move internally in the company.  The company is always going through change therefore both formal and informal opportunities are always available to develop change & project management skills.  There are many great leaders in the company and excellent networking opportunities.  We also have great benefits including work from home flexibility and generous vacation time (vaction is separate from sick/personal time allotment).
cons:
- Company culture has gone down the drain since 2007. After acquiring very Merrill & Countrywide, the friendly "let's help each other learn and grow to reach higher standards together" bank culture has been replaced with a "throw people under the bus" and "get ahead by any means, including making snap business decisions without considering consequences" culture.  The company doesn't care as much for it's associates as they used to. The atmosphere is highly political, much more so than it was in the past.
- The company is VERY disorganized and lacks in an integrated communication strategy even within individual business units.  The right hand never knows what the left hand is doing, even within peer teams.  We spend a lot of time fixing problems that we create internally (many due to poor decisions, or lack of communication).
- Company is too big, too complex, and extremely hard to navigate.  There are many convoluted processes in place (like internal recruiting, compensation, & promotions) that the average associate does not understand.  Like wise, the company is so big that it's very hard to know what's what organizationally & who's who, even within the smaller business units. 
- Company does not require formal training for managers.  Likewise, most associates are only required to take annual compliance training, but no formal on the job training. This often leads to entire teams not knowing/understanding and underperforming in their function within the process.  A lot of associates and managers are set up for failure if they are not savvy enough to just "figure it out".
- Compensation/Promotions: The "lucky" associates that have the opportunity to work for great leaders may be fortunate enough to be paid in the appropriate range and recieve promotions based on capabilities and value add/leadership potential to the company.  THIS VERY RARELY HAPPENS. More often then not, associates do not get timely promotions or raises. The associates who "play the game", but may do less or lower quality work will be be paid more than the guy who's really performing.  Furthermore, all performance evaluations & rate increases, etc. are subjective based on the immediate manager.  There is no consistency in how associates are rated, which leaves a lot of room for favoritism.
- The company overall has certain values and advocates specific things like (inclusive meritocrazy, and flexible work schedules) but all that depends on the immediate manager. If an associates immediate manager does not advocate the companies values, than the associate is out of luck.  Likewise, there is no associate support to protect from bad/poor management. If an associate is dealing with an unfair manager, he/she has no true recourse of action (other than to call the internal HR Advice & Counsel hotline, which means nothing because all they will do is document for a case against the associate if the problem continues to compound).
