pros: The benefits are amazing. Health care has two options, and HMO or CDHP. They pay for child care,  give $3k towards the purchase of a hybrid or electric car ($2250 after taxes), and give you money in your HSA  account (we got $1000 for a family).
cons: They frown upon even a minute of OT  for non-exempt employees. For salaried employees, they pay just slightly above the new labor law threshold, so they can get 50-60 hours out of you without paying extra. Healthcare is more expensive if you make over $50k cash compensation.

pros: Routine work. Get reasonable starting pay. Able to interact with customers, great if you are a people person.  As an employee, you can take advantage of the best services such as high end accounts without needing to maintain a balance minimum . Great growth opportunities.
cons: Gossip is evident throughout all of the branches. Many managers play favorites,  and participate in office gossip.  Affairs between employees were also common in my area.  Not a great work/life balance.   Tellers are not allowed to sit, ever.  Some days, Tellers are completely slammed and are breaks are not openly encouraged.  Expect to stand for 8 hrs straight.   Very stressful at times.

pros: Full Disclosure: My last work day was actually in 2006, but didn't give the option to go that far back... Great people, decent management. Pay was just enough to keep you comfortable, but not enough to get you ahead.
cons: As with many large corporations, they were would not let implemented plans come to full fruition before implementing another one.  Once got written up for being 20 seconds late from lunch. As far as bonuses, it was more about beating the numbers rather than doing the actual work which became soul crushing.

job_title: Pres Relationship Manager in Fort Myers, FL
pros: The work itself is great. The company has enhanced its health and benefits package. The base pay is comparably fair.
cons: So many changes it will keep your head on a swivel. Constant updates with operating programs, has not adopted paperless operating systems. Half hour lunches. Bonus payout is highly dependent on your overall's team success. Multiple managers system can make your job expectations or role very unclear.

pros: I began the training portion of Bank of America client servicing team two months prior and although there is a lot to follow and comprehend it comes quite easily
cons: I have only worked there for a brief amount of time   I would say there are some cons I can think on the top of my head number one being very little time away from phones very little time for bathroom breaks outside of your lunch and 215 minute breaks

review_title: BAC a great place to work and build a career
job_title: Instructor II, Assistant Vice President in Brea, CA
pros: It was a great company to work for. The opportunity to advance is there as long as you are applying yourself and doing your job exceptionally well. Diversity is also a major positive for this company. Benefits are great!
cons: If there is any type of complaintabout you there is very little recourse for you if you are "guilty" and your career or reputation can be tarnished. Someone can launch a smear campaign against you and you have no way to defend yourself against allegations.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Associates are friendly, good hours.  I have been with the company for almost 2 years and there is a lot of room for growth and development as well a positive work culture that promotes your best well-being.
cons: Some of the branches are understaffed and it creates extra stress for the employees of those branches and frustration with the customers that come in.  Even with the improvements in technology that allow banking to be done practically anywhere, it is not a reason to sacrifice an entire department of retail banking.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Glendale, AZ
pros: Learned computer skills, I learned how to apply computer skills to the customers I served, I also learned valuable phone skills and how to deal with irate customers, it was a very good experience and I can use these skills in my next job.. it was stressful but i learned a lot about going the extra mile for my customers
cons: Stress the stress on the job because we were supposed to handle the calls within a five minute time frame was very stressful and often I had to go over that time limit to satisfy my client. So it was not a very good environment

review_title: Great times cane to an end
pros: The company cares about doing what is right for it's customers regardless of cost and expense.  It was nice knowing I was part of something very ethical even when the media did not portray it as such.
cons: Like all businesses they need to react to changing market conditions and that led to downsizing which impacted my work location and me personally.  So my time ended but I was provided support in my job search and a severance package.

job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in New York, NY
pros: Now that I have interviewed at other companies (Banks) I actually have no pros
cons:
Vacation time is based on years at BOA and many other Banks offer  PTO which starts at no less than 4 weeks a year. 
Bonuses are paid if you are working diligently toward your goal & not making it.  Yearly review raises.  Work, life balance is actually a priority not just talked about. When down sizing a position, they did it by Center not by capability.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Many projects, career advancement, culture of valuing employees. Annual raises and semi-annual performance reviews. Professional atmosphere, good colleagues. Very generous family leave.
cons: Corporate culture and red tape. If you get on a bad project you can end up working long hours with difficult deadlines. It all depends on which team you are on. Once you have been there for a while you can speak up and transfer to different teams.

pros: Great for entry level financial advisors to learn business, exposure to managed products. BofA is a big place so there are opportunities to post out after a year.
cons: Glorified banker, too much pressure to sell bank products, Competition with bank relationship managers, Merrill Edge is too close to bankers as far as goals, expectations, etc. so you step all over each other....consumer banking is a horrible place to be, Managers  are de-motivating and almost threatening for performance., moral is low. You have to justify using the restroom and  therefore, not available to clients.

review_title: Mixed. Great job, not su much for a career.
pros: The Employee Networks are rich and vibrant. Management says the right things at the right times.
cons:
The environment is political and bureaucratic. Despite the work of Senior Management, the politics and bureaucracy persists.

There is a ceiling for people at BAC. Typically, in Technology, this occurs at Band 3. The internal advice is leave, and if you prefer, after a few years, come back.

pros: Part time work.The pay is going to increase by 2020 but you will PAY dearly for it.
cons: Wants same referral results as full time.They will make you feel like a failure if you don't get them referrals.They will then keep track and pick at every little thing you do to fire you or make you leave.They have favorites here so be prepared.If you can get referrals daily you will be fine .The minute you don't look out they are coming for you.They want checking accounts, credit cards,applications, etc.daily....Although, they migrate half your line to the atm and customers you see are repeat customers.

review_title: Bank creates opprotunities to last a lifetime as a career.
job_title: ECommerce Product Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: The bank is a large organization that deals with several different aspects of the financial industry so your opportunties are large.  You can move around within different groups at the bank and feel as if you started working for a new company which is great and refreshing for your career growth.
cons: The recruiting and job search is less than par.  Very very slow process with little communications between recruiting and an associate who is posting.

review_title: Pro's & Con's at Bank of America--Premier Division
job_title: Premier Client Manager in Naples, FL
pros:
Benefit Package
National Bank
Many Resources
Many Customers
The primary focus of the CRC Client Manager Candidate role is to build client relationships that will lead to generating revenue for the business. Significant marketing and proactive relationship building skills will be essential to broaden existing relationships. CRC Client Manager Candidates will be able to demonstrate comprehensive understanding of banking capabilities with the client by assessing needs, identifying, and recommending financial solutions. The successful CRC Client Manager Candidate will inspire trust & confidence in clients through problem solving, listening carefully to the client??s needs, and by proactively managing products and/or services through telephone contact. Eligibility for this position requires candidates to possess Series 6 and 63 licenses required.
cons: Poor Senior Management That Is Not Consistent, Nor Realistic

review_title: Bank of America is a solid company that will be around for centuries.
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Houston, TX
pros: The best reason to work for B of A would have to be the benefits. 3 months maternity leave Male or Female, 4 weeks off vacation anually as a manager are two of the great benefits as a Banking Center Manager.
cons: The Salary is not what you could earn at some of the competitors. Realistically, Bank of America is a very safe place to work now-a-days considering the economic conditions we face.

job_title: Vice President Technology in Jersey City, NJ
pros: 1. Good benefits especially if you are planning family :)
cons:
1. compensation package in technology is very poor compared to other wall street banks for similar role.
2. Although Bank of America stresses on work-life balance. It depends on your manager how flexible and fair he/she is to allow you the flexibility to manage work-life balance.
3. Bank has a very bureaucratic process towards work. So good ideas are appreciated but you have to be really lucky to get the support to action them. 
4. Growth is dependent on how good rapport you have with your manager and how much your manager supports your case.  Performance is a secondary attribute.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in McLean, VA
pros: Global Outreach, Many different divisions within the bank to advance into, fair compensation packages only if you know how to negotiate (especially as an internal promotion).
cons: You have to know and be liked by the hiring managers to get a promotion, qualifications alone don't cut it. You have to be very aggressive and let it be known that you are interested in moving up in the company or else people will think you are content where you are right now.

pros:
Excellent Benefits
Rewarding Success annual bonus
Paid Holdays
Possibility to move up if working for Legacy BofA personnel
Customer focused and concerned with Associate Satisfaction if working for Legacy BofA Management.
cons:
Still have a lot of clean up to do as far as legacy CW Executives and Management
Lack of communication from Management at times

review_title: Financial management and advice for high net worth clients innan assigned territory.
job_title: Premier Client Manager in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros: This company offers competitive salaries to Client Managers who are doing well. Company benefits  are second to none compared to competitors.
cons: Management was poor. Some client managers get assigned to territories where they can hardly make a sale, and yet are expected to perform at the same level with others in more affluent territories.

pros: Big company, encourages movement within company.  Lots of opportunities to move laterally as well as upward.  Easy to stay challenged and motivated with so many lines of business.  Overall has very positive people and a very good annual review process that helps you to develop yourself and take advantage of opportunities.
cons: Big company politics that you'll experience anywhere.  If you run into it you can always apply internally and move around.

pros: They have fairly good benefits.
cons: It could be a good place  but there is so much political drama - one would think Merrill Lynch rescued Bank of America and not the other way around.  There is a witch hunt going on with trying to rid the company of all BofA employees in London.  It is not a pleasant place to be at the moment.

pros:
Great Benefits, Easy Job, Great vacation days - If you want to make good money for little effort, this is an easy place to get work.

Projects are usually large and tied to some type of financial impact.

The Bank is so large, you can find almost any job you imagined, but there will be stiff comp for the roles.
cons:
Lots of meetings
Lots of Red Tape
Long development cycle
Huge budgets
You'll find you lose a lot of efficiency as you have to start over again and again.
Monotonous

review_title: Great compensation and variety in regards to finance, work is not always fulfilling
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Excellent compensation as compared to other finance roles, offers diverse opportunities through frequent rotations, collaborative culture that encourages sharing of knowledge
cons: Very frequent change for the sake of change that is not tied to any measurable improvement in the business, lots of busy work within the finance function that is not challenging or personally rewarding

pros: Good Benefits and excellent source of information about the products and regulations.
cons: Split days off, you rarely can have 2 days off together, lack of respect from management, very poor opportunity to advance not support from your manager, important events are not communicated among employees, we had to chit chat here and there to find out some of the info, management do not pay attention to employee's concern or suggestion. Rush training even the managers offer to do the test for new employees.

review_title: Good place to work - Not perfect by any means, but a great platform
pros:
- large. multinational bank
- top tier player in most industries and products
- lots of very bright people
- increasing global presence
- extensive client relationships
cons:
- one word: countrywide
- overly bureaucratic
- conflicting strategies in different parts of the bank

review_title: Frustrating bureaucratic environment where the decision making is broken
pros: One of the greatest opportunities in Financial Services history
cons: Inability of executive management to execute

review_title: Poor experience, wouldn't recommend as a place to work
pros: The vacation time was good. In class banking training was good. I enjoyed the role playing and team buildling exercises. Some branches are nicer than others.
cons: Very political, positions are not well compensated. Dead-end job. Benefits were too expensive. Training was too long, computer based. Training would be better if they were on the job and real time. Focus on the job tasks at hand.

review_title: Lots of read tape. Leadership needs to spend some time looking at how they are allocate monies.
pros: They match your 401. Ok time off, although is not PTO. Offer lots of educational classes for free online.
cons: Too much money is wasted on resources that don't support daily/project needs or needs that could be performed at the local level. They don't give enough "local" authority, consequently it takes longer to get something done and the follow up work in exhausting! Too many chiefs and not enough Indians. Pay rate is not always equal to amount of work or experience you bring or create at your job.

review_title: Great job for a paycheck right now.
pros: Bank of America has good benefits overall.  You get a nice variety of banking service for free.  Made a decent paycheck and never worried about not receiving enough hours.
cons: Very picky about what you could and could not do for customers. For example, you may get in trouble for something as simple as printing out a customers bank statement when the day before you manager explained that that was a task you needed to do.And the chance for promotions was close to zero.

pros: Money and benefits are good, but you will work like a dog for them
cons: Very little support to employees who are not in a central office. Too many people try to manage employees' work, very confusing and no matter what you do, someone has decided that you are failing. Receive minimal support or training as a new hire, not even a desk, phone, or computer for nearly a month.

review_title: Great internship to experience wealth management and financial advisory.
pros:
While I only was an intern for 3 months, this is what I noticed:
Efficient culture
Great, intelligent people
Fortune 10 company
High producing teams that seem to be rivaled by no one else in the wealth management industry
cons: Interns, which is what I was, didn't receive any compensation. Interns did receive college course credit, however. Yet, this credit still had to be paid for by the intern.

pros: The only limitation is self and the ability to network and grow from within. All cards are on the table if you are driven and have a goal in mind.
cons: Being on the tech side of the house is a very thankless job. Management only cares when things don't work, then all hell breaks loose. On the other hand tech jobs will last much longer than any Project related jobs so the tradeoff might be even. I am sure this is the same anywhere else.

review_title: Large Bureaucratic Firm with Outdated Mentality
job_title: Senior Vice President in Calabasas, CA
pros: Ability to work in bank with broad market power.  Great opportunity to move throughout the firm in different positions.
cons: The firm is overly reliant on HR in all decision making, which further hampers already suboptimal performance.  The focus is on depth of management skills, rather than expertise in subject area, so managers with no experience are often given the lead over areas in which they lack knowledge or experience.  Buzzword environment where appearing to do the job and the process is more important than the results.

pros:
Excellent Growth Opportunities in banking domain
Direct interaction with clients - Good experience in working with teams across different locations @ offshore and onshore
cons: Bank of America depends a lot on its contractors  -Like Accenture, TCS, Infy, IBM - They drive the things from their -this will give a little chances for Associates to show their skills upto the mark due to lack of opportunistic with in the projects

pros: Great company reputation, great research, great training, competitive salary, opportunities to work independently as long as producing results.  Great opportunity to listen to industry experts.  Get out what you put in.
cons: Extensive research and support means giving 62% of commissions to company.  About 90% of focus is on prospecting for clients when building a book of business.  Culture and values completely about how many new assets can be brought in and not as much focus on attention to current clients.  Not for everyone.

review_title: Great benefits.   Can be a lousy culture.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Good pay scale. Flexible working arrangements.  Some smart people who really do try to do the right thing, despite the bureaucracy.
cons: I came over during the Merrill Lynch merger. Since then, I've had several new managers, and never meet any of them in person.  There are 400 tools needed to do your job, and it's easy to spend a day wrestling with a tool instead of doing real work.  The bureaucracy can be stifling.

job_title: Sales Support Associate in Dallas, TX
pros:
401K plan is good. 100% match up to 5% of annual salary. They deposit 2% at the end of the year on top.

Work varies between departments & managers, but overall a decent job except for compensation.
cons:
Raises are based on salary, so if you start with a small salary they will not count for much. This goes for both promotions and annual raises. 

Job doesn't always feel safe, as lines of business are shuffled and dismissed on occasion. When a position becomes available it is often filled before line of business associates even get a chance to apply (transfers from other departments, sometimes even from outside).

job_title: Risk Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Some of us get to work from from home.
Tons of learning opportunities.
Bank of America is a great name on your resume.
cons:
Large organizations mean there is the possibility for you to get stuck in a small area of work that doesn't translate well to other companies.
Lots of competition here and its easy to have your job eliminated.

review_title: A company struggling to stay competitive after terrible decisions from previous management.
job_title: Home Services Specialist in Concord, CA
pros: Great benefits including vacation, sick leave, child care, tuition reimbursement, and banking discounts.
cons: Depending on your line of business and upper management, lots of office politics. Constant layoffs hamper morale and at times it doesn't seem like upper management knows what they're doing in terms of responding to market changes.

review_title: AVP - CNSLT - BUS TECH INTG (credit card technology SME)
job_title: Business Technology Analyst in Addison, TX
pros: Decent Benefits.  Four weeks vacation plus two weeks of sick time was really great for taking care of my young kids.  I had a couple of really outstanding managers but I'm not sure that's the norm.
cons: Exceptionally rigid bureaucracy at times.  BAC is a behemoth so some departments don't react to customers or the market very efficiently.    There are many internal controls that can be counterproductive.  It is often difficult to find appropriate resources.

review_title: Good Company with GREAT EMPLOYEE BENEFITS.
job_title: Professional Teller in New York, NY
pros:
Great Benefits
Flexible Schedule
Career Advancement
You know exactly where you stand/ rank with your performance. 
Teller position is very involved in different aspects of the business, you can learn a lot and move up quickly. 
Have anonymous employee hotline for complaints about anyone or anything.
cons: Very competitive and a lot of pressure is put on tellers its not just take care of the customer and make sure your money is right at the end of the day. The teller position is much more involved. You are measured which can be both a con and a pro. A pro because you know where you need to improve.

review_title: Loved my job; disappointed in how I was let go.
pros: The training was outstanding. I loved the open door policy that the managers had.
cons: I was let go because of my attendance. I missed a few days because my infant was ill. Since my missed days didn't effect me directly, I was released from my position. I don't think that I should have lost my job because of the days missed. My child being sick was out of my control, and was a first priority for me.

review_title: My experience with the work and people overall was good, assuming you make it through all the layoffs.
pros: People (overall) were great to work with and I enjoyed most of the work I had done with the company. There seem to be opportunities to try new things and get training.
cons: The layoffs... and more layoffs... and more layoffs. Hard to take pride in the company when good people (including yourself) drop like flies all the time. I understand a company needs to make money but it has been a different company and culture since Hugh McColl left.

review_title: Good work experience but long way to go for a good carreer
pros:
Great company benefits 
Good working hours 
Hourly pay 
Bank policies
Work experience in cash handling, customer service, and sales.
cons:
Unresponsive co workers (not working in a team) 
Poor management 
Based on favoritism

review_title: Bank of America has great benefits for employees. The perks are better
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in New York, NY
pros: The best reason to work here are the perks. Through their community and charitable contributions, I have met a Nobel Peace Prize winner, got paid to deliver food to the elderly, and walk some great dogs! If you're on a good team, life balance is amazing!
cons: They really should be more competitive with regard to assistant salaries/bonus.  As Wall Street companies go, other brokerage houses and banks pay their assistants better.

review_title: My experience at Bank of America was satisfactory. I really enjoyed the work I did, helping homeowners.
pros: Flexible work options. Bank of America has many work from home positions which is awesome. Additionally the health benefits and other perks such as company discounts are hard to beat.
cons: Employees are paid slightly less to their peers at other major banks in similar positions. The company is also set to continue layoffs through the end of the year.

review_title: Benefits are hard to compete with.
job_title: Branch Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Work-life balance is nice, I get to pick up my kids from school most days and 3 or 4 weeks of paid vacation has been nice. Benefits are hard to compete with, I've looked elsewhere but they keep me here. Tuition reimbursement, health care, child-care reimbursement, etc.
cons: Personnel turnover in branch gets frustrating. Various managers, since it is nearly impossible to get fired there are people who get moved up simply because they've been in their current role for so long. They have no business being in management.

job_title: Foreclosure Specialist in Simi Valley, CA
pros: great benefits, decent pay and thats all i can say
cons: management doesn't care about their employees. they were incapable of providing proper training and did not have any procedure manuals. they expected employees to self teach themselves. so many people went on stress leave it wasn't worth the stress at all. Management didn't even know what they were doing thats why they all got laid off. a lot of favoritism as well… management were all women and they promoted their friends to get ahead. lots of catty chatter and did not care about being loud around employees. these women made it seem like they were so unhappy in their home life so they treated people so poorly in their work environment.

review_title: Exactly the part time job I needed
pros: Benefits for part timers (tuition reimbursement!). Flexible hours at non-traditional banking centers. Easy to transfer to other branches (I moved a couple of times/different states).
cons: Same challenges of any service position (difficult customers). If you're stuck in a banking center with a manager who is more about cutting costs than helping provide good service, that's no fun.  Dealing with other people's money isn't for everyone.

job_title: Sales Support Associate in New York, NY
pros: Nice office.  Some good people.  Advancement opportunities.   Good job if your moving up the ranks from retail banking.
cons: HIGHLY bureaucratic.   Company is (any one who works there will tell you this) a process driven organization.  Not Results driven.  The work is very redundant, due to the many systems that are employed that are not integrated.   Lots of busy work.  Seems like middle mgmt often takes on assignments to make themselves look like a high performer in the eyes of their superior.  Ends up just keeping the SSA's extremely busy and unable to devote there time to improving the actually business (helping the portfolio managers).

pros: Wonderful benefits program. Consumer banking has many strong individual contributors who truly care about their clients.
cons: Consumer banking continues to see massive cutbacks, greatly effecting associate & customer satisfaction. This has turned into underpaid & overworked associates & even more disgruntled customers for them to try to satisfy with less time & fewer resources.

review_title: nice paid vacation/sick time plus all federal holidays
job_title: Assistant Vice President Team Fulfillment Manager in Irving, TX
pros: The banking and investment end of Bank of America shines
cons: Outdated mortgage systems, underwriting reflects too many tiers of risk due to repeatedly paying for  past mistakes from Countrywide days with no customer service initiatives. Did not see any room for growth due to constant layoffs. No company match of 401k.  Big box bank mentality for mortgages.

review_title: Bank Of America is one of the best companies to work for
job_title: Vice President IT in Newark, NJ
pros: Training, energetic corporate culture, Support , Good benefits, Flexible work hours and location, Diversity, Cultural sensitivity, chances to grow within and outside your area of expertise, Support from Senior management, actively polls personnels for inputs and actually act on the feedback. Industry standard pay scale. Big support for women in technology.
cons: As with all Large organizations specially in Financial sector, change is slow and adoption of new processes takes time. with over 250K employees, finding ones own self is a challenge.

pros: Good benefits, pretty stable atmosphere
cons: Pay stagnant, unfilled promises of advancement, after awhile, it's difficult to advance. Management changes so often, there's a new "game plan" every 6mos-1yr and new mgmt comes in before you can get your promotion. After 4yrs with almost same pay and ever changing direction, everyone ends up burnt out, even the good ones. Eventually all talent leaves, tired of not being compensated or appreciated. It's sad and frustrating

job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Buford, GA
pros: Easy to be promoted from within. Good benefits and I received a great salary. Enjoyed my co workers.
cons: You feel pressured to sell products to customers that don't need them. Impossible goals for tellers and personal bankers. Lots of managers are not qualified for the position. They get it because they have a degree but know nothing about running a bank.

pros: Good salary/decent commission payout, good benefits, 401k match 5%
cons: Micro management,  constant performance focused sales meetings (phone, in-person, etc.) Commissions are upfront, performance-based, paid quarterly. Clients aren't yours, shared with all other Merrill Edge FSA's. Prospects with over $250,000 to be referred to Merrill Lynch. No assistant. Also have to do sales as a Bank of America Banker (checking, credit cards). Mandatory outbound calls made weekly recorded and graded by compliance. Quarterly payouts can be reduced by as much as 30% for compliance penalties.

pros: Free Advantage Checking and Savings Money Market Account. Free checks. Nothing else. Nothing positive about this place.
cons: Horrible pay as a Teller. Tellers are forced to push customers to open accounts that they didn't need. They exceed levels of micromanagement. Tellers work hard without incentives for the Personal Bankers. Bank of America is the worst Bank to work for and to bank with. My manager had anxiety issues because of this place. The day I left this place it was one of the happiest days of my life. I care for people. Don't work for this bank if you really care about yourself. It is 1000x better to clean toilets in busy bar than working for this place.

job_title: Associate, Sales and Trading in New York, NY
pros: Good Salary, Exposure to very interesting career opportunities, Work with some of the brightest minds in the industry, Competitive, Intense but good work life balance, Constant communication globally, Great building to work in, Easy commute from all areas of Manhattan.
cons: Poor Senior Management, Lack of goal orientation, blurred reporting lines and poor leader ship. Teams are not well selected and do not often seem to work well together. Management spends little time mentoring and developing junior talent.

review_title: Lots of opportunities, hierarchical, you need to manage up
pros: I had tremendous flexibility in my job; final manager was very supportive (as in "Why are you bothering me asking if you can order a new server; if you need it, order it.")
cons: Because BofA is so large, it is important to meet and learn about your manager and his/her peers and his supervisor.  Always manager expectations up.  Not as easy as in a small company.  I was in Portland; my last 3 managers were in San Francisco.

job_title: Relationship Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Can quickly move up the corporate ladder without much politics, upper management actually does want to see you succeed and will provide guidance to get you there, whether it's changing to a different career move within Bank of America, or moving up to management. Peers are great to work with, easy build close relationships with peers and management. If in sales, unlimited money making potential.
cons: Aggressive sales quotas and goals, lots of redundant duties on the operational & sales side.

review_title: Easily the best job I've ever had
job_title: Project Analyst/Project Manager Operations in Lancaster, CA
pros: Great pay, great team, freedom to do what works in order to produce results on the back end.  I genuinely enjoyed the work I did, and the people I did it with.
cons: BofA's countrywide acquisitions led to a lot of layoffs in their call centers, my own included.  Keep wary of your workplace and how long it's been under BofA.

pros:
Good 401k plan: 5% match
Good vacation plan
Flexible work space with telecommute
Mature Sr Leaders with strong ethics
Good Health benefits
cons:
No promotion opportunities, must leave the company and return in new role if hope to get promoted
Change for changes sake. No value behind the change besides the new Exec trying to make a mark. It gives us all whiplash with constant Exec changes
Promote Diversity but employees know it's only to check a box to make it on the "100 Top Diverse co's" for free advertisement. If all of your low paying, part time positions are filled by minorities and your Sr Leader positions are filled by one group..you are NOT diverse.

pros: I think that the salary was good for a first-time Teller with no previous experience.  The ongoing Teller training was outstanding and kept us abreast of current banking laws + regulations.
cons: At times, there were not enough Tellers scheduled and customers would complain. It was hard to move up to other positions.....if you were very quick at your job, you remained as a Teller. If you were well-connected to Management, you had a better chance at being promoted.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Financial Solutions Advisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great People, great benefits, access to learn new information and training

review_title: A great company that needs clearer direction.
job_title: Financial Center Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
-Great benefits, 4 weeks vacations for managers, $5,250/year tuition reimbursement for undergrad, great insurance with lower costs for employees making less than $100k, 401k matching, the list goes on
-Early closing times, most branches are 9-4 Monday-Thursday 
-The company has many avenues to provide feedback and suggestions for improvement
-Best mobile and online apps in the industry
-Bonuses for managers are set up so that if Operations was good, you can still make bonus even if you were short on revenue goals and vice versa 
-Up to date client management software and HR software giving you the ability to add those programs to your resume as most other companies use the same software
-Learning and networking events are very cool, free access to tons of articles, books and videos online and live to desktop training sessions as well as employee networks that meet in person and over the phone 
-The value of the bank’s products make it easy to recommend valuable solutions to clients 
-Very well structured policies and procedures, and a policy to “stand by” a manager that made a decision that made sense and was well documented, even if it results in a loss to the bank.
cons:
-Reporting structure of the branches, bankers report to a market leader instead of the branch manager, but branch managers are held highly accountable for their results. Branch managers do not have the ability to perform disciplinary action for these associates, meaning behavioral issues could go unaddressed.   
-Hours are nice, but staffing is tight so if you lose a person or someone goes on vacation it makes it very difficult to run the branch 
-Hiring/training process takes forever so if someone quits or gets promoted you might not have a replacement for 6 months
-Moving from the branch into other lines of business is difficult, there isn’t a lot of interaction between departments and in most cities there aren’t other departments besides branches at all so advancement past branch manager is difficult. 
-Internal audit can be punitive, many months of work is looked through but scoring policy only allows for 3-4 errors to pass, and not passing means additional action planning, potential disciplinary action, and your reputation as a leader becomes damaged. 
-The banking products are quality but some fees are hard to justify to clients. 
-Currently not a great sales process, there should be more structure available for newer sales associates with limited experience. The bank almost seems undecided on how they’d like you to speak with clients, with many local market leaders creating their own processes to help. 
-Not a great reaction to the Wells Fargo scandal, the culture still places a lot of pressure on meeting goals or completing tasks like outbound calling without a lot of resources to help train associates on how to effectively perform.  
-Company culture needs work, the bank has been responding to so much over-regulation and I think they’ve lost sight of what sets Bank of America apart, and in my opinion that is the innovative training and education of the associates. There used to be a lot more pride in taking ownership of situations, solving problems in creative ways, and having strong team atmosphere. Lately it seems there is less focus on teamwork and helping everyone to be the best, and too much focus on competition and meeting metrics.

Poorly bad treatment from those “above you.” You’re just a number to the company, a lot of brainwashing, gossiping, Bad training, horrible customers. They have high sales goals for CSRs but do not provide any commission. Everyone else gets commission except CSRs! Horrible environment! Managers are never in the branch, they always finds way to do half days or not come in at all. They also disappear and take almost 2-3hr lunch breaks. EXTREMELY HIGH TURNOVER! Worst decision I have ever made.

review_title: Bank of America- Not as bad a workplace as some people perceive...
pros:
-You are rewarded through hard work.(Those complaining are simply not applying themselves or perhaps on the manager's bad side....)
-Somewhat competitive salary depending which region/market you work in. 
- GREAT benefits. 401k matching, pension, tuition/child care/commuting reimbursements, Health care insurance(Vision/Medical/Dental) and also provided with a expense card with $600/yearly, more when insuring family members/spouses. Lets not forgot a quarterly bonus(which mostly depends on referrals/sales)
-You have the opportunity for career and personal growth; it depends just how much you plan on applying yourself. As for personal, you get to meet and work with some great people. 
-Every work day is different... and quite interesting despite what most people might think.
cons:
-Salary not as competitive compared to other financial institutions yet; I personally believe the benefits provided by BOA provide a generous overall package. On a side note, the quarterly bonuses could also use some work- especially towards top performers.
-Sales goals tend to be quite unrealistic, especially in the current economic situation, but through the BOA spirit... we try to get the job done and be as successful as we can. 
-There can be some difficulty in career advancement while working for BOA.

pros:
Management sets goals and allows employees flexibility to meet them
Room for internal advancement
High quality employees - those few bad hires are gently terminated in due time
cons: lines of authority can be fuzzy. this is because the work is so IT intensive that one could have a few superiors to report to or to work for - sort of a matrix organization due to the type of work

review_title: Senior Operations Project Analyst at BAC
pros: Several departments to which you can transfer.  Relaxed environment.  Casual dress on Fridays.  Open to adhering to schedule requests.  Colleagues good source of information and collaboration.
cons: Management does not know how to manage and seemingly keep "secrets" from the employees in what looks like incompetence.  The people who get promoted to not deserve it, while at the same time the people who work extremely hard basically go unnoticed despite praise received from managers who work in other departments.

pros: Benefits are hit or miss. Some good, some not so good for the amount you have to pay. The hope of progression
cons: They sell you the dream of aspiration and career growth but it seems to be more situational and luck of the draw. I have ALWAYS been an exceeds exceeds employee and have soooo many "cute" lil awards etc but barely any increase in compensation in nearly 3 years. I mean they would rather recognize me globally vs. increasing my pay, responsibilities etc.

job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: Lots of challenging work, ineresting places, for interesting clients.  Managers are competent, they have a very resonable review process and bonuses are easy to get.
cons: Too Much Travel, disconnected from the team, Clients sometimes unreasonable.  We do not always know what we are selling and the products change all the time.

job_title: Teller and Personal Banker in Irvine, CA
pros:
I'd say Bank of America is a good place to work if and only if you are a college student. Schedule is flexible as long as you give them notice before hand. Required to work saturdays if you are part time. 2 weeks paid vacation is a plus.

Salary is competitive. I started from $10 and was raised to $14 in one years time. Key is to meet quarterly goals and you have to DEMAND for it. I was about to leave for another bank but they raised my pay so i stayed. If you do good they'll do a lot of things in your favor.

Benefits are excellent. Covers dental, health, insurance. Again I stress it is only a good job if you are a student. Bank of America pays $5200 a year for tuition reimbursement. You just have to be working at "meets expectations" and manager will approve it without second thoughts. 

Wear your own suit to work is a plus. I know Chase has those ugly blue shirts and I sympathize with them.
cons:
Sales sales sales. If you are not good at sales you will suffer. Managers breathe down your neck every second. Mark my words. Expect to do a lot of sales in this position. This is not a position to be if you are uncomfortable with sales. I've seen 2 employees getting fired in 1 month for not meeting their monthly goal. Some managers will have you stay on Saturday afternoons to do cold calling to meet your goals. 

Stupid guidelines: no water at desk. C'mon, I'm a teller, I speak to 30 customers per hour. I need my water. 

Career advancement is tiny. If you are looking to break into the finance industry, this is not the job. Once you are in retail banking, you are stuck here. A lot of people have the concept that as long as I perform well being a personal banker, I can get licensed and become a financial advisor. WRONG. If you do something great you'll be doing it FOREVER. After being stuck at the PB job for 5 years, I quit and got hired at UBS as a financial advisor. They even asked me why I was still a PB with all the credentials on my resume.

pros:
Good growth potential under the right leadership. 
Benefits – Healthcare, tuition reimbursement, childcare, adoption reimbursement as well as many other options for families. 
Affinity groups designed to connect networks of Bank of America Associates together.
cons: Work-life balance could be a little better in certain “high-volume” areas.

review_title: I was ready to leave when I left.
pros: job security if basically the main or best reason , however, that was the case up until the year of 2008.. After the year of 2008, job security has not been available for most of Americans, especially persons within the financial industry..
cons: The was a high turn around with in my department. The customer service department, in my opinion, is not the best place to start out at because it feels as though you're a slave.

review_title: The experience has been an okay one. Too be honest it feels more like a rollercoaster.
pros: The benefits and culture I really enjoy having at the bank. The vacation time is also another great benefit at the bank.
cons: There is no room for advancement. Management wants you to speak your mind but they do not care to listen when you have concerns.

review_title: So many other choices to originate home loans for.

cons: Brand name is tarnished, extremely difficult to get files approved, underwriting guidelines are way too tight compared to EVERY other lending institution, processes and file flow are not logical.

review_title: Nice place to work. It could be better.
job_title: Instructor I; Language Specialist in San Jose, San Jose

review_title: Bank of America Atmosphere and Culture
job_title: Loan Services Specialist in Chandler, AZ

The only problem with the company is that you will be underpaid compared to all the other major banks out there. The benefits are above average and the vacation time is great compared to most. The culture is becoming more employee focused, with new facility upgrades and more numerous employee events.
cons:
Slow career progression. Can be very unsatisfying if you are working on one of the "forgotten" products with very few customers.
A few managers do not seem to care about their reports. Thankfully there are less of these as time goes by. Compensation can be very inconsistent.

pros:
Great people, who have adapted to change - 

Pay well for easy jobs
cons:
The job has became impersonal. Culture changed from being service centered to being productivity centered (Metrics-Based) where we are viewed more as a number as an individual -

Contractors are considered dirt by management - Micromanagement at this company is awful, and there are frequent layoffs and reorganizations. 

Most recent reorg consists of forcing employees to careers they arent interested in - " MY WAY OR THE HIGHWAY mentality " 

Favouritism / Brown nosing / YES MAN philosopy

cons: Vacation time was a pain to get approved, most managers were more concerned with deadines than workers.  Morale was low because managers did not interact well with underlings.  Promotions were for people who were good individual contributors rather than good team players.  Survival of the fittest was managements strategy.  If a manager doesn't like you, they will make your days miserable.

job_title: Vice President PMO Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: a Nationwide presences, all different types of jobs all of the world. A lot of variety, and can specialize in key areas of finance where skills are transferable to other inudstries

review_title: Its an ok job if you like to badger people!

sales are pushed beyond comfort

review_title: Less Learning , Less work, High bureaucracy
job_title: Vice President; Tech Manager in Calabasas, CA
pros:
If you are mom and want to work from home with less stress
If you want a stable job with less money
cons: No learning as there is tent mentality going on between various teams who don't share knowledge or trust. Business people make decisions for technical teams and tech teams obey them as the word of law.

review_title: Overall, been a great, rewarding experience in the 2 1/2 plus years I've worked here.
pros: Strong encouragement to move up within company though hard to find roles outside of banking center. Definitely look to hire within first which is good as I've been able to move up twice so far. Really great benefits overall and especially on medical side.
cons: Compensation, though that is getting better. I'd still say need to increase initial pay for most branch employees. Typical political things you must deal with, but should be expected going in.

pros: Benefits are great and working for a huge company that it is, you can easily transfer onto another position or move high up.
cons: The internal problems are never ending... The environment is somewhat okay, but it can be hectic. Higher up managers, managers period in the Home Loans department don't know what the heck is going on, but expect you do. You are encouraged to voice your opinion and any issues you bring up are sent to a point of no return.

pros: Outstanding benefits, the health insurance packages were incredible. The company has a great understanding for personal emergencies - I had taken maternity leave (12 weeks paid), and soon after returning to work my husband was in a major accident and on life support. BoA has an employee family benefit where they will hold your position in qualifying medical emergencies such as this, although unpaid (since my fmla had been used for the year). I'm grateful to have had such an understanding company and management team as a support in such a scary time.
cons: Lack of career growth opportunity, feeling like a spec in a crowd.

review_title: You'll love this job, if you are only looking for a paycheck!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great team to work with.  Dependable hours and paycheck.
cons: Procedures change at the drop of the hat.  Not enough time to research problems or provide customers with quality resolutions.  Sure to burn out quickly.  Lower pay scale.

review_title: Great place to work if you can live with employment uncertainty.
pros: Competitive pay and good benefits including health insurance, pension, paid time off, charitable contributions matching program.
cons: Uncertain employment environment in which the company has frequent reorgs (avg of 1/yr in my space) with no apparent employer to employee commitment, regardless of the employees ability and commitment.

review_title: Bank of America has some really intelligent people.
pros: I have found that Bank of America has some of the best people that I have ever worked with.  They also have some of the best hardware for running their systems.
cons: They recently lost a number of their high-ranking employees to attrition.  This is causing some uncertain around where the technology team is headed.

pros: Excellent assignments and leadership.  Great opportunity to enhance career and learn about the industry.
cons: Program was going through a lot of change making it hard to know what you'd be asked to do next and even harder to see how it would fit into a career path.

job_title: Senior Infrastructure Engineer in Charlotte, NC

Very knowledgeable teammates

Layoffs and involuntary reorgs - no job security 
Senior management creates undeliverable technical designs where they have no expertise without consulting SMEs then dole out punishment when you can't deliver 
No work life balance - you will be called when you're on vacation, at a funeral, etc

pros: Able to move up pretty fast in consumer banking as long as you're aggressive and vocal about where you want your career to be. Automatically get holidays off so that is always a plus.
cons: Reduction on teller line before upgrading ATMs creates a very busy environment, sometimes it can be quite hectic if we are short staffed. Sales goals are much harder to achieve depending staffing issues. Pay is not that great.

job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Tampa, FL
pros: They have great health and employee benefits.
cons: Sales goals are made now unreachable. Before this year, sales goals were attainable. I had some great commission payouts. I had eight years of payouts. This year they made the goals so unattainable that it made it difficult to work for them anymore. My health started to be affected because of the pressure.

pros:
Great starting pay
Great benefits being a part time employee
cons: There was no training program in place. I spent 2 weeks on the computer doing modules and reading over laws. I would spent 8 hrs in front of a computer and it sucked. After the two weeks I spent a week watching someone and then I was on my own. Even my manager at the time stated that I was thrown to the wolves. It made the job difficult being that we were a very busy branch. WAYYYY understaffed as well. Everyone was looking for a way out.

pros: 1) Latest Tech - invested heavily in new technology.  Ex: our team was devoted to DevOps and private Cloud before either was a "thing".  2) Governance - finally, software development that avoided the "hodge podge" and sprawl problems by actually abiding by good SDLC practices! (standardized programming libraries & repos, Service Catalog of standardized technologies, Change Control processes in-place).  3) Good training resources - digital library including O'Reilly; sponsored tech classes.  4) Top notch benefits - 3-6mons of paternal leave!? yes, that's paternal not just maternal; that's an example of top notch (others being: Bank holidays of course, so MUCH vacation, excellent retirement investing resources, discounted auto and mortgage loans, recognizing domestic partnerships, etc. ... the benefits list goes on and on so there are Bank "Lifers")
cons: Typical corporate politiking ... examples: 1) The March to Madness - every March (and most Septembers) was the march to layoffs.  2) Bucket/ranked performance review system - you get put into buckets; managers must rank their direct reports, and 10-15% of employees _had_ to be in the "bottom bucket", aka. on the list to be purged in the March to Madness.  3) Advocate Managers - you MUST have a manager who advocates on your behalf in the purging meetings (I was laid off after an excellent advocate manager left the team), or be cunning and network your way into another team to "reset" your ranking (I heard the Bank clamped down on internal mobility). 4) Non-banking hours - Banking hours?!  HAH!  Maybe at the Branches but not for core Bank divisions (investing, fraud, operations, etc.); many of us worked any hour of any day.

pros: BofA, specifically the GT&O (Global Technology & Operations) division has been the most rewarding, challenging, interesting and personal growth driven roles I've had in my 20 year career.  Technology is always at the ready, we never have to want for any tools or resources to successfully execute our job, and we always have the necessary support from our direct management, as well as executive management.  We're able to execute our role in a virtual/remote environment which allows us to spend more time on working and less time in a car/bus/train/plane, etc.
cons:
A few of the downsides of the role and employer is the governmental regulations and reporting that we are required to execute.  This is true of any employer, especially one the size of BofA, however, as a financial institution, we are under significantly increased scrutiny, while other companies and organizations which are significantly inferior to the goods and services which we provide.  

Another con of working in such a large environment and organization is that we can't simply hire the most qualified individual to fill a role; we have to meet specific hires and numbers of employees under certain classes of people which encompass: race, sex, abilities, etc.  Simply put, the government interferes with our production significantly with their ridiculous regulations to ensure that a specific class or group of people aren't overlooked, even when these individuals are nowhere near the most qualified candidate to fill a position.

pros: Fairly simple job. Lots to learn but if you can learn quick then this job is good for you to do.

pros: I don't have any pros about this organization.

review_title: Processed mortgage loan repurchases and analyzed the overall process for efficiency.

cons: Seriously lacks teams communication. No one talks to anyone, even if they're literally right in the next cubicle. They'd rather write you a long email to explain the simplest thing.

review_title: A place for a job, not a career
job_title: Litigation Intake in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The work was easy and mindless.  I could listen to music while doing my job and never really struggle.
cons: You'd think with a large company like that, there would be stability but most people at the time were worried about keeping his/her job.  The culture is not transparent and I found most departments/individuals blaming each other for any mistakes along the way.  It's everything you'd expect from a "big bank" - not a career destination.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Boston, MA
pros: The pay is decent and there are a good amount of benefits, including account perks.
cons: Bankers hours don't actually exist, some of us worked 6 days a week, 11 hour days. The company culture is terrible. They do not care about their people at all. The managers do not know how to coach or motivate a team they simply re-iterate what the goals are, as if you didn't know.

review_title: The FSA role is an "island". You will be forgotten.
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent opportunity to serve risk-averse clients who need it most. Brand/name recognition. Good benefits, decent pay (although you are not paid enough to justify the cons).
cons: You are at the mercy of your banking branch team. Unethical business/sales practices and high competition from the bank side (compensation always overrules client's interest since bank has extreme performance goals) will force you to endure the most horrific working conditions such as: pushing bank products, micromanagement, unprofessional working environment, challenging for compensation, begging for referrals from banking team (FSA is competition to the bankers), mismanagement/high turnover, lack of leadership/communication, etc. The business model simply does not work and you will soon enough be holding up the SOS sign.

job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Bluffton, SC
pros: great benefits and awesome co-workers
cons: Serious lack of communication from regional management, unrealistic sales goals, false promises

pros: Great managers at the lower levels.  Every team I was on over a 10 year period was great to work with, no matter what the size.  Project managers who were brought in as contractors got lots of help and cooperation from permanent employees.
cons: Groups can be changed, added, reformed without warning and without input from the person whose job is being changed. I was once moved into an operations position (I had no experience in Ops) after I had been in development for several years, and I had been up for a promotion as a developer, so I was pretty bitter about that.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Utica, NY

cons: jobs and disciplinary actions are threatened over human error by some of management as a way of coaching.  There needs to be more training throughout the year, often times you're walked through a 20 minute power point and expected to know everything pertaining to the new changes.

pros: If you work hard the rewards are there for you, great education that is easy to learn
cons: There is an attitude  if your face fits you will get on, and there is a lot of backstabbing going on in certain departments, some people causing trouble for others trying to get them into trouble

review_title: Great Benefits, about the only great thing
job_title: Home Loan Consultant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Benefits are some of the best around. Inexpensive health insurance, lots of life insurance options, tuition reimbursement, 16 weeks paid maternity and paternity leave.  Employer 401k match
cons: Too many metrics, reports, too many data crunchers micromanaging everything.  Constant changes yet cannot keep up with fast and ever changing mortgage industry.  Nearly impossible to close a loan on time, the fulfillment partners would rather decline and cancel loans than fund them. Still very much us vs them mentality in fulfillment versus sales.

review_title: Great job for a college student
job_title: Bank Teller in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wonderful place to work if you're a college student. The manager really respects me as an employee and I feel happy coming to work each time. My teammates are all wonderful people and it feels like a small family. Maybe after finishing my degree I can work in another position within this company.
cons: Only con of this company is that I wish I got paid more for my position. Tellers are responsible for a lot of important things and we are worth more than $16/hr.

pros: First off if you don’t need much to be decent at this job, as long as your good with people and sales you’ll be fine. Great benefits and great salary when you have the right team in the right market and the right managers it’s amazing and makes the work life balance worth it (rare though). You get your own office and a fancy plaque that makes you feel good. The company strategy that they put out is smart, more focus on financial planning instead of monotonous servicing. They are in the business of helping our clients.
cons: theres always 2 sides to a story, while they preach and push forward all these great things they need to purge all of these issues that keep customers away from us Now let me tell you, I’ve worked in multiple locations in multiple states. And unless you have extreme patience just use this job as a means to an end so you can work at a better one. There is a HUGE divide both in clients and in associates alone where people are stuck in there old ways. It leads to a lot of disconnect and miscommunication between associates especially management. They set too many metrics you have to hit. I have to worry about making sure every single aspect of Bank of America is over 100% to goal. I understand I must meet the metrics but I think we forget we are human and Erica hasn’t taken over yet so don’t act as if my job is on the line when I’m 135% in everything else BUT OH NO I DIDN’T HAVE ENOUGH MERCHANT REFERRALS. Another thing that frustrates me is when you do try and put in the effort and struggle every single time to hit everything and even though the location your at doesn’t have the clientele for that business aspect of Bank of America it can limit you to try and get promoted or a raise. Another thing is time, you can get fired if you mistype your time which makes sense but when a HUGE amount of your employees are getting flagged and written up for time tracking (especially your high performing ones) DONT  YOU THINK ITS TIME TO SIT DOWN WITH WORKDAY AND GO OVER YOUR BUSINESS  AGREEMENT WITH THEM? I don’t get it, this company is a double standard and won’t even pay us good bonuses, I worked so hard to reach the top 2 tiers and I felt like I got paid half than what I put in

review_title: Best company I’ve worked for so far
pros: Work life balance, pay, benefits, very organized company, PTO and vacation from the start, opportunities for advancement aren’t all vertical and are truly endless, global company, always working to improve their policies, great training program, really seems to strive to be the best.
cons: In the end, BoA is still a massive corporation. Sometimes you feel very minor in the grand scheme of things and sometimes it can feel a bit robotic, but they try their best to make it not feel that way and you can really tell.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Ann Arbor, MI

cons: You are told what to say to customers. You are graded on your predetermined behaviors and not your performance. Upper management is very far disconnected from daily activities and extremely incompetent. If you like to be micro managed via email, this is the perfect job for you.

review_title: Awful Company - Horrible from an employee and customer perspective

review_title: Horrible Place -- I wasted My Time

review_title: IT has been good place to learn about the financial services industry but need to move on to advance your career.

review_title: Great company to work for, many different levels of management can be a little challenging to get things done.
pros: great benefits!!!!  there is a lot of different departments so you can have many different career paths, as long as you can find a friend to get your foot in the door.

review_title: I enjoy the diversity and opportunity at the bank.
pros: As compared to other companies,the health and vacation benefits are good. Plus there is opportunity to work from home in many departments.
cons: You can be a bit of a number with so many employees that it is hard for upper management to know the importance and contribution of some jobs.

pros: Benefits - Good health care coverage at a reasonable price, tuition reimbursement (if you can get approval to attend classes and it's related to the banking business), assistance for child care costs, minimum 80 hours vaca and 80 sick time (2 days can be used as personal time).
cons:
Little room to advance - most moves are lateral. When hired I was told they were looking for a small % of college grads to fill this job to possibly move into management in approx. 6 months. It's been two years and not one of the college grads in the department has been considered for advancement, only lateral moves to other "phone" jobs. 

Management is not knowledgeable about the departments they manage and managers are switched out constantly. Most managers in my department have never worked the job, therefore they are unable to provide support when needed. They seem to be there only to ensure you are adhering to your schedule and enforce policies. I have had 5 managers in 2 years. By time one catches up with my reviews they get replaced by someone else. 

In the case of phone based jobs - you are literally tied to a desk. You may not leave the phone without manager approval or scheduled times (which may be up to 4 hours apart). No off-phone time to review email communications (policy changes, etc.), so it can be difficult to keep abreast of important information. Nearly zero interaction with anyone face-to-face. No flexibility in scheduling and most schedules are late morning to evening and included weekend days, meaning it's nearly impossible to further education. Incentive is paid for above expectations performers, but failure to reach incentive goals results in reprimand. Those who perform as 'average" should be coached and encouraged rather than punished by poor reviews. Those who don't excel in all areas aren't recognized for their hard work.

Sick time computation (which may vary by department) is complicated and difficult to adhere to. You are given 80 hours per year sick time, but each absence is an "occurrence". Occurrences are computing on a 12 month rolling calendar and at your 5th occurrence you are on "warning", therefore you can have plenty of hours of sick time available this year, but be unable to use it without reprimand because of an absence last year. For people with kids or who had a period of medical issue in the past, this can lead to a perpetual cycle of being reprimanded for each absence (up to threat of termination), even when those absences are few and far between at that point. 

Stress levels are high, incredibly so considering the job is phone based. The problem is not the customers (they can be rather frustrating, but not the primary source of stress). The stress comes from all the things listed above. Between the crazy sick-time policy and the stress, half of my dozen person team is currently on med leave. This seems to be an issue department wide, so either the bank is hiring nothing but sickly people, or they need to examine their environment.

job_title: Preferred Centralized Sales in East Providence, RI
pros: Lot's of opportunity to learn the products available with the strong training team, great benefits when it comes to needing time off. Management willing to help out where they can.
cons:
I was given false information about the pay from recruiters, HR, as well as training members. It wasn't until got on the calls (call center position) where I actually was able to realize the actually details about the position. In a nutshell, you work 8 hours, you get a 30 minute break and 2 15 minute breaks. You are allowed 0 minute to yourself. You're expected to take non stop calls unless its your break (if you need to go to the bathroom it takes out of your 15 minute breaks) You are 100% watched at all times you're expected to take as many calls as possible while selling to clients. I went into the Position with the idea it was a sales position, thats not accurate. Its a servicing position you get clients who call to check their balance, you will very rarely get a call from someone actually looking to sign up for something. I was told "top earners are receiving over 10k a quarter with the new incentive program" which was a total lie, the top person in the country received a 10k incentive check. If you're doing well they change your calls with he flip of a switch so its hard for you to succeed, they're nazis when it comes to paying the incentive out (any time you fail quality or have poor client surveys you risk the ability to even getting that incentive check you worked so hard for) and just a heads up, in order to get 10k in a quarter you need to get the bank $100,000 in profit (credit cards and checking accounts pay the highest towards that in they're valued at $250 each).

I don't want to seem like I'm doing nothing but bashing this company, I wasn't a low performer either nor was I ever at risk of losing my incentive due to failure of quality or surveys, I just want the truth out there, if i was given the truth from the beginning of the process I never would have left my previous employer. I understand a tight ship needs to be ran but this is something like I never seen heard or witnessed before, I went in with the expectations I could make 80k+ a year when realistically you're a top performer if you're making over 60k.

cons: The Bank is slowly laying people off.  You never know when you're number is up, and most employees are on pins and needles.  Also, as the Bank has been cutting positions, the ability to move up is just about non-existent.  You are trapped in your position.  Pay is meh.

job_title: A V P Financial Solutions Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Great parental leave, good vacation time if you can managed to take it, good base for the role, decent incentive.
cons: Unfortunately,this organization a very slow, dysfunctional operational infrastructure. Employees / customers often wait min. of 30 min on hold for even minor account service. The computer systems are antiquated, pieced together from dozens of acquisitions, confusing, and whats worse they do random updates without notice so when you go in the next day to service a client you stumble through a new process you have never seen before. If you're a cross functional employee you have a minimum of 15 applications open at all times on the computer just to do your everyday tasks. If you call another department they treat you like a 3rd party. You have no power to own service issues which are frequent. Computers go down alot,  once mine went completely and I was unable to work for several days. They outsource their IT so even though I was assured I'd be up and running in 5 days it took 7. I was paid to sit around which was not good for me nor my clients. Even worse duplicate orders of equipment is another issue where associates are often left with the responsibility of returning excess items. There is an abundance of waste at BOA. I truly feel for clients and associates that are dealing with this company. The client facing employees do their best but the infustructure issues are so bad they are worn down with client complaints all the time. If I had to describe this company I would call it a really big, really old ship with a leaky hull that will eventually sink. I do not recommend unless you enjoy suffocating in a web of bureaucratic red tape. There are better options out there in the super regional space.

review_title: Great company, takes care of employees and clients

cons: Would be nice to have more computers to do work with. Everyone has work to do, but not everyone has access to a computer to do the work.

pros: Good benefits, pay, empower their employees, located across the country, lots of opportunity for job growth.

They are willing to take business risks by letting go established educated employees, to hire new (cheaper) employees in a centralized location with the believe that 20+ years of experience can be taught in 6 weeks...guess what it can't!
