job_title: Preferred Sales Specialist in Brunswick, ME
pros: 3-4 Weeks Vacation time, good benefits, and a decent bonus if you put in a lot of work, many different departments to transfer to / work for
cons:
You are closely watched to anytime you are not allowed on your phone. You are allowed 8 minutes a day (outside of a lunch break and two 15 minute breaks) to not be logged into your phone. Yes, this includes bathroom breaks. You are allowed an average of 30 seconds after the call to do your paperwork. You will be talked to if you go above it.
Your sales goals are large and forever changing to what the bank needs. None of the managers or coaches have actually sold 95% of the products so they are clueless as to what needs to be done to achieve said goals. They will ask you why you are not hitting the goals and what you plan to do to hit them.
They dock your bonus on a number of different ways.
They try to micromanage your vacation time by making it unavailable if the bank is behind in goals. Then they blame the associates for taking sick time/vacation time (that they gave you to use) as the reason for not hitting goals. When this happens, expect them to push overtime. Overtime can't be mandatory, so they phrase it like "What is your commitment for overtime this month?" - then keep pushing and asking you even if you say you have no availability. If you don't do overtime when they ask, they act like the bank will never do a favor for you in the future to "flex time" (work another day instead of the scheduled one) if one comes up.
They will have you drive into work when there is 2 feet of snow. (not kidding) Then they pretend like they are doing you a favor by offering you to flex for another day in concern for your safety. Again, if you are on a set schedule this does not work (especially for those with kids)
There are a ton of different level positions and levels to work in with Bank of America. However, they do not always post all of the available jobs and getting transferred to another department is next to impossible. If you want to move up from your current position you need to : be top in sales and quality, never object to anything a manager or higher says, never go to the bathroom, drink the kool aid and be a brown noser.
There is a lot of discrimination, ageism, sexism, among other things that gets swept under the rug in the workplace.
Oh, and if you hit your sales goal, or crush your sales goal - don't expect a thank you. Expect a higher goal next month.
You need to follow a billion different regulations to sell something, reading a book to a customer per product, and if you miss one word you lost your bonus.

review_title: Bank of America is becoming the Bank of India
pros: Pay is good, vacation is good, ability to work from home if ok with your management
cons: too many people from India in Technology, they have contracts with TCS and Perot which all hire India consultants which BAC thinks saves them money, too many managers and red tape, the managers all switch after 1-2 years so you get new one.  The upper managers put procedures in place that don't make much sense.

review_title: It's all in who you work for.....
pros: The best reason to work at Bank of America would definitely be to get the name on your resume and hopefully to make some good money. In this environment, banking jobs are hard to come by so a good opportunity with the company wouldn't be a bad career move. I personally think that your experience at the bank, due to its large size, will be VERY dependent on what city you live in, what division you work in, and who your manager is. Some managers are highly incompetent, and poor motivators, others are great motivators, great leaders, and inspire you to work hard. So when you interview, assess your manager very well.
cons: The downside of working at Bank of America would definitely be that the size of the Company means some groups are mch better to work in than others, meaning your experience could be a crap shoot. In this environment, banking jobs are hard to come by, and there is a lot of stress and worry about being downsized, so a safer industry may be more appealing right now. If you go, try to negotiate severance up front. I can't stress how much your experience at the bank will be VERY dependent on what city you live in, what division you work in, and who your manager is. Some managers are highly incompetent, and poor motivators, others are great motivators, great leaders, and inspire you to work hard. So when you interview, assess your manager very well.

review_title: OK, but work/life balance can depend solely on your manager
pros:
Good benefits - although insurance is expensive and even the top line plan still leaves a lot of out-of-pocket costs.
Internal training website allows you to basically get an MBA, if you have time for it. They recently rolled out more technical training, which is good.
MyWork (work-from-home program) is excellent opportunity.
cons:
You can get "stuck". Hard to meet people/mentors outside of your division.
Salary very low compared to other companies. Raises are almost a no-no discussion.
Work/life balance depends solely on manager - some will push you into the ground with getting their projects done, changing their minds, and making you redo work. Others are very concious of hours worked and push you the door at 40, for your own sanity. That is a really bummer because it can be quite a shock to go from one expectation to another, especially when your role is switched due to senior management shuffling.
Constant reshuffling of the same people into slightly different roles, that really end up being the same. If it has been 6 months and I haven't been assigned a new boss or role, I am shocked. No senior manager (except the CEO and his direct reports) seem to stay in place long enough for anything to actually change. I am all for change, but this just gets ridiculous.
Constant layoff worry - as with any company.

review_title: Tough to get promoted in Operations Technology
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
- lots of change taking place so there are opportunities for interesting projects
- flexibility to work from home when necessary
- generally hardworking people
- try to show employee appreciation (though sometimes comes off as forced)
cons:
- As a former Merrill Lynch employee, I was disappointed to see that Bank of America has even LESS of a tuition reimbursement program. While ML covered $8k per calendar year, BAC covers just over $5k. Given an MBA program at a top school can run you at least $80k (mine is $120k) this is hardly putting a dent in my payments.
- HR policy of "you need to be in your position for at least 2 years before eligible for a promotion" really stifles young employees growth. Unless you have a manager really willing to fight for you, if you would like to fast track your career, there is little opportunity to do so. My first year out of college I was given the speech that I had to wait another year for promotion due to HR policy- eventhough I was deemed "ready"- this was for my promotion from Senior Specialist to AVP. Next time around I did get AVP, and a year later I was doing the job of an incompetent VP who was on his way out the door. Instead of promoting me, I was again told "we tried, but you need to be in your slot for 2 years." This was ultimately when I decided to move, as I realized I could get twice as far in another company much sooner.
- It is also worth mentioning that most people in the department have been there 15-25 years so little value is placed on fresh, young, new opinions.

review_title: So far just average but the potential is there
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Chandler, AZ
pros:
I've provided very valuable advice to clients many times over and made a true difference in their lives.  At Merrill Edge you are given the ability to provide pure portfolio management and leverage the company's research department to give mass affluent client's solid financial solutions.  There is not another place in the retail world where client's with less than $250k can find financial advice and pure portfolio management in such a cost effective manner.

The office is in a nice area and is in the opposite direction of most rush hour traffic.

The sales training is very good.

It's a good place to develop and polish sales skills, presentation skills, and communication skills.

You will have a chance to learn a great deal about the markets, advisory services, and the financial services industry.  You have full access to BoA/ML research as well as mutual fund company knowledge and resources (from the wholesalers).

The site manager makes it a point to walk around and talk to entry level advisers.  I'm not sure what the prior reviewer was talking about.  

If sales and financial services is not your thing, but you still have a good attitude, they will make an effort to help you find another position on the service side.

Is see so much potential at this place for efficiency improvement, client experience improvement, associate sat improvement.  This is a pro and a con.  

That being said, the focus by management seems to be all over the place and I think there are a lot of growing pains right now as well as merger pains resulting from the BoA/ML merger.  It's also a large corporation so there are a lot of moving parts.


The platform is awesome and is such a great value to client's with under $250k and even clients with over $250k.
cons:
The base salary is not competitive in Core 1 versus salaries at other firms or in similar jobs.

Initial job training is average.

The chairs are horrible.  For a job where you sit all day, they are so uncomfortable and old.  

Phone jobs are competitive and repetitive no matter where you work.  At Merrill Edge, it's no different.  Also, there is a tendency for management to micro manage in any call center.  Again, it's no different at Merrill Edge.  It's just too easy for data to be pulled and analyzed at a call center.  The powers that be can't help themselves.   That being said, I've seen it way worse at other call centers.  It's actually not too bad at Merrill but that could easily change.

1 out of every 10 calls results in production.  The rest of the calls are left messages, service related, or disinterested clients.  It can start to wear on you.  You have to have the right personality for this type of job and this industry.  It requires a good deal of persistence and a hunger for knowledge of the business.

You do not have your own book or a long term relationship with your clients because it's a team based phone environment (this could also be a pro depending on how you look at things).  Make it easier for clients to call an adviser directly.

pros:
Pros unmitigated by cons:  Great benefits, good salary, tuition reimbursements, life-balance programs, family assistance (such as elder care and adoptions)

Pros mitigated by cons:
WORK FROM HOME - Big push now is to remove the work from home program so new hires are mostly going to be working in an office and current employees are being pushed out of the program. Since many of the teams in IT are virtual, it's moderately pointless since the benefits of working in an office mean promotional opportunities (more about that later) and having greater access to your team and the people you support. But if they're all in another state or country, than mostly what you get out of the deal is a commute and increased noise levels when you're trying to function. As a new hire, you're not going to be working from home.

My direct managers were amazing people whom I admired, but to be honest, if I'd had anyone else I wouldn't have stayed 5 more years. 

There's are several methods for educating employees, including the eLearning program and mentoring programs, but taking the time to invest in them isn't easy, even when it's mandated that you take them.
cons:
Poor PR for the company: I was mortally afraid to tell people I worked for BOA because then I'd be treated poorly by them. I know one employee who experienced delayed emergency medical treatment once admitting nurses found out who he worked for. When people found out, it was impossible to escape their wrath and stories of mistreatment. BOA MUST turn that ship around, if only to make it safe to admit our employer. I spent most my waking hours with you, so denying it is horrible!

Toxic reverse takeover culture: After the Merryl Lynch purchase, the company culture went south. Layoffs concentrated on people from BOA as the reverse takeover turned the company toxic. It no longer was relatively safe to make a mistake, getting thrown under the bus and the likelihood of getting written up skyrocketed. I'm not a cavalier employee by nature; I've always been studious and exacting in everything I did. Despite being IT, I am not of the cowyboy coder mentality, but when overly cautious types like me are negatively impacted, it's a sign. This cultural change was reflected in calls to HR too, as quality HR representation became much less friendly and helpful. I seriously wonder how long it's going to be before someone takes a hard look at the ratio of people being laid off who were from BOA prior merger or Merryl Lynch prior merger, because I expect it's going to result in a significant law suit.

Little opportunity for growth:  Senior management flattened the hierarchy without investing in a culture that was comfortable for it. The number of people competing for jobs effectively increased by a factor of 10! Lots of people were demoted at that point, lost their titles, and were demoralized, and the people below vying to grow were demoralized by virtue of there being much fewer positions to grow into. 

Frequent, unpredictable layoffs: self-explanatory, but it used to be a seasonal thing, now it's an all the time thing. We used to call it the slaughter. Also, during one slaughtering season I witnessed while I still worked in the office, I was enraged to see some of the managers giving word to the dismissed were having a good time and cracking jokes. Maybe it's gallows humor because they were trying to manage the distress of having to do it, but treat the occasion with the solemnity it deserves, since the survivors can SEE you and remember.

pros: In a company of this size, you will always find a few bad eggs in management; it's just a fact of life. However, moving past those what you will find is some of the most amazing leadership to be had anywhere in a large, corporate, financial institution. cons: It's corporate america. Knowing your role, and driving for excellence WITHIN that role is rewarded. Any efforts outside of that narrow margin are not appreciated or rewarded.  That's just the nature of large, corporate behemoths.

Micro management might be a big issue and there will never be enough time to do all the reports they want you to do ( coach your bankers , sales tracker (more of this in a moment ), referrals trackers, and others )

Many times I worked very hard to find out that because I didn't add a history note on the system before I submit the investment , I won't credit for it. review_title: I wouldn’t recommend, avoid excessive workload and disarray.
job_title: Operations Analyst- Insurance Administrator in Tucker, GA
pros:
Benefits are awesome. 
Company has longevity. 
Pay is average to high per market. 
Complementary coffee/tea (only Lipton). 
Opportunity to participate in many volunteer activities. 
Can sign up to have employees contribute to a charity of your choice as well. 
Opportunity to attend several events (including international) that are hosted through out the year. 
At the end of each quarter there’s complementary lunch on the company.
cons: Whew, where to begin. Office environment is VERY old fashioned/traditional, meaning there’s still a presence of nepotism, racism, sexism and overall unprofessionalism. Many things get swept under the rug if you’re one of the “favorites”. During my employment I heard foul language, seen disrespect to one another and lack of corporate etiquette. In my department employees were very disruptive by being constantly out of their seats having personal side conversations very loudly in another language (which is in violation of BOA rules). Breaks were supposed to be 15 minutes but teammates would regularly go on smoke breaks for 30-45 minutes at a time which caused their work to be behind. They never stayed late to catch up work which resulted in them needing help from the other teammates. This adds additional workload to the overall team. If management doesn’t say anything, who blames them. Training was absolutely HORRIBLE. Many employees have been there for 10-30 years and do not want to train new employees due to fear of being overshadowed or passed over for a promotion. I received little to no training because the trainer I was assigned to only wanted to help her best friend. Her best friend has been employed in that position for almost two years and is still not retaining information thus far. I basically had to train myself for the time I was there. When I asked questions I was oftentimes ignored and/or forgotten. When I suggested getting help from other teammates who seemed to have a grasp on the information also, it was frowned upon. This puts you in a compromising situation because now you’re neglected from being trained and can’t reach out to other sources for help. Workload was extremely behind and no one really wanted to help. Grunt work was oftentimes put off on “the not so favorites”. Those that stayed overtime to catch up work were overlooked, while the teammates who are very behind in work and never stay late, got praised. I just didn’t understand it. Safe to say, glad I’m no longer in this disarray. (This experience is based off the Tucker, GA location only, Unsure how other locations may operate.)

review_title: "Needs Based Selling"...maybe for the corporate meetings.
pros: Very large and secure ( as this volatile world will allow)  financial institution.  Wide array of products and services to offer customers.  Bank of America in the recent economic environment has  a very large customer base with the addition of both ML and CWide.
cons: Bank of America has become the "fast food" of retail banking.   They try to preach a "needs based selling" model to all new and current employees.  BUT, the unrealistic goals that are asked of you trump that.  Most manager's either turn a blind eye or actively condone a forceful if not blatant ignorance of what a customer can handle or really needs.  The "Market Team" sets goals very similar to what you would see at a mall store ( the Gap or a Shoe dep't).  These Goals include checking accounts, savings, and credit cards, etc.  The only thing that your manager will care about is a number at the end of the day.  Not the three letters from happy customers left on his/her desk.  Those won't even be put in your file.  It doesn't matter what you do as long as you open enough checking and savings accounts.  You are NOT an advisor you are a fast food clerk and hopefully a speedy talkative salesperson who glazes over details.  This is a VERY entry level position in the financial world.   Promotions are given to the one with the highest "numbers" no matter what intangibles are present.  They say ethics is upheld tantamount, but even a proof-positive example is brushed aside as a "one time occurrence".  Management at the retail level is far from professional.   At a meeting, regional executive has said  "if you are feeling under-appreciated, you are in the wrong business".

opportunity for transfers and gains in level of position, stock options, 401K and constant training sponsored by the company

review_title: Decent part-time job, good way to network and build an entry-level resume.
job_title: Senior Merchant Teller in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
If you're willing to learn and mature yourself professionally (speaking from a younger generation perspective) this is a great opportunity. Bank of America will train you how to speak to clients, how to handle difficult situations, and how to work with a sense of urgency. It's a great part-time job during college/school to help build your resume. If you're looking for a long-term goal here, there are a lot of opportunities given the several different locations/branches (but don't think a promotion will just be 'handed' to you). You need to have the right work ethic and attitude. It's also a great way to network. I used to love talking to my customers on a daily basis. Some will keep in touch long after you leave. 

Quite honestly, the work is easy. It's 'retail' banking. Do your job and you'll be fine. 

Part-time and full-time employees receive benefits. Vacation, sick days, jury duty, 401K, medical/dental/vision, tuition reimbursement, childcare reimbursement, paid leave, etc.
cons:
Low pay. Bank of America will pay you a much lower hourly rate than other banks in the area. I still have several contacts that work for the company, and in 2012 in Los Angeles, they were starting off tellers around $11-$12/hour. I started with the company in 2007, and started at $10.00/hour (or it could have been $9.75…?). In 2009, I left making $11.00/hour as a Senior Teller. I was often tempted to go to Wells Fargo, Chase, or even smaller credit unions, where they offered $2.00-$3.00/hour more, but chose to stay with Bank of America because I knew it would only be temporary until college graduation.

Office politics will drive you crazy. It's easy to be recognized in the branch level (recognition is often based on your performance - referrals, sales, customer service), but to be recognized by upper management above the branch level is difficult (and they're the ones that control the promotions). You need to suck up to move up. As always, it depends on your branch and market. I worked in Southern California and found that the particular market manager I had was notorious for favoritism, and only promoting employees she liked on a personal level. Sometimes you need to wait it out. There are constant changes with management, branch and upper-level, and if a great manager ends up at your branch or market, you may find yourself with a great opportunity. I know people who have moved up from a part-time teller to manager in a little over a year. Some people stay tellers for years. 

However, it's not always based on management. It has a lot to do with your attitude and your work ethic. A lot of the tellers, personal bankers, and even supervisors were incompetent. They would leave their stations and wander around because they didn't want to help customers (basically, they didn't want to work). Many didn't know how to deal with customers during a difficult situation (what I like to call the blank stare), and many didn't want to go above and beyond for their branch. Call me sensitive, but I saw my branch as my team, and I would help whoever I could if they needed help. Unfortunately, a lot of employees will not have your back here. They'll complain about the smallest things like taking a later lunch, not being able to sit, not wanting to help customers after 6:00PM, emptying the trash, etc. There's also constant office gossip. Employees befriend in cliques. Your best advice is not to get involved, it's not worth the petty drama. 

Sometimes you can't blame them though. Bank of America doesn't hire the highest caliber of employees at the rates they pay, and at the end of the day, you get what you pay for.

job_title: AVP- Post Sale Claims Specialist in Addison, TX
pros: Great co-workers and management, this will feel like a very family like environment to you, and you can count on always having someone on your team to lend a helping hand.
cons: Now the downside of being a BOA employee is you will never know what is going on. One month you will be in training for another position, and the next month you'll find out you may not have a job in the next month in a half, when you start with this company start with a back up plan.

pros: Back then, there were some very smart quant teams in Merrill Lynch - which means you get to learn a lot in a short time and get to contribute to the bottomline immediately. Banks in general are very fast changing organizations, so you also learn quite a bit of organizational psychology.
cons: I had a very good time there, so do not have much to add in the cons section. The chaos of 2008 took a toll on some of the groups there, but overall, I think it went well for most people where they stayed or left after Stan O Neal's departure.

pros:
This is a company that one stays with forever!  If you're looking for a career and a interested and growing with a company this may be the place for you.  If you do not have any prior banking experience, No Problem.  The starting position is a Teller.  Lots of customer contact.  Expectation is to delight and uncover needs for the customer. So please know, this too is a sales role.  

You can only move up from there.  

The bank is also a great place for Part timers or students.  The work-life balance can be better but most managers are pretty flexible with you
cons:
There seems to be a bit of disconnect with upper management and retail stores.  Retail stores (or what you may know as the bank) see thousands of customers a month.  The banks priorities seem to be changing constantly.  It's difficult to know what your focus should be day to day.  It is definitely becoming a company that is more sales driven.( ala wells fargo, ugh)  So, if you do not like sales. This is not the place for you.  

If you're looking to get out of sales and into a different role within the company or start out in a non sales role, Good Luck.  Seems like most roles are again mostly sales, and also you you may  need to have a lot of exposure to get into any other role.  Most of the administrative roles are filled by lifers as are the audit team roles.

review_title: If you don't speak Spanish, you won't go anywhere.
pros: Health benefits are really good.
cons: You can't get promoted unless you're a favorite or speak Spanish. Managers are beyond unprofessional and don't seem to realize that customers tell the tellers how fake they act when greeting them. I wish the managers could hear what their "favorites" have to say about them behind their backs.  All they want us to do is lie to our customers to get them to apply for credit cards.  Everyone in the bank gets a bonus except the tellers who do all the work selling them. Salaries are below average and raises are a joke if you even get one.

pros:
-great benefits, paid time off, tuition and childcare reimbursement, and many perks/discounts offered
-for sales and management positions, pay-for-performance ensures you are rewarded for hitting and exceeding your goals
-hourly pay plus incentive pay
-company tries to foster a recognition culture
cons:
-retail banking. it is what it is.
-bankers become slaves to the incentive plans which change every year.
-being pushed to sell credit cards is not pride-inducing
-not much exposure to other lines of business outside of retail

review_title: Great company, great name to have on your resume.
pros: I worked at Bank of America for seven years and it was the best role I've had throughout my 20 year career in Finance. Management has done a great job in their steady climb out of the financial crisis of 2008.
cons: Compensation can be lower than some banks due to the easy availability of lower cost location employees (Charlotte, NC). BOA has a "genteel" culture that can make getting direct honest feedback at times difficult.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Detroit, MI
pros: Great health insurance benefits, child care reimbursement, tuition reimbursement
cons: Selling products and services to customers who clearly can not afford them just to make the bank money is a low blow and shameful. Pushing the "Product of the week or month" is a great way to earn a quick buck and even faster way to loose any chance of return business

pros: I was a part time teller.  The benefits for full time and part time are amazing.  Part time employees get full benefits which I was grateful for when I went on maternity leave.   The hours were awesome because my weekends were free.
cons: the pay is not great. in the three years I worked there I only got a .62 cent raise.  if you are in school full time the hours you can work are limited and management don't want to accommodate.  There is also favoritism within the market.  and the work is extremely tedious.

review_title: Worse professional experience in over 25 year career in IT
pros: Wide variety of technology; well-developed tele-work program (although the company's commitment to it seems to be declining; talented, dedicated co-workers
cons: Constant re-organization and lay-offs; no job security; every directive from management is delivered with a threat; constant changes of course; total lack of set direction; the most hostile relationships with vendors and suppliers I've ever seen; lots of talk about making BofA the best place to work from the top but ultimately absolutely no commitment to employees.   I've worked for 3 large major corporations in over a 25 year career and this was, by far, the worse professional experience I had.

pros: Opportunity to learn new things.
cons: Poor management, Work/life balance they are not tolerant when emergencies arise that must be dealt with during company hours and it is difficult to take time off without repercussions. The division I worked in constantly changed processes and rules. The associates were never truly understanding of processes due to constant change and upheaval within the department.

job_title: Customer Service Representative/Business in Lincoln, RI
pros:
Began with old Fleet as it was changing over to BOFA. Very pleased with the team members and management staff. It was new and chances to move ahead. Began taking care of personal accounts, moved on to the business accounts.
Was part of a luncheon at Kirkbrae country club Lincoln ,RI and many motivational parties. Received many awards for performance and supporting my teammates. I went above and beyond to assist a business customer and received a bouquet of flowers and a thank you note. My article  were on the BOFA internet site for a year. I did receive nice profit sharing of bonus payouts that was great.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Kansas City, MO
pros: Bank of America really does care about their employees.  They have decent salaries with great benefits.  Working conditions are good.  As always, it depends on the department and manager you work for, but generally, I have had great experience with managers at all levels. There are always opportunities for advancement, though they are not always clear, but they have ways to increase your learning via web classes.  I went from cash handling to an at home work position over the twenty plus years I worked there.
cons: Some have complained about a work life balance when you move to higher positions, or if you are in a high volume type production environment.  The tellers and banking centers deal with sales issues, but in many back office positions that is not the case.  One major issue is that when they do their yearly "house cleaning", they consolidate departments and lay folks off without warning.  We held our breath every year or whenever an internal re-org took place.  This does not lend itself to job security and gives the impression that the company is not really concerned about its employees.

job_title: Operations Project Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: Chance for advancement, good bonuses, good working conditions
cons: Some managers become managers through who they know, definitely not what they know. Bad employees stay on forever without being fired. Critical thinking and playing the devil's advocate to intercept small problems before they become big problems is not practiced.

review_title: Excellent Benefits with Opportunities for all Associates
pros: Team atmosphere and management is willing to listen to any feedback and will address without negative consequences. Your peers are often very helpful when encountering difficulties or needs for your team. Great Benefits and programs for Associates.
cons: Job depends on available projects. If a project budget is cut, so may your job. You can encounter challenging and demanding managers (being prepared and willing to follow-up in a timely manner helps address their questions/concerns) on project teams.

review_title: Consistently dynamic workflow, with limited ability to focus on any specific given task at a time.
pros: Top notch benefits; vacation time/sick time/personal time; decent pay. BofA itself is a great company to work for: excellent benefits, decent pay, holiday/vacation/sick time/personal time, etc. But unless you are a heartless liar by nature, you wont last.
cons: Septic management culture; hostile work environment; impossible sales quotas. Probably the most stressful professional environment ever. The sales quotas are nearly impossible to meet coupled with a hostile management culture.

job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Windsor, CT
pros: Great environment to work in. The supervisors/Managers are friendly and helpful.
cons: One could not rely on this job to pay bills. Even though the job  was an "as-needed-basis" you were never allowed to put in a full week's work to get a decent pay check.

review_title: Was good as long as it lasted
pros: The pay is great. The people are very motivated. There is much immediate responsibility. Nice work location. High profile work. Real impact.
cons: Connections business. Much internal rivalry. Work environment that is life to most people. Extremely competitive. Mundane work that does not require the most skills. Long hours.

review_title: The whole industry is jacked up not just B of A
job_title: Tram Manager I in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Benefits are competitive. Pay can be competitive. Many other compensation perks such as tuition reimbursement, life resources, corporate access to continued learning resources such as Lynda.com, TED talks, and Harvard Business review. 5% 401k match that is fully vested with no waiting period or length of employment conditions. Very progressive on diversity and equality (notice I also list this as a con ;). Lots of change and movement, opportunities to try new roles and departments. Vacation and sick time are generous.
cons: Since I've been working, there has been a constant of semi regular layoffs and down sizing ("right sizing"), although the bank makes a fair effort to help displaced employees, the severance is pretty fair, and they will also first try to find a different role opportunity for you before laying off (known internally as a redeploy). The internal operations can be  frustratingly bureaucratic and nothing happens quickly. HR is basically a bunch of knuckle heads and/or straight malicious. There can be huge pay discrepancies (I'm talking 30k plus), for many people doing the EXACT same role. They are slow to promote but fast to ask you to increase your responsibilities. I have had to be in an "acting" role for months at a time before ever officially being promoted. That means being severely under compensated for the level of work performed, but in my case it eventually has worked out each time. For a lot of people it doesnt. Huge commitment to diversity which is mostly good, but sometimes is overboard or also causes a kind of reverse discrimination/favoritism. I've witnessed a fair amount of nepotism but it's generally more localized rather than inherent to the institution.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Hopewell, NJ
pros: I've been working at EDGE for a little under a year, and it has been a pretty good experience.  With absolutely no industry experience or educational background, EDGE has taught me a lot.  You have the opportunity for paid study-time for licensing which is awesome.  Also, you immediately start talking to clients about their portfolios, investment strategies, and goals right after training as opposed to making cold calls and hoping to get someone on the phone.  If you embrace your role as a financial advisor and take the time to learn more about economics, capital markets, and investment strategies, you'll quickly realize some of the cons at EDGE.
cons: Call center.  No matter how you want to give yourself a fancy label or corporate title, you are a call center representative.  Because of the set-up of the platform, advisors are expected to be transactional; miss just one day of goals and God help you with the rest of your month and forget even trying to go on vacation.  You'll lose out on the financial planning aspect of the job as well as you don't have a book of business that you're responsible.for and can't talk to clients about annuities or insurance which is a vital part of any financial plan.  The 'adviors' that do the best are the ones that are good phone salesmen.  It's hard to take the role seriously when you see some people get promoted but can't explain what's happening in the markets to their clients.

pros: Good place to gain experience in a large, complex environment.  They've got it all; from mainframe to laptop and everything in between with the software to go with it.  There's never a dull moment.
cons: Layoffs are part of the company culture.   The reorgs and people shuffling add complexity.  We were stunned to repeatedly hear, "It's not my job and I have no idea who can help you."

review_title: Great company for career mobility. Opportunity for growth and development if you work hard.
job_title: Small Business Banker in Chicago, IL
pros: Endless opportunities for development. Many tools available to network and grow within organization. The company is everywhere. You could relocate to many parts of the country. Great corporate perks and benefits.
cons: Too much red tape. Very methodical and never any room for debate. Company promotes diversity of opinion and debate on paper, but does not value this very much in actual situations. Lack of transparency among leadership, No Real clear answers from decision makers.

pros: Love the culture of doing what's right for the customer. They encourage making sound decisions within parameters and try to remove roadblocks for staff and customers.
cons: Little or no formal training on systems and procedures. Literally sink or swim. No ability to adjust teams schedules to meet unexpected swells in customers. Zero tolerance for OT policy does not go ever well with a line of customers out the door and 1 teller.

pros: Amazing team. Company is filled with great people. Mentoring is a part of the company culture which I personally find to be amazing.
cons: Need to hire more people. Work is extremely overwhelming. Especially within the teller line. Too much work and not enough people to do it. Also too many managers they now have restructured the company so that there is one sales manager and an operational manager. They tend to clash against on another.

pros:
Great high quality HMO/PPO Dental, Vision, Life insurance plans & Health Benefits with low co-pays/deductibles. Offers Kaiser, Aetna, Anthem BlueCross BlueShield & United Healthcare.  Dental offers MetLife Dental PPO & Aetna DMO - both include free dental checkups & coverage for other expenses such as fillings, crowns and braces.  Company gives $500 towards your annual medical premium and is deposited into your Health Spending Account card after you complete the wellness activities - health screening and health questionnaire. 

You get  10 paid sick days and 10 paid holidays (excludes call center associates) and offers floating holidays.  Depending on your band, you get a certain number of days of vacation.  The lowest band starts at Band 9 & 8 which starts with 2 weeks of vacation (after 4 years you get 1 more week), Band 6 & 7 gets 3 weeks (after 14 years you get 1 more week) and Bands 4 & 5 starts with 4 weeks (after 24 years you get 1 more week) and so forth.

Full- or part-time U.S. employees are eligible for vacation time off, unless you're in job bands 0-3, commissioned or scheduled to work fewer than 20 hours per week.  

**The maximum amount of vacation you can earn is capped at your annual vacation allotment.**
cons: Management puts too much pressure on associates in regards to development.  I feel that when the employee is ready to be developed, he/she will reach out.  As far as career opportunities go, you cannot move up within your department without your manager's approval/endorsement. (In my case, it is in the corporate offices, not the financial centers).  I have a colleague who has been in her role for 14 years and was not endorsed to move up due to one issue she encountered with a hiring manager in regards to recruitment strategies. She has given up on trying to move up and decided she will remain in her current role.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Spokane, WA
pros: The best reasons to work for Bank of America are the employees, the companies reputation of how to solve problems in regards to banking, mortgage, loans, credit cards. etc...
cons: Customer Service. The wait to get someone on the line to handle those problems when calling by telephone or the response time to answer and email. I think the company has gotten so big that they forget about customer service and focus more on how much the makes as a whole.

job_title: V P Service Delivery Manager in Newark, DE
pros: The people with whom I work are both a team and a family. We do what it takes to get the job done and we care about one another.
cons: Pay is an issue. The culture is such that you get "promoted" with no compensation. Your annual performance increase is thought to be adequate. I have never worked in a place with such a practice.

review_title: Comfortable, yet not much opportunity to grow
job_title: Relationship Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people to work with. Power of teamwork and networking. Good place to find yourself. 2-3 week vacation per year. Good work/life balance. Can go to many routes from this position - Operation / Small Business / Mortgage Lending / Financial Advising
cons: Health Insurance benefits are mediocre/poor. Difficult to get sponsored for licenses (only top 1% might get the chance to be selected to be in a program; need to pass the program to get licensed). Company doesn't really care about employee's education advancement.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: My immediate was a good guy.  His manager?  Not so much.  I nicknamed him "the Diva" as he was extremely loud and needy.  Benefits were good.  Work-life balance was good (depending on your manager).
cons: The EA title was downgraded to an Administrative Title.  Bonus disappeared for assistants - but depending on your managers, SOME (a small percentage) of assistants continued to receive company bonus because their managers changed their titles.  Imagine having the same job as another assistant, within the same hierarchy, but receiving less money because their title allowed for bonus and yours does not.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (Teller) in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good pay for Tellers starting pay. I worked within a team environment. The people I worked with were amazing! My branch had some of the best people I have ever worked with. Dental benefits good. Vision o.k. They do match 5% on retirement.
cons: I worked for Bank of America five years, ten years ago, where the main focus was exceptional customer service. Unfortunately the focus is completely different now. Main goal for tellers is to get clients "referred" to see a personal banker who will hopefully sell them something else. Goals are set each day that seem to be more important than anything else. Of course the usual as any business customer service, quick service, and always to suggest the customer use the electronic systems available instead of coming in. No breaks at my branch because there was not enough Tellers to serve the customers. Two tellers are not enough to take care of customers on a Monday for example. Very hard to call in sick if you were ill because there was no one to cover your shift. One of the managers said to the teller who worked close to me after she worked from 7:30am to 5:30pm and who only had a half an hour lunch and who had 350 transactions "this is all the referrals you had today's?" That is what happens when there is so much pressure from Corporate that make selling the most important. Much more motivating for people who put all their energy into working to hear "Great job today guys!" Anyway there is more but this is the core of the negative. Medical Benefits expensive.

pros: Decent base pay for a sales position. Nothing else positive to say.
cons: Very high turnover. Also, you have the same numbers to hit regardless of your offices location. This was something managment said didn't make a difference but it obviously did. If they place you in a low income area, good luck.

review_title: Good company - it is what you make it.
pros: The salary was quite decent and I know there is an effort to try and engage employees more and change the morale, but this is like any other large corporate with hundreds of thousands of employees.  It's impersonal, but it depends primarily on your immediate team and manager.  It is what you make it.
cons: It's impersonal... you're a number.  Management talks a great talk, but the follow through is not there.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: I have nothing good to say about this bank.
cons: Stressful and unfair treatment. Very strict with meeting sales and quick to discipline you.

job_title: Consumer Market Manager in Tampa, FL
pros:
- Plenty of opportunities under one roof thanks to multiple lines of business.
- Great benefits including 16 weeks paid paternity leave
- Leadership development training
cons:
- Upward career mobility has stalled with flattening of the organization.
- Lost a bit of its meritocracy culture -- it is more and more about who you know to be promoted.
- Diversity and inclusion is more talk than action. Bank can't get its act together in creating a truly inclusive environment specifically at senior leadership positions level.

review_title: Management does not walk the walk
pros:
Bank of America is my second home. I have worked at Bank of America for over 10 years. I have gained the sense of loyalty to the extent that this is like my store that I will fight for. Though it's very disheartening that the management does not do what they preach. Doing the right thing is impossible because of politics and procedure. I cared BEFORE but hearing from my own boss, "Let it go... Let the powers be." I felt like there is no sense of fighting.... You just have to go with the flow. I felt like because of out voicing my concerns, it stained my credibility. 
I surely love my job. The company is very flexible to your personal needs. If you want to be one of the leaders someday, you have to be outgoing, vocal and walk the same plank. Not as bad as you think. But if you are a conscience-driven person, you will have a struggle against your conviction.
cons: There is no such thing as perfect company. Whether you work at BOFA or with other company there is always a debate. Theory is different from actual observations. There is a always a compromise, may it be the customer and so be it.

pros: The benefits hands down are A1,  You can advance just about anywhere you want within the organization as long as you have a foot in the door, perform well and network through all the available channels they offer through their intranet. In my many years with the bank I've worked in Mortgage, IT and Retail Consumer & Business Banking. Every department has its ups and down but I can say there were more ups than downs.
cons:
Be prepared for change that sometimes make no sense.
Retail banking market has short staffing all the way around

review_title: Know what your getting in to
pros: - Big Company with lots of resources and opportunity to grow
cons:
The systems are built to cost you money. There are horror stories once you get hired of advisors getting screwed out of sales compensation. Usually the reasons are  because of the complexity of the systems. If one tag is missed you can lose credit for the sale, even if there is no doubt that you closed the deal. 
They will also train you that its all investment related, but once you get there they make you hustle credit cards to people.

review_title: Things aren’t always greener on the other side
job_title: Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: The pay is probably the best as far as bank pay is concerned. They love to take outside talent and make sure you are content with your pay.
cons: Too much favoritism and politics. If you are looking for a job to have your work speak for its self, this is not it. You have to either be a favorite or  political.

job_title: Small Business Consultant in Sacramento, CA
pros: I have had an exceptional experience with my career at Bank of America. The job is always challenging, but I have been blessed to experience great leaders who helped to develop and mentor me for personal career development.
cons: It's a big corporation. Some leaders earn their position politically instead of based on merit - but rarely do those situations last very long.

review_title: Fantastic Organization with Immense Learning Opportunities
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros:
- Incredible CEO, who is personable and leads by setting an example. 
- Many resources and tools available to continuously grow in your role. 
- The passionate workforce who all rally around one mission, improving the financial lives of our customers. 
- Many perks and benefits that are offered to employees (401K match, good health insurance coverage, discount programs, generous vacation policy, 4-month maternity leave)
cons: - Need to improve the work-life balance of the workforce who are in financial centers

pros: Nothing apart from brand name
cons:
Sadistic, Micro managing and  bureaucratic associates and manager, particularly in emea regional team. 

No respect for employees, who are treated like animals or Bullocks, with associates all the time over analyst's head to beat the hunter.

Associates do not even complete the required 9 hours of the day. They come and go as per their whims. I am sorry to say but the team inefficiency is primarily because of more associates than required. Productivity increases when some are absent.  

Back biting is a daily thing. 

No learning. People become unemployable after coming here. They consider employees as assembly line labourers with time earmarked for every task.

review_title: BoA sets unrealistic job scope for HR Managers that want to be successful
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Huge company that allows you to move to new clients and constant change
Fully mature HR functions
People you work with are great
cons:
Expectations/workload very frustrating for those that want to do a good job
Had 5 new managers in one year.  Consistently had 2 new managers per year for 7 years.

review_title: Highly corporate, inflexible environment.  No room for freedom or ideas
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Addison, TX
pros:
Big name looks good on a resume.  There is some opportunity to work with technologies you may not have had exposure to before.  

Benefits are alright, though you would expect more from a big company.    

Compensation is in line with the average, but money doesn't seem to be a problem for them.  They are a bank.

Good work/life balance. You basically put in your 8 hours and go home.  There are no rewards for extra effort or "going the extra mile", in fact, they actively discourage it.
cons:
Most teams are scattered all over the place so you never work face-to-face.  Everything is phone and Skype.  I worked there a little over a year and never even met my boss.  

Very restrictive.  It's "my way or the wrong way".  They only want devs who can follow precise instructions.  No room for ideas, suggestions, or any deviation.  You do exactly the task, the way they tell you. Nothing more or less.

Dull, boring work.  Most of the applications are already built, so you'll spend all your time working on other peoples code.  No opportunity to carve your own space there.

Turf wars and company politics are rampant.  If you're new, be prepared to do the work no one else wants to do.  You'll get put on bad project with other bad developers and bad leaders.

Don't go to HR about anything!  They talk a big game about open door policy and all that, but my experience was just the opposite.  Verbally abusive managers often skated with no consequences while anyone who submits any sort of complaint gets punished.

pros: Health Benefits, Sick days, and vacation
cons: If you stay here for greater than 5 years you are stumping your career.  Too many people making boat loads of money and do nothing.  Uneducated, just good bull artists.  Diversity and Inclusion and CSR are very phony, only window dressing for investors.  Good people ignored and passed up for promotions.  The power to do does not apply to everyone here.

review_title: Overall a good organization to be in
job_title: Analyst-I Applications Prog in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
Good work life balance
Nice work culture and overall positive office environment 
No problem at all in taking leaves, even unplanned  
Good other benefits like office meal cards,  gym etc.
cons:
Leaders are biased and a lot of favoritism can be noticed
Few old employees are just sitting and only there for relaxing
Not much technical exposure in most of the teams unlike other technology companies or competitive banks

review_title: Good place to work overall - if you can keep up with the corporate politics, but this is not the only place that has it.
pros: growth opportunities are there. Need to keep up with corporate politics. Huge company but has some pretty good options for development.
cons: senior managers are often a old boy's club. The decisions sometimes are not simply made based on merit, it often is simply a result of who you know. But, after all, are most places not like that?

pros: in this job market no explination needed. Great benifits and some experienced managers.
cons: Some managers don't know what they're doing, or how to manage, at some pionts there are impossible expectaions. Manager need to come up with a better way to meet thier goals and delight the associates. If you make them happy they will do the same for your customers and help bring in business.

pros: It's just like High School, with all the friends and the drama.  If your good the customers will praise you.
cons: This job seemed to just drag on, everyday seemed just like the last with the same drama in the office and the same deposits by the customers.  It's amazing how much praise you can get from the customers, but the managers don't care.

pros: They do a good job of getting diversity into teams as well as a lot of young people.  You do have a chance to look at most all deals that are out there which is good.
cons: Very bad management structure and job functions move all over the place.  They spend a lot of money on technology but it is lacking in a lot of areas.

job_title: Small Business Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Interview process was fairly easy.  Most of the training is done at the branch.
cons:
Extremely high sales goals with little bonuses paid to associates.  Some branch managers are clueless about sales and refuse to pay overtime.

They hire too many associates without college degrees.

review_title: Bank of America Employee with 2.5 years in the Bank
pros: Benefits, work-life balance, knowledgeable colleagues, opportunity to advance if you have any sort of degree along with a minimum of 6 months experience in your given role
cons: to move up you need to have connections with management or be extra commited to working by the book (don't cut any corners) to advanve

pros: The company is obviously big and well known, if you happen to get good managers its not bad, there is room to grow because they like moving up people from within the company.
cons: Lowest pay rate out of all the banks i know of, bad management in my personal experience. irresponsive to many of the problems the employees have or any of their complaints.

review_title: I gave my everything to the company and gained great experience, but didn't earn the title to show for any of it.
pros: Benefits, Flexibility, Spirit, and Comfort.
cons: Lack of of advancement, lack of training, lack of retaining good associates. You are a warm body to do the job and aren't treated as the valuable associate you should be recognized as. Bonuses are minimal. Their idea of recognition is a certificate and pat on the back, instead of being rewarded with money. Business-wide changes aren't thoughout, only vastly acted on. Poor Management. Higher Management is selected by who you know or who you kiss up to rather than the experience and hardwork you have put in.

review_title: Overall a positive place to work. Still some issues with the integration into Bank of America.
pros: Depth of resources for clients. One of the few places that can truly be a one stop shop for financial services. Unmatched resources for helping HNW individuals and business owners.
cons: The mere size of the organization can sometimes be an impediment to change that might better serve the employees and clients.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Wichita, KS
pros: Great Company.  Top pay and benefits especially the childcare and tutiion reimbursement.
cons: Once you leave Bank of America it can be curse and a blessing.  It can be difficult to locate another job who has similar pay and benefits but when people see BofA on your resume it gives you an advantage over the other applicatants.  Especially, if you have been with the bank for several years.

review_title: Good place to work, but no balance
pros: The benefits are amazing, the pay is competitive, and you never have to work on Sundays. There is a lot of opportunity for career growth and promotion if you work hard and meet your goals. The company is moving in the right direction to be transparent and do the right thing for the customer, so I feel good about what I'm doing there.
cons: The only con I really have is the lack of balance between work and family life. While you do get sick days, you really can't use them without being raked over the coals.

job_title: Collections and Modification in Addison, TX

review_title: An "alright" experience with decent pay but serious management issues.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in East Providence, RI
pros:
~  Compensation was relatively competitive for its line of work (customer service in a call center environment).
~  Assuming management was fair or receptive, there were a number of creative and interesting ways that employees could be recognized such as cash incentives or gifts (ie, gift card for retailers, Bank of America merchandise, etc).  I received a $50 Macy's gift card simply for keeping my stats in the top 3 during a chaotic period for the company.
~  Emphasis was generally on quality and customer values as opposed to unrealistic sales pitches or cross products.
~  Plenty of opportunities for VTO (voluntary time off/unpaid) based on call volume and each rep's individual schedule. 
~  Building/site was relatively new & therefore clean, organized with an outside area for smoking and relaxation plus tons of parking and on a frequent bus route.
~  Relaxed dress code: jeans permitted.
~  Raises were relatively frequent & based on  performance: for the short time I worked for the company, I received several raises.
cons:
~  One of the biggest issues I found within the East Providence site itself, was a serious lack of consistency among floor managers, site managers and the general/lead manager.  This led to dozens of issues including various interpretations of banking laws and regulations: one manager would basically enforce it as "A" while your own would enforce it as "B" causing major impacts on quality as well as producing very confused customers.

~Aside from specific incidences regarding banking laws, this also caused major issues among teams on the floor.  My manager, specifically, interpreted each site rule per verbatim: ie, no pens or paper, no food, no decorations, no personal items, etc while the manager sitting five feet across, couldn't care less.  While this may seem trivial, our small team would sit in blank cubicles, no holiday decor, etc while the folks immediately in back of us, were decked out with holiday lights, magazines, treats and so forth.  Yes, we are certainly there to work but considering the nature of the job (non-stop calls), any small activity or perk makes a huge difference in our day.  This was depressing to say the least.

~  No assigned seating or desks.  Placement was a free for all and those of us working later in the day usually found ourselves sitting alone and away from our teams.

~ Ridiculous rules.  Overall, each day seemed more like an adult day care than a financial institution.  The East Providence call center specifically, had a "paperless" policy meaning no pens, no paper, magazines, etc were allowed on the floor.  Again, considering the lack of consistency among management and the monotonous tendencies of the job, this made working ever so much more difficult to focus on.  Employee satisfaction can make a huge difference in the quality of one's work & I suspect the ridiculous turn over of employees is possibly related to this.

~  Very strict attendance, PTO and sick day policies.  Regardless of the reason why, all PTO (vacation) & sick time needed to be approved well in advance.  As opposed to scheduling things based on your site or team, this was based on the company as a whole making time off for doctor's appointments, family emergencies or general illnesses, close to impossible.  Typically the only options would be to call out, receive an occurrence or use VTO if available (unpaid).  Unlike many of the other companies I've worked for, they also had an extreme no tolerance policy on weather related absences.  During the Warwick floods or the serious blizzards we experienced back in 2009/2010, we were expected to be there and if not, were automatically given an occurrence.  Sadly, again, due to inconsistencies among managers, some were given less of a reprimand than others for the same instances.  Additionally, this created an endless cycle of very ill employees reporting to work: on more than one occasion people on my team would come in with stomach viruses, vomit in their waste baskets and stay for the remainder of their shift infecting everyone around them (again, no assigned seating).  Once on a warning, the employee would forfeit their incentive bonuses and any hope to apply to other departments regardless of their stats.

~  The customer survey system was greatly flawed.  Although in my particular case, I was consistently among the top of my peers, every so often I'd receive a customer e-mail survey that clearly was not for me (ie, a call I transferred to another department, customer was not satisfied with the second individual they spoke to and would fill out the survey for that person instead of the CSR).  Even in situations where the survey was very obviously not for the employee (ie, customer referring to the opposite gender, specifically stating the call was regarding a mortgage or something we do not handle as well as other very obvious identifiers), managers would refuse to remove any survey score unless the customer identified the rep by his or her name.  Which never happened.  Sadly this very small incident could be the difference between the much needed bonus or nothing at all.

~  Scheduling was completely outsourced quite frankly, to India.  If your shift started at 7:50am and you needed to call out, this would create an issue: they weren't open until 8am and you're required to call out at least an hour in advance.  Due to the serious language boundary, there were also major issues where employees would call to find out if a shift change was approved or to call out only to be given incorrect information.  (I winded up receiving a warning at one point due to what appeared to be a "no call, no show."  I had called out, followed procedure only to later, be told I had not called.  The calls are not recorded.)

pros:

cons:
So many uneducated employees (e.g. people who don't seem to be able to communicate in writing with correct punctuations, grammar and spelling), not only in the front-line staff, but also in middle-management positions, which makes it rather discouraging.  

It seems like a lot of semi-critical positions don't require a degree to get hired, when they truly should. People are put in critical positions, when they don't have what it takes, and they can only relate to their own little part of the process vs. looking at the big picture. Although it is a big company, and you'd think you'd have a lot of opportunities to move around, I haven't been able to get into the right position within, and I'm starting to think it may just be because I don't know the right people; otherwise, I have several years of internal experience in addition to a Finance degree, which should be enough to get a descent position, but apparently not.

pros: Stability, not a super strict work environment and can dress pretty casually. They do try to offer site wide activites for associate satisfaction but sometimes they are poorly executed.
cons:
Being here 5 years, there have been few opportunities to move into something else. Anytime a position opens, the hiring managers expect a lot of effort on your part (i.e. coming in multiple times on your off days or lunch breaks to learn more) well before the job posting to demonstrate interest. Unfortunately, the different job functions aren't clear and often times you don't know a job exists until its posted. And by that time they have several people they have in mind for the job, they are just posting it as a formality. Also, not being located in the main locations (DE or Charlotte) makes the growth opportunities even more limited. 

They expect quite a bit of effort for a very small increase in pay. They are quite skimpy with increases, it's taken me 5 years to get to making $30k base salary, and the only way to make more money is to really just move up in the company. If you have the opportunity to get a bonus each month, when they determine your yearly raise, they take how much you earned in bonues and add it to your yearly and consider that in how much they will give you in a base salary increase. If you are doing well on bonuses, you are probably not going to get the biggest increase, but in the end you make more money anyway with bonuses if you perform well. 

Very few people in my location have a M-F schedule and many work 2nd or 3rd shifts. However, they do offer compensation for those who work later shifts (8% pay). Also depending on your department, you will likely work holidays, even if its selecting a few out the year to work. Requesting vacatim time can be a challenge, especially if you are new, as its mostly done by seniority with the company and the particular department you are in. Often times, you will run out of vacation before the years over if you have a lot of weekend activities since you likely will work at least 2 days between Friday and Monday.
