pros:
Benefits - vacation/sick/purchased time off, health insurance, 401k (5% company matching).

Volunteer opportunities within the community on behalf of the company (if your manager approves, you can earn 2 extra hours of pay a week) - which is also a great way to network.
.
With the right managers (and your own drive) there is opportunity for advancement.
.
It is a socially respected job to have, regardless of what position you hold.
cons:
Depending on your manager, sick time is difficult to use without getting written up - there is even a computer program to tell how much is too much even though you are given up to 2 weeks, taking a personal day doesn't exist (depending on what rank you hold - does not apply to managers) and getting to the doctor while you are sick is practically impossible.

It is difficult to schedule your vacation time off, even though you get 2 weeks to start, with it going up from there depending on position - you have to schedule a year ahead of time if you want any kind of holiday off.

You don't get to pick your day off during the week, so it is difficult to plan sometimes - you usually get the same day each week and schedules are supposed to be given a month in advance, but that seldom happens.

Getting help from other associates is difficult, because staff has been pared down to bare bones and the back office call center has also experienced the same, so calling them is sometimes a frustrating experience when getting assistance with things one has little experience on.

Advancement depends on politics and "winning" i.e. sales performance, which depends on a great number of things sometime out of your control and management refuses to accept those other reasons:  banking center neighborhood, ethnicity, commercial traffic, proximity to other banks and BoA banking centers, etc. 

Sometimes you are bullied by your managers, depending on their personality, and HR blames you for misinterpreting their ridiculousness when you call to discuss a grievance.

There is WAY too much shifting people around, sometimes it makes sense, but sometimes it doesn't - customers complain.

It is a difficult life/work balance - you are potentially disciplined for accruing overtime and other times required to do so, depending on their fancy.

Sometimes when you ask managers things, they spew bureaucratic nonsense when they should really just say, "You know what, this sucks and I'm sorry, but hopefully it will get better soon," because they aren't really in charge either.

Compensation is minimal - you have to go back and forth a couple times with recruiters even though you are worth more, yearly raises go for about $0.15...if you AND your team qualify.

review_title: Buy out of a local bank.
pros: Great, innovative products.  Can find an ATM anywhere.
cons: B of A bought out the local bank I worked for.  They focus on profit, not people.  They want us to sell a credit card to every customer who walks through the door.

review_title: DFW area is great so far
pros: REAL employee training!!! Very impressed with onboarding training, nice employees to work with, team environment. Good company values. Starting pay is fair(but not great). Nice benefits (especially holiday and vacation time) Willing to hire from outside the banking industry! Management is willing to help you grow your career.
cons:
Salaries are fair, but they could be better. Don't expect the big bucks unless you hit the area Assistant VP/ VP level, or regional management level.

No real cons yet, but I'm still new and will update later if anything major sticks out.

job_title: ATM/Debit Fraud Claims Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: Pay for performance, great atmosphere, great people, quickly recognize talent and hard work
cons: Sometimes difficult to identify opportunities. They're always there, just difficult to find the right ones to forge your career path.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Scranton, PA
pros: Great Pay, nice employees, some managers were really easy-going.
cons: Poor training. There was little control over the large group that had to be trained. Made it a very difficult environment for me to learn in. The manager I got was never there. Had to walk across the room for help. Never quite understood if I was doing well or not (no feedback). No help desk (felt like I was all alone). If a customer asked to speak to a supervisor no one would step up to handle the call.

review_title: One of the best jobs that I have had.
job_title: Home Services Specialist II in Taunton, MA
pros: They reward employees with lunches and treats and have theme days with activities and prizes. Have extensive training programs that you can take advantage of to move ahead in your career. Company promotes from within. Extremely flexible hours.
cons: Can only move to a different area of the company once a year with approval from managers and human resources. Starting pay was on the low side but overtime and bonus made up for that.

review_title: Good company that struggles with bad press and constant reorgs.
pros: Most teams embrace working together for common goals.  Folks are professional and friendly.  Work environment is fairly flexible.
cons: It is extremely hard to move upward within a team.  YOu must move to another group and 'promote' yourself.  Benefits are steadily decreasing each year.  The worst part is never feeling settled...there is constant churn and re-org, with the daunting cloud of potential layoffs.

review_title: Under the heading of "Being the Best Place to Work"
pros:
The company says all the right things -- tells employees to do the right thing and talks about diversity/inclusion.
Used to allow some employees the ability to work from home, which increased productivity.
sometimes risk management.
Culture of the using recognition -- sending ecards/ebuttons
Vacation
Employee survey
cons:
Constant layoffs and reorgs.  Most folks are fearful of being laid off, which hinders progress.
Talented individual contributors and the best managers are getting laid off.
Not many opportunities in the technology groups. Most hiring for technology folks is in NY/NJ and CLT.
HR continues to make polices making it more difficult to find and transfer to a new role internally
Senior tech leaders are centralized mainly in NY/NJ and are out of touch with other cities IT teams.
Tech leaders make decisions about the employees without really knowing them at all -- missed opportunity -- why are other good employees not considered for key roles even if they live in different cities?
Technology execs hiring friends and family -- its a conflict of interest and others on the team are silence when they attempt to raise a concern or risk -- if you want to work here then you have to shut up when the tech exec friends don't want to follow policies 
Incredibly difficult to get anything done or make progress on any project. You can follow all the rules but there are multiple teams throwing up road blocks every step of the way.
Health insurance sucks -- used to be good but all the inefficiencies in healthcare are now the burden of the employee. Aetna does a poor job paying claims and attempting to be all things to all people.
Work/Life balance is biased towards work
Span of Control has been used a justification for crazy actions like demoting folks to a lower band and changing reporting structures. When this happens, employees feel like they have a target on their back and perhaps the company has a strategy for attrition (get employees to leave by making it uncomfortable) thus saving the company from paying a severance. If that is the plan then HR and Execs have done a great job which will be reflected in their bonus.

pros: Another line on your resume.
cons:
Technology senior management is chasing trends but has no overall strategy. The one and only positive, the work from home program is being shut down. The reason is to increase collaboration but yet they keep pushing India resources into projects. That does not increase face to face collaboration unless I am mistaken.

Reorgs happen every few months and the wrong people are in positions of power. Poor management decision making is part of the daily working life here.

Senior management pretends to care about employee feedback but it's all show.

Morale is very low due to constant threat of layoffs and lack of direction.

Benefits are horrible. Health insurance choices are high deductible and higher deductible plans.

job_title: Vice President Process Design Consultant I in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
My Work program - allows telecommuting for part or all of the time.
Discounts for pc purchases, amusement park tickets
Benefits are good and management is good about being flexible on personal time out of the office
cons:
Work life balance is sometimes forgotten or not taken into account.  Alot of red tape to get processes approved
Sneior leaders change frequently and each one shakes up the organization with so many changes and lay offs - very discouraging and frustating at times - it makes it difficult to get the work done

review_title: Overall great company to work for with a few kinks to iron out.
pros: Since I worked in their Military Banking division my experience may or may not be similar to those in the states. Overall really nice working environment. Great training program and support of peers to help with learning curve. Good work recognized by leadership.
cons: Very rigid guidelines to follow in certain areas that have nothing to do with customer protection or security. Very cookie-cutter design which is understandable for purpose of uniformity but taken to extreme at times.  Guidelines sometimes worked against client's favor because there was no wiggle room.

pros: you get government holidays off! you don't work sundays! You can contribute to your 401k and they will match. You can have their 'best accounts" with out having to carry the balances or pay fees.
cons: Sales goals are too high! Not enough products offered compared to other banks for example personal loans. There are not enough workers! They don't allow overtime and they don't have enough staff during the day to take care of customers and get things done. Their sales incentive for tellers in non existent.

job_title: Banking Center Manager II in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great Pay, Benefits and Hours.
cons: like anywhere else, it depends on current Manager which changes annually when they re-align and you have to learn what is important to them.  If you can get through that it's not too bad.

review_title: Lots of opportunities at the bank to pick up many new skills but be prepared to spent a lot of time at your desk.
pros: Be prepared to be challenged because you will learn many new skills in a very short amount of time. Not to mention, there are a lot of opportunities for movement across divisions.
cons: The hours are one of the biggest challenges, you could easily spent the whole day at the office and still be convinced that you could have done more, really eats into the work-life balance.

review_title: Banking just isn't what is used to be.
pros: I like working for this company because of the people. Co-workers are like family and some customers are great. The benefits and pay are what mainly keep me going as most bankers are well compensated for their performance. Hours are convenient and vacation time is great. I love that there is paid maternity leave for both expecting moms or dads.
cons:
What is expected of us is not always clear making it hard to satisfy the leadership team and the bank. The expectations change constantly making it frustrating to work. The only time a sale counts is if it books making it seem as if we aren't doing our jobs. Leadership is never satisfied with anything and makes it seem as if we are in control of our customers application outcomes. The sales goals are not fair across the board as some busier centers goals seem lower than they should and 
vice versa. The expected outcome should be based on the traffic and clientele in the area. Not all banks are located in areas where people have "money". Seems like the bank is trying to filter out many types of customers and in the process are losing focus on what really makes up a bank. They want "top talent" but are making it harder every quarter to meet our goals. Changing the incentive manual whenever they please does not give us a clear picture of what's expected.

review_title: The experience in this company  has been just that , an experience, a good one at that and a good company to work for .
pros: The pay is decent , the employees are great to work with , you have to take the initiative sometimes and change the culture at the center .
cons: no work life balance .. too much stress on management at the banking center .. not enough resource for them ..

review_title: You're expendable. A number not a person.
pros: Day care reimbursement, great medical and retirement benefits. If you're lucky a good team and a good manager that cares about you. Good training and experience overall. Excellent maternity and paternity paid time off (3 full months!)
cons: Hard work life balance, usually working six days a week. Completely always understaffed. Customers know it and say it but the bank has you lie and say that your are not understaffed and that we have online, mobile and ATM banking...which they do but it's obvious that a year ago there were 3-5 tellers, 2 plus bankers and 3 managers whereas now there is one teller, one banker and one to two managers. Pay is very low compared to any other bank. Always told to sell, sell, sell in the employee meetings then told to "do the right thing for the customer". They do not have a fiduciary understanding. You are constantly threatened to be put on disciplinary action for not making your numbers and they do put you on a lot of disciplinary action. They change everything week to week, month to month and year to year. Once you learn something, it changes and they say they promote "360 degree coaching" but they do not. Tenure means nothing to them. They need to treat people who work hard and are dedicated to the company for many years different than a new hire, which they don't. I was actually told that they have to treat everyone the same whether they've been there for a month, year, five, ten or twenty plus... if that was true then why doesn't everyone have the same salary and amount of PTO whether they've been there a month, year, five, ten or twenty. Advice to current employees....get out while you can! It's a ticking time bomb with very limited upward mobility.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Solid deal flow, opportunity to work across groups / across industries / and across regions. Access to senior bankers and group heads was above average. Strong team dynamic.
cons: Timing of my employment put a damper on morale, several rounds of RIFs. When revenue generating work was slow someone was always quick to stick you with what seemed like a meaningless internal task that often made for late nights and ruined weekends

pros: Great benefits, they pay for most of your child care, and they didn't hold it against me that I don't have a degree. They promoted me because of my work ethic and ability to learn and manage.
cons: The company has changed a lot in the 14 years I worked there. They expect you to do every single job in the branch while working with half the staff you used to have. They're making some huge associate cuts and aren't replacing anyone. That makes the assistant manager and the manager have to do everything in the branch plus worry about CRAZY high sales goals. They harp on you to be ready for audit, be on red calls if you aren't making your sales goals, email this fax over that, BUT you have to be in the lobby to lobby manage at all times. It's VERY stressful and it doesn't have to be. Upper management wants to be promoted so they need you to make them look good at whatever cost. Sell things that customers don't need do what you have to do to make the numbers make them look good. I got out at a good time. This company is doing things wrong and they stopped caring about the customer. They only care about their numbers and if they look good. If you're a customer and they can't get a sale out of you, then they will shove you out of their office and tell you to call customer service. They'll bend over backwards for you if you'll give them a sale. If not, GET OUT!  That's not how it used to be. No more suckers for the kids, no more coffee in the lobby. It's a sales center, not a coffee shop. Somewhere along the line, they stopped caring about people and only harass you to sell, sell, sell.

review_title: You are just a number on a scorecard. Company only has interest in your numbers, not your growth.
pros: BoA has a great name brand and offers a competitive employee benefits package, including health, PTO, tuition reimbursement and 401k with 5% match.
cons:
With the new "preferred rewards" strategy, the bank continues to increase the sales goals quarter to quarter while reducing the incentive dollars for each product sold, making it very difficult for bankers to make commission. These changes happen too often and fast without providing reasonable staffing, support and training. Every role at the branch level is beat down on sales day in day out every day. Each day starts with a huddle where the manager discusses the sales result from the previous day and where we need to be for the day, week and the month. The huddles are often very intense and fear-based and besides letting you know where you need to be there's little guidance or coaching to help you do better. A lot of leaders don't have sales experience and don't provide meaningful mentoring. Team morale and motivation to succed is significantly down. Branch management is stressed out from the daily pressure from higher up and the ever increasing stress trickles down fast and deeply from top to bottom of the chain. 

Associates are doing tons of more tasks on top of everything else with the expectation to meet the highly demanding sales goals and customer survey score. Tellers are extremely overworked as the company is restructuring the teller positions to save money or gear toward the self-service technologies as they say.  With just one teller, the lines are getting much longer and irate customers don't want to listen to any sales pitch. Drastic changes are made to the strategies, incentive plan, procedures and staffing far too often. With staffing issues, you will often work lunch(30 minutes) or be pulled out of lunch break to help out a customer. From the moment the bank door is open, you'll have to be ready to hustle and take it all in. Every day is a roller coaster ride.

pros: they used to pay well, have interesting stretch assignments, and value their employees. if you're lucky, maybe you can still find a team like this at the firm
cons: they are driving down comp for the majority, experience has been devalued, jobs have become bland and boring, the few do a lot and many sit in meetings most of their day. talent and team building is a thing of the past, lack of career path

pros: Childcare reimbursement...goes actually back onto your check.  Also Jacksonville, Fl corporate office has a daycare, cafeteria, and gym on the campus! Benefits are great as well. Depending on which department you're in...the supervisors are pretty awesome to work for.
cons: One supervisor can ruin your future with them. An attendance issue out of my control caused my supervisor to mark me as nonrehireable. It's been 5 years, they won't remove it. Also if you don't have certain training, it's hard to move up. I was a customer service representative for auto loans. I wanted to learn more about the mortgage industry. I was passed over continuously even applying internally. Chase offered me the opportunity to come in and learn mortgage collections, loan modifications, etc at $4 more an hour starting out and eventually $25,000 more a year about a year later!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Kannapolis, NC
pros: Salary is great; 401K opportunity is good, with very good company match; generous vacation time; ability to telecommute, when necessary, is very helpful.
cons: Lack of meaningful communication; harder to move laterally than expected; too much middle management; too many people who do not read emails, do not pay attention, and do not keep track of their own takeaways from meetings.

job_title: Consumer Products Strategic Analyst II in Plano, TX
pros: work-at-home, flexible work hours in many groups, work-life balance highly important, good salaries, very diverse, teams tend to be very open for you to learn new things outside of your regular job
cons: starting to remove work-at-home privileges, tremendous amount of org changes, more ability needed to increase salaries with title changes for internal candidates - great candidates are much more likely to leave due to compensation only

pros: The benefits are great and being in a friendly environment helps me become a better person. You should really look into it because it will change your life.
cons: Just take your time, but work at a decent pace. It  will become busy and its okay to feel rushed, that's normal. Just breathe and pace yourself because at the end you did better than expected.

review_title: Home Services Specialist, Post Closer, Property Preservation Securing Authorization Call Center Rep
job_title: Home Service Specialist in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Esthetically pleasing surroundings, giving me some work while many corporations not hiring.
cons: Superiority complexes from the permanent employees to the contractors,no confidence of potential long term employment with company who obviously would rather have contractors work a period of time and let them go so they do not have to hire them permanent and allow them benefits. The Policy that contractors who were let go when particular projects came to end, had to wait a period of at least a couple months before they could be given an opportunity to work again.

pros: Very supportive, positive place to work.  Management in the mortgage department committed to help sales staff succeed.
cons: Confusion & knee jerk reactions to small market changes.  They hired 250 mortgage professionals in Jacksonville, interest rates ticked up less than .5% and they eventually let more than half of the sales force go.

pros: They have $800 Bn in commercial loans and $30 Bn in residential/ retail lending.  They're in the business of lending money, make no mistake about it. Institutional business is sound. If you're retail, you're lucky to have the software that came over in the Merrill merger.
cons: There's over 220k employees.  The bank is massive and there's more redundancy than BCG, McKinsey or Bain could figure out if given a decade.

pros: The interview process was seamless from talking to the recruiter to meeting my Financial Center Manager. They definitely don't micro-manage you and expect for you to own your own develop with the tools and the platform they provide to you.
cons: You own your own development, so don't ask too many questions from the same people that are trying to run the branch, help all the tellers out and also help train you. So you have to be very aware and respectful of everyone's time. No hand-holding here.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Mostly good people to work with. Opportunities to work on interesting projects/ initiatives abound. Great learning opportunities as well. Your voice will be heard and you will have a say in the work you do. Avenues to make an impact abound.
Great benefits.
cons: Management changes too often. Lacking in diversity. career advancement slow. perfect place for who you know and not what you know mentality, so make sure you network a lot if you consider employment here. Internal mobility is encouraged unless management sees otherwise...

review_title: Great benefits but little opportunity to advance
job_title: Trust Administrative Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The maternity/paternity leave policy (4 months paid leave; up to an additional 2 months unpaid); pleasant co-workers; never take my work home with me; standard 40-hour work week; good work/life balance
cons: The work does not feel very meaningful.  Also, they have hired some very competent employees and given no path to advance up the ladder.  So there is a lot of dissatisfaction for that reason.

pros: I loved the people I worked with and made some great friends and managers. It was also great experience to be face to face with community members and has good benefits
cons: However, with the tightening protocol around revenue it felt like we were constantly being micro managed.  Lots of conference calls is also a downside.

review_title: Overall good company to work for BUT needs to pay attention to what the customer's concerns
pros:
Awesome benefits (reasonably priced medical premiums for families, dental, vision, child care reimbursement is a gem)

Great training, care about the development of employees

Easy to advance within company, based on performance

Great work/life balance, vacation, PTO, sick, requesting time off 

Free of fees accounts for employees
cons:
No incentive program in place for CSRs (tellers)

Work on Saturdays

No consistent raises based on performance

Understaffed and rude, angry customers fuss at tellers for having to wait for long periods of time

No more overtime, have to take longer lunch break to eliminate extra time

All busy branches aren't staffed with a relationship banker to lobby lead, which is very much necessary when lines are very long

Still using deposit slips, need to upgrade to electronic deposits 

Busy centers have to do night drop when usually not enough time to complete other tasks before opening

pros:
Mostly great people to work with. Good benefits. Considerable technology variety and scale. Strong diversity and inclusion atmosphere. Used to have strong support for remote workers.
Some departments have great work-life balance.
cons:
Layoff decisions made at the top without including 1st and 2nd level management. Lots of politics. No effort made to retain top talent.
Some departments are so understaffed that FT employees get burned out with evening and weekend coverage. Lots of older technology due to no budget for upgrades.

review_title: A company that offers meaningful career mobility...
job_title: Small Business Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Despite the position where one starts BoA offers many opportunities across different business verticals; as such, if one is driven and resourceful, the possibilities of experiencing an uptick is very possible.
cons: Like many large institutions, navigating the office culture could serve to derail or impede the type of individual who shuns "the office buddy system playbook mentality".

job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Simi Valley, CA
pros:
Excellent benefits - medical, dental, vision 401 K, tuition reimbursement (depending on field) 

Great co-workers (have made some long lasting relationships) 

Gained some great experience in a variety of areas/departments

Plenty of room for growth - depending on who you know 

HR is EXTREMELY competent at solving problems/disputes within the company. For instance - Seniority means nothing if you violate policies and procedures and get reported. You will be written up or terminated.
cons:
Depending on the department - management is HORRIBLE 

Although there is plenty of room for growth (positive) - being able to get that growth takes patience, and also is dependent on who you know in the organization - This is extremely bad for morale

Organization pays outside/new employees more than existing employees - again, bad for morale

Layoffs are indefinite due to corporate restructuring (outsourcing to other countries) as well as acquiring CountryWide Home Loans, which turned out to be a horrible liability that cost thousands of associates their jobs

Compensation is not based on experience, but on how well you negotiate for it. 

Although HR is excellent, its hard to report horrible management for fear of retaliation. You will have to have a squeaky clean record if you even fathom reporting someone in management. 

Depending on the department - the environment can be toxic and unhealthy. 

Not enough incentive given for quality work

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Lots of opportunities to move around and go to different roles.  Company is sort of structured like a consulting firm in that way.  Very good parental leave policy (16 weeks paid leave).  Good company benefits.
cons: Very large organization.  Can take time to have decisions made.  Rarely are you making decisions in a silo, and must include several business or support partners, which can lengthen the process.

review_title: Technology manager focused on delivering many software infrastructures for application hosting.
job_title: Senior Vice President Senior Technology Manager in Jacksonville, FL

As a long time employee,  I decided to leave because of this.  Also,  I thought the benefits were good until I went to another large competitor and realized that  it was not the case.

review_title: Decent Job for new college grad looking to start in the invesment world.
pros:
* Adequate training resources for obtaining licenses (online quizzes, study guides but all self-motivated). Once you get your Series 7 + 63 or 66 however, all studying is done on your own time.

* Will give you a crash course on Investment world and customer service if you lack the experience.

* Training staff is very encouraging, supportive and knowledgeable. 

* Having market holidays off (but that's most financial jobs)

* Paid while studying to obtain your Series 7

* Will provide free food when call volumes are very high (they'll often ask you to work through lunch to help)

* Cafeteria was great

* Pays fairly well for no college degree required

* Quarterly bonuses can be rewarding if you hit all metrics

* Multiple campuses throughout US tend to offer opportunities from time-to-time for promotions on the higher teams if you are a great deepener and ok with relocating.
cons:
* It's a call-center. Need I say more?

* HEAVILY micromanaged (breaks & lunch are assigned to you daily and differ, have to submit e-mail to team leads every day of every moment you weren't taking calls. Every second not spent on the phone with client or "available" to take a call is tallied, ultimately counts against you and could lose bonuses because of).

* Approx 5 mins given after each call to enter notes, submit requests to other teams, print off documents, essentially to TAKE CARE OF ALL CLIENT BUSINESS - after 5 mins, team lead will call you out in front of team asking if you need more time, or if call volumes are high, tell you to do it after market hours.

* Service roles are still very sales driven (will lose QA points if you don't mention services or products customer doesn't already have, no matter how irate client might be)

* Work environment is loud and rather chaotic on the floor.

* Promotions are only given to those with high 'Deepening' numbers, which means, convincing a client to talk about their Non-Merrill assets with another specialist. All other metrics (QA, Customer Satisfaction, Retention, etc...are an afterthought for promotions)

* Once you're licensed, you essentially thrown into the role with very little help. Sink or swim type mentality. 

*Team leads often seem "too busy" or "annoyed" when you ask for help or have any questions. You're always referred to a very internal search engine or calling to other depts to find answers.

* Constant coaching/monitoring of your calls, for those that appreciate freedom and flexibility in their work, this is NOT THE ENVIRONMENT FOR YOU.

* 24 hr call center, so you may end up working weekends, overnight, etc. and all shifts are based on tenure.

* Requesting for days off VERY DIFFICULT; they ask you to submit days off literally months before. (ex. Xmas holiday requests in May/June)

pros: The employees at my branch were top-notch individuals - a quality that speaks well to the branch manager who hired them.
cons: At the branch level, some company executives would visit and make claims of being more customer-centric, however, when new policies were enacted, they were not in my opinion, geared toward customers.  I understand that BoA is a very successful business, but wish they would have done more for the customer.

pros: Industry standard benefits, high tenure and experience, great coworkers
cons: No work/life balance, antiquated performance review process, inferior office spaces, bogged down in red tape, low autonomy, high work-around and manual process environment, no longer focused on being the best place to work, low career progression for professionals/executives

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Vancouver, WA
pros: The benefits are phenomenal. Excellent medical benefits (also allowed me to have my mom on the insurance), dental, vision, 401k with matching contributions, child care reimbursement, automatic enrollment in preferred rewards, paid holidays, 2 weeks paid vacation, and 2 weeks of paid sick leave.
cons:
- Poor staffing behind teller row (do not be surprised if you left alone to take care of clients inside the center and in the drive up).
- TERRIBLE incentive bonuses
- Borderline unethical business practices - staffing hours are cut to encourage digital banking. When people complain about the staff, the bank blames the client for "choosing" to come to the center and they deserve to lose 30 minutes of their day because of their decision to come into a financial center instead of using the ATM.
- Your success is 100% in the hands of other people (you only get credit if a banker remembers to give you credit. You can only advance or move somewhere else if your manager approves the transfer. If your manager refuses to lose you as a teller, your options are to deal with it or quit)
- Only the numbers on your scorecard matter; other factors do not matter. I worked at a center that was set to close its doors. The banker was transferred to another financial center so there was nobody there to help clients. I was forced to accept a 0 on my BCR score (40% of my scorecard) and upper management essentially told us, "tough luck, deal with it".
- Money matters, not people. Sales get helped right away while servicing is referred to the customer service phone number. I've literally seen millions of dollars get pulled due to this mentality.
- No trust. Bankers and managers get very little freedom when trying to help a clients. review_title: Bank of America great benefits, great stress.
pros: The bank is well known, and stable.  It is a rather secure bank when compared to smaller financial institutions.  It also has very good benefits even for part time employees.  The retail bank is a reliable work arrangement with little fear of layoff.  There is a great retirement package that still includes a Pension plan, and also provides a 401K contribution match.  The benefits are the sole reason many people remain with the bank when other working conditions are considered.  There are also options for working from home for service and administrative positions which allow great flexibility for some employees.  These facts combine to make Bank of America a good prospect for employment.
cons: The retail bank is a very stressful place to work and has extremely poor compensation.  The bank is constantly attempting to create more account opportunities from those who seek services at the banking centers and use tellers as the main referal source.  The work as a teller gets more and more complex with higher and higher expectations for performance (mainly sales referrals) without regard for workload or compensation.  There is a philosophy of "Pay for performance" that the bank has taken on, which is not well applied to the lowest levels of bank employment (the tellers).  Our incentive package does not provide incentive, as it is only a nominal amount of money (maximum of $1000 per year- depending on the branch performance, not simply the individual's).  With the hourly rate of pay being extremely low, even compared to other banks in the area, the incentive is not motivating and does not produce greater performance.

pros:
Big company, lots of opportunities. There is a very diverse number of jobs and all skill levels are needed in the company.
The bank invests in good equipment for it's workers. An employee can see openings in other departments and seek to be transferred. The chance to work from home is very good for technical workers. Bank of America has been buying out other banks and financial instituions and as they merge, yes, there is some overlap but also there is opportunity also.  If one succeeds in doing a good job on the merge of one company they become more senior and are a valuable resource for the next merger or simplification of a business system or process.
cons: Big company, lots of "process". As you can imagine a lot of process is needed but often the biggest part of any job is to fill out the paper work or business required audit trail for every action. I am hoping that the senior management can simplify the process so that each individual can get more work done. If we get more work done we can be more competitive and reduce the time to market the development of programs and procedures that help our customers. That way we would be able to spend more time with the customers and insure that they are pleased with our systems and services.
